title: Researching new venues
description: Our current venue for meetups, Dial Arch, is proving quite noisy with sports often being played loudly on TV so we're going to research new places to meet on Thursday night. There are a couple of new pubs opening in Woolwich Arsenal which we are going to check out to see if they are more suitable. Let's meet in front of the Dial Arch.

title: In person Critiquing session at The Equitable in Woolwich.
description:
This will be an in person critiquing session. We'll be back upstairs in The Equitable in Woolwich for this one.
https://woolwichequitable.com/

Based on our experience in our last in person session, we will only critique three extracts.

I will send out the extracts on the Sunday before the session to those who sign up.

The purpose of this meeting is to provide and receive critique on submitted extracts of members' creative writing, whether they're working on a novel, screenplay, poetry, a memoir or short story, etc. We share our extracts via email ahead of the meeting to give us all a chance to read the work in our own time and reflect upon it so as to be able to provide useful critique.

If you are new to the group we ask that you participate in at least two of the critiquing sessions before you submit work for review so that you get to know us and have a good understanding of how we operate. This will help you to get the most from a critique of your own work.

title: Bring your laptop, and work on your own material in convivial company
description:
This meetup is still free. You will be refunded if you attend. The £2 is simply to dissuade people from signing up and not attending.

The venue is the Snug in the Woolwich Equitable; turn left once you come into the pub and you should find us in the separate room there.

You don't have to bring a laptop. Use a pen and paper or clay tablet and stylus if that's what works for you.

title: Break the ice, Pitch our Ideas and Write!
description:
As the first meetup of the group, we shall make introductions over coffee and pitch our ideas. After an hour of writing, those who feel like sharing can do a live reading for feedback on the beginning of their work.

(Please make sure your laptops are charged as there may not be enough outlets for everyone)

We will be gathering upstairs where we have an allocated space for up to 26 people.

THE PROGRAM:

6pm to 7.30pm- Arrive and Write

7.30pm-8pm- Introductions (So that the members can get to know each other)

8pm-9pm- Pitch, Live readings and discussions.

You can read your work and discuss creative blocks or ideas (6 spots available for 10 mins. block each). You can email me or volunteer on the day. Dont be shy!

A refreshing beer at the Famous Market Porter in Borough Market to mark the event!

IMPORTANT:

Also, do RSVP if you cannot make it so that people on the waiting list can attend. Do be considerate.

Many Thanks everyone and see you soon.

xxR

title: Break the ice, Pitch our Ideas and Write! Part 2
description:
As we are still in the first month of our novel writing challenge 2014, we shall welcome new members. You can pitch your idea to the group. After an hour of writing, those who feel like sharing can do a live reading for feedback on the beginning of their work.

(Please make sure your laptops are charged as there may not be enough outlets for everyone)

We will be gathering upstairs where we have an allocated space for up to 30-35 people.

THE PROGRAM:

6pm to 7.30pm- Arrive and Write

7.30pm-8pm- Introductions (So that the members can get to know each other)

8pm-9pm- Pitch, Live readings and discussions.

You can read your work and discuss creative blocks or ideas (6 spots available for 10 mins. block each). You can email me or volunteer on the day. Dont be shy!

IMPORTANT:

Also, do RSVP if you cannot make it so that people on the waiting list can attend. Do be considerate.

Many Thanks everyone and see you soon.

xxR

title: Write-In, Discussions and Live Readings!
description:
We are in our 2nd month now and we should have 5000-8000 words in or be halfway into planning the novel. Screenwriters should have completed research and outlines, and should have begun writing their treatments or scripts.

PROGRAM:

6pm to 8pm- Arrive and Write

8pm to 9pm- Live discussions and Readings.

Beer at the infamous Market Porter after our workouts!

Looking forward to it.

x R

title: Write-In, Discussions and Live Readings!
description:
Lets encourage, inspire and support ourselves and our fellow writers to complete our fabulous novels by the end of the year!

The sessions will follow a format of 60-90 mins of writing time and thereafter 60-90 mins of discussions or live readings.

Optional: A pint at the local Pub after our mental workouts!

Optional: A pint at the local Pub after our mental workouts!

title: Another Meeting
description: Back again, but this time it's Tuesday

title: Another Meeting
description: Like a pheonix from the ashes, we're back. At this meeting it'll be the usual readings and discussion plus we decide the future of this group (which will include a likely name change and the hunt for a new venue) so get on it.

title: Yet Another Meeting
description:
Excuse the short notice x x x

Usual time of half six and readings at half seven

title: Same Old Same Old
description: Yet another gathering (presuming we get permission from the pub)

title: A Bit Of Writing and a Bit of Reading
description: Folks, we're back again. Come along at half six for a writing block until roughly half seven. This will followed by some readings from members that will be met with constructive feedback by the group. Afterwards a pint or two will likely be enjoyed. If you'd like to read out feel free to bring a submission or email it to londonbridgewriters@gmail.com please aim for no more than 2500 words.

title: Trying Again: Writing And Readings
description: After last week (to my knowledge) kind of fell through lets try again. This will be another piece of writing time between 6.30 and 7.30 before we read some of our stuff out and discuss it in detail - submissions are welcome, so bring it and preferably email email it to londonbridgewriters@gmail.com so we can all have a gander on the night via the web.

title: Another Meeting
description: We are back again. Half six for writing and readings from half seven with feedback. Note the last few meetings have been very quiet so if we cannot guarantee four people then this may be cancelled on the day.

title: London Bridge Writers Group - First meetup of 2015!
description:
This is the first meetup of the year. I can see that a number of new people have joined the group, due (I suspect) to New Years resolutions. Therefore, let me just run through what the meetup will be about.

The format for this first meeting will be;

7pm to 7.30pm - Meet and greet. A chance to establish what everyone's aims for the years are, what you are working on and what you hope to get out of the group.

7.30 to 9pm - A chance for willing participants to read out a piece of writing that they have been working on, in order to receive constructive feedback from the group. This is completely voluntary, and I am sure some of the regulars will have been feverishly writing over Christmas.

9pm onwards - Get drunk in the pub downstairs... what better time than a Monday night? In seriousness, we normally have a couple of drinks and some lively debates (sometimes about plays/novels/movies - but often not).

As this is the first week, we will also discuss if the timings and setup of the group suit everyone, and will adjust accordingly for the subsequent meetups.

This group was founded last year as a challenge to write a novel or screenplay in a year. It has since evolved into a more general writing group, and the members have often been working on multiple projects. That being said, we would encourage you to bring along a decent sized writing project if you intend on attending regularly, both so that you get the most out of the group and we have the pleasure of seeing it evolve week on week.

Those in attendance range from complete novices (like myself), to well seasoned writers. Whatever your level we would welcome you to the group.

title: London Bridge Writers' Group - Pub Meet
description:
**The George Inn**
The George provides the room free of charge (they are awesome), and we encourage you to purchase drinks (and food – the burgers are great!). As it’s a pub and not a picnic area, please don’t consume your own food and drink there.

**Format**
We start at 7pm and run until 9pm. We hear approximately six readings of 10 minutes (\~2000 words), then discuss the piece for 10 minutes. Email your work to: london60transmitter@emailitin.com as an attachment (It must be an attachment). A link for access to googledocs will be given at the start of each session to enable people to read along, which in turn enables more considered feedback. Work submitted will be automatically deleted after 10 days. We decide on readers/pieces at the beginning of each session.

**Safe and respectful space**
The group is run by volunteers, and we don’t have the capacity to read submitted work in advance. If there is anything in your work that might distress or disturb some readers, for example concerning any kind of abuse, please give a trigger warning before you read. Be specific and concise. If it becomes apparent during a reading that a piece is inappropriate, the moderator will stop the reading. In discussing others’ work, please be mindful of how you express yourself and do not use discriminatory language, even if such language features in the piece.

Work submitted will be automatically deleted after 10 days. We decide on readers/pieces at the beginning of each session.

description:

title: Fiction Writing Style (Three Key Elements) - Workshop and Discussion
description:
One of the key aspects of fiction writing is developing and using an adept style of writing. There are many elements that go towards this, but for this meet-up we will concentrate on three of these.

This session will delve into elements that go towards writing and we will concentrate on the fabric (so to speak) of writing style.

PLEASE NOTE: This will be an interactive session sitting around a table. So you will discuss and engage with other members of the meeting.

AGENDA:

1. Show, don't tell (Detail/Specifics).
2. Evocation (Evoking emotions).
3. Profluence (Profluence).

1. SHOW, DON' TELL:

One of the most commonly discussed aspects of writing style. - We will discuss this and then try some examples. Starting with some basic 'tell' sentences and then developing them to see how they can be improved.

In this session there will be around four or more sentences that will be given to the group for jumping off points. Some time will be allowed for the group to chat and come up with suggestions for how the sentence(s) can be developed.

E.G.

- 'John walks down the street to his grandmother's house.'

Nothing wrong with the above sentence, but it is not engaging with the reader.

Instead, try writing:

- 'Every step was like walking through mud, as sweat rolled down his cheeks and an impending feeling of doom saturated John’s mind, for he knew that soon he will be at his grandmother’s house.'

2. EVOCATION:

Evoking emotions. This is a sure fire way to engage with your audience. There are many ways to do this and (perhaps worryingly at times) newspapers or websites often do this with great effect even though they are not writing fiction.

Creating an impulsive or engaging feeling that draws in the reader. This can be subtle or have a great effect.

We will discuss examples and ways of how to do this. Ways to do this could be show injustice, love, vengeance... etc..

We will also write some example paragraphs that evoke emotions.

3. PROFLUENCE:

Moving your story forward and keeping the reader engaged.

There are numerous ways to do this and some of these will be discussed.

For example plot points, creating anticipation, revealing a mystery, etc... Are all ways and methods to keep your reader interested.

-------------

Other Details:

1. Although not 100% necessary - it would be a very good idea to bring along a notepad and pen/pencil.

2. This will be a short session of 1 hour and 30 mins.

3. Please remember to bring a photo ID and scan it at the guest registration tablets at the front desk when you. If your photo ID does not successfully scan, please check in at the tablet as a guest of "Meetup Event".

4. Any questions please ask.

5. As the topic of writing style is huge it will concentrate on three aspects and will cover as much as possible in the short time available in this session.

6. Location:

WeWork 12 Hammersmith Grove
12 Hammersmith Grove London W6 7AP
April 18, 2019 5.30 PM to 7:00 PM

title: Developing your Writing Style (Evocation and Show, Don't Tell) - Workshop
description:
One of the key aspects of fiction writing is developing and using an adept style of writing. There are many elements that go towards this, but for this meet-up, we will concentrate on:- 'Show, Don't Tell' and 'Evocation.'

This session will delve into these key elements that go towards an effective writing style.

-----------------

NOTE: This will be an interactive session sitting around a table. So you will discuss and engage with other members of the meeting.

This session suits both new or experienced writers who are looking for a refresh or discussion on these topics.

------------------

AGENDA: (5.30pm to 7.00pm).

1. Show, Don't Tell (Detail/Specifics).
2. Evocation (Evoking emotions).
3. Cultivation of a Paragraph (bringing your own example).

1. SHOW, DON' TELL:

One of the most commonly discussed aspects of writing style. We will discuss this and then try some examples. Starting with some basic 'tell' sentences and then developing them to see how they can be improved.

In this session, there will be around four or more sentences that will be given to the group for jumping off points. Some time will be allowed for the group to chat and come up with suggestions for how the sentence(s) can be developed.

E.G.

- 'John walks down the street to his grandmother's house.'

Nothing wrong with the above sentence, but it is not engaging with the reader.

Instead, try writing:

- 'Every step was like walking through mud, as sweat rolled down his cheeks and an impending feeling of doom saturated John’s mind, for he knew that soon he will be at his grandmother’s house.'

2. EVOCATION:

Evoking emotions. This is a sure fire way to engage with your audience. There are many ways to do this and (perhaps worryingly at times) newspapers or websites often do this with great effect even though they are not writing fiction.

Creating an impulsive or engaging feeling that draws in the reader. This can be subtle or have a great effect.

We will discuss examples and ways of how to do this. Ways to do this could be show injustice, love, vengeance... etc..

We will also create a paragraph and use that to evoke emotions.

3. YOUR PARAGRAPH:

As part of this meet-up please prepare a paragraph on any subject you wish. (I will bring along one to discuss as well).

Then bring this to the meet-up and at the end of the workshop as a group we will look at this paragraph and discuss how (if possible) it can be built upon.

You don't need to print this out and can just read it out from your phone or laptop.

-----------------

Other Details:

1. Although not 100% necessary - it would be a very good idea to bring along a notepad and pen/pencil.

2. There will be handouts you can also write on.

3. Please remember to bring a photo ID and scan it at the guest registration tablets at the front desk when you. If your photo ID does not successfully scan, please check in at the tablet as a guest of "Meetup Event".

4. I may take some photos on my mobile and these will only be shared on the meet-up to help promote the group.

5. Location:

WeWork 12 Hammersmith Grove
Room E1
12 Hammersmith Grove
London
W6 7AP

title: A social and chance to meetup with fellow writers
description:
This meetup is a casual social for writers who wish to meet other writers in a friendly atmosphere.

This meetup could be a spring-board for creating relationships with writers that you find common interests with, and potentially for feedback, support, brainstorming and all other matters that relate to writing.

There is no agenda, but to help guide the conversation for this meetup - please consider the three points below for discussion:

1. What writing are you working on?
2. When do you hope to have it finished by?
3. What are your next steps?

--------------------------

--- My plan is to create a mastermind group or potentially several mastermind groups could sprout from this meetup (and repeat meetups like it). ---

Although this is meetup is not a mastermind group itself, but a pre-cursor to meeting other writers that you find you have common interests with.

-------------------------

The word “mastermind” was coined by Napoleon Hill in the 1920s. Hill believed that when two people come together to solve a problem, their combined wisdom forms a “master mind.”

He urged budding entrepreneurs to form mastermind groups (or “alliances”, as he called them) where they could keep each other accountable to their goals and give each other advice about their projects.

The Inklings is one of the best-known mastermind groups formed by writers. Headed by C. S. Lewis and J. R. R. Tolkien, the group gathered on Thursday evenings at Lewis’s rooms in Magdalen College. Later on, they would also meet for lunch at a local Oxford pub called The Eagle and Child.

The members of the group came together to share ideas and receive feedback on the latest drafts of their novels. Tolkien, for example, read aloud from a manuscript that would eventually become The Lord of the Rings.

(The section above about mastermind groups was written by Nicole Bianchi).

title: Ghost Stories - How to write a short ghost story in the classic Jamesian style
description:
In the workshop, we will discuss ideas, structure and plot points that relate to classic victorian ghost stories and in particular those of M.R.James.

The aim will be for you to learn how to write in a Jamesian style and then in your own time proceed to write a short ghost story.

If you already have a lot of experience in this genre, please still feel to join and share your knowledge.

--------------------------------

Agenda:

The meetup will be a laid back workshop and participants will be encouraged to engage in the discussion.

1. A short introduction to the Jamesian style.

2. An overview of general approaches to making your writing suspenseful:
2.1 Limit the POV.
2.2 Style and form.
2.3 Dramatic irony.

Then the body of the meetup will be for all to discuss and come up with ideas following the points below - for your own ghost stories.

- We will stop halfway through for a short break of around 10 mins.

3. The Jamesian Style:
3.1 Location and setting.
3.2 The main protagonist.
3.3 An object.

I will bring some specific examples of characters and settings from some of James stories.

--------------------------------

To create the perfect Jamesian ghost story you will need the ingredients below:

1. A quaint, ancient setting. Such as a twee English country village, an estranged seaside town or a stately Abbey. James loved to utilise the antiquity of a colourful setting with an isolated atmosphere.

2. A lady or gentleman protagonist. Many of James’ characters are naive reserved scholars, who are often not convinced something strange is happening until the final climax of the story.

3. A pivotal antiquarian object. Whether an old book or an antique, the discovery of a mystery object that unlocks and attracts an unwelcome figure from beyond the grave is a signature mark of James’ stories.

-------------------------

The story that you produce will be after the meetup, will be at your own pace and in your own time, but it would be great to see your short stories, if you wish to share them, once they have been completed.

-------------------------

James was a lecturer at Cambridge University and at Christmas time he became well known for reading back his ghost stories.

He was master of the uncanny, the purveyor of the uncomfortable and a writer renowned for his atmospheric ghostly tales. It was also in Victorian times a tradition to tell ghost stories and one of the most famous ghost stories of all time was set in the Christmas period - that, of course, being "A Christmas Carol" by Charles Dickens.

Jameson ghost storytelling was straight down the line and revolved around the idea of real ghosts, not psychological illusions or paranoid affects of the human mind. So if you prefer writing psychological type ghost or horror stories then this workshop may not be for you.

- Just to note - although Jame's stories were published in the Edwardian period, he wrote and shared them primarily during at the end of the Victorian period.

--------------------------------

The writer M.R. James once said: “Two ingredients most valuable in the concocting of a ghost story are the atmosphere and the nicely managed crescendo.… Let us, then, be introduced to the actors in a placid way; let us see them going about their ordinary business, undisturbed by forebodings, pleased with their surroundings; and into this calm environment let the ominous thing put out its head, unobtrusively at first, and then more insistently, until it holds the stage.”

-------------------------

The owner of Frequency Cafe has kindly let us use this space for free. Although you don't have to, please do consider buying a coffee or something to eat if you can.

title: Creativity Workshop for fiction writers: kickstart your imagination
description:
This writing workshop is for writers of all levels of experience who are interested in fiction (short stories, novels, screenplays, etc.). We will be exploring various methods of generating ideas and tapping into your creativity. The tools used will include freewriting, visual prompts, randomizers (i.e. story cubes) and more.

Throughout the day, the activities will build on each other so that when you leave you should have plenty of material to work with on your own if you wish. You will also have lots of new tricks and strategies that you can use in the future if you get creatively stuck or are searching for new ideas.

This workshop is perfect for anyone who is looking to start a new project, is battling writers block, or simply wants to explore their creative side (you don't have to be an experienced writer to join! beginners are more than welcome!)

Come with a notebook, pen, computer, whatever you prefer to write with -- and a willingness to play and explore!

Spaces are limited so please only RSVP if you can make it. If something comes up, no prob! Just change your RSVP so someone else can have your space.

We will be in the function room in the back of Artisan Coffee in Ealing Broadway.

title: Developing your Writing Style (Evocation and Show, Don't Tell) (Online)
description:
One of the key aspects of fiction writing is developing and using an adept style of writing. There are many elements that go towards this, but for this meet-up, we will concentrate on:- 'Show, Don't Tell' and 'Evocation.'

This session will delve into these key elements that go towards an effective writing style.

-----------------

NOTE: This will be an interactive session sitting around a table. So you will discuss and engage with other members of the meeting.

This session suits both new or experienced writers who are looking for a refresh or discussion on these topics.

------------------

AGENDA: (7 pm to 8.30 pm).

1. Show, Don't Tell (Detail/Specifics).
2. Evocation (Evoking emotions).
3. Cultivation of a Paragraph (bringing your own example).

1. SHOW, DON' TELL:

One of the most commonly discussed aspects of writing style. We will discuss this and then try some examples. Starting with some basic 'tell' sentences and then developing them to see how they can be improved.

In this session, there will be around four or more sentences that will be given to the group for jumping off points. Some time will be allowed for the group to chat and come up with suggestions for how the sentence(s) can be developed.

E.G.

- 'John walks down the street to his grandmother's house.'

Nothing wrong with the above sentence, but it may not be engaging with the reader.

Instead, try writing:

- 'Every step was like walking through mud, as sweat rolled down his cheeks and an impending feeling of doom saturated John’s mind, for he knew that soon he will be at his grandmother’s house.'

2. EVOCATION:

Evoking emotions. This is a sure fire way to engage with your audience. There are many ways to do this and (perhaps worryingly at times) newspapers or websites often do this with great effect even though they are not writing fiction.

Creating an impulsive or engaging feeling that draws in the reader. This can be subtle or have a great effect.

We will discuss examples and ways of how to do this. Ways to do this could be show injustice, love, vengeance... etc..

We will also create a paragraph and use that to evoke emotions.

3. YOUR PARAGRAPH:

As part of this meet-up please prepare a paragraph on any subject you wish. (I will bring along one to discuss as well).

Then bring this to the meet-up and at the end of the workshop as a group we will look at this paragraph and discuss how (if possible) it can be built upon.

You don't need to print this out and can just read it out from your phone or laptop.

-----------------

Other Details:

1. This meetup will be held online and I will share the link nearer to the workshop time.

2. The meetup will be held using a video service called Whereby.

3. I will share handouts via google docs at the start of the meeting - but I will need an email address to share these.

----- This session will be on Skype -----

Any questions please do ask.

title: Build a free WordPress.Com Website - An online hub for you as a writer (Skype)
description:
Hi all,

- In this meetup, you will be taken through the process of setting up your own free WordPress website.

- This process will be using wordpress.com and will cover the setup of a simple website including a homepage, contact and blog page.

- This online workshop is suitable for those who have never used WordPress before or would consider themselves at a beginner level.

--------------------

PLEASE NOTE:

-- This workshop will take place over Skype.

-- There is a small charge for this meetup/workshop.

-- I will send you my skype address once you have signed up, or please contact me directly through meet-up for my skype address.

-- You will not need any coding skills for this workshop.

-- As this website will be provided for free from WordPress – the URL (website address) will have WordPress in the title. E.g. It will be – www.mysite.wordpress.com instead of www.mysite.com.

---------------------

It goes without saying that in the modern-day world a huge amount of communication and information is provided from the internet and accessed through mobile devices and desktop PCs.

By staking a space for yourself online you are creating a central point for where you can share and display your work. And also where you can promote your work and potentially build a community.

This will be a short 2-hour course and by the end of it, you will have a WordPress.com website and will have the basic knowledge to be able to go on and build similar Wordpress.com sites.

------------------
Agenda:

1. Introduction:
1.1 The difference between WordPress.com and Wordpress.org
1.2 Creating a clear vision for your website.
1.3 Listing the key requirements and prioritising.

2. Sourcing design assets and images.

3. Stage 1:
3.1 Setting up the site.
3.2 Choosing a template to start with.

4. Stage 2:
4.1 Initial configuration.
4.2 Adding pages.
4.3 Adding posts.
4.4 Adding a Menu and Customisation.

5. An Agile approach: Don’t aim to be perfect! Some of the best feedback you’ll get is when the site is live.

------------------

Any questions please ask.

(The course will be held by Chris Mitchell who has worked in technology and project management roles for over 10 years and who has built numerous websites, both large and small.)

title: Creative Writing Workshop: Write Away Those Cobwebs!
description:
This will be our first in-person (and SOCIALLY DISTANCED) creative writing workshop since you-know-when, perfect for anyone who's longing to shake off those lockdown cobwebs and let their imaginations run free.

This writing workshop will consist of various exercises and prompts intended to help you generate new ideas and tap into your creativity. You don't need to have anything you're already working on (though if you do, also cool), and you don't have to share your work with the group if you don't want to. Writers of all levels of experience are welcome (and If you've attended before, note that there will be no repeat exercises: all fresh material here!)

Throughout the session, the activities will build on each other so that when you leave you should have plenty of material to work with on your own if you wish. You will also have lots of new tricks and strategies that you can use in the future if you get creatively stuck or are searching for new ideas. This workshop is perfect for anyone who is looking to start a new project, is battling writer's block, or simply wants to explore their creative side (beginners are more than welcome!).

Come with a notebook, pen, computer (bearing in mind that we will be outdoors), whatever you prefer to write with -- and a willingness to play and explore!

Arrive at 2pm for a 2:15ish start. We will be meeting by the gazebo in Walpole Park (which is near the cafe and near-ish the pond). Bring something to sit on if you wish (i.e. pillow or blanket as we will be on the ground). We will have hand sanitiser, but bring your own if you can!

There are no refunds available for this event, but if something happens on the day please get in touch, we may be able to give you a place on a different workshop at a later date.

Again, we will be VERY STRICT ABOUT SOCIAL DISTANCING at this event. Masks are optional as we will be outdoors, but please maintain the recommended distance as much as possible.

See you then!!

title: (NOW ONLINE!) Creative Writing Workshop: How to write PROSE that FLOWS
description:
Update: THIS EVENT IS NOW ONLINE

This will be a fun and informative creative writing workshop for writers of all levels of experience.

In this writing workshop, we will explore what it is that makes words 'flow' on the page, with close analysis of different writing samples by authors who are renowned for writing intelligent and page-turning fiction. We will then discuss how to achieve the same effect in your own writing, working from various prompts and exercises so that you leave the workshop with expanded knowledge on the matter as well as a few creative tricks up your sleeve.

Come ready with a notebook, pen, computer, whatever you prefer to write with -- and a willingness to play and explore!

title: Developing your Writing Style (Evocation and Show, Don't Tell) (Online)
description:
One of the key aspects of fiction writing is developing and using an adept and clear style of writing. There are many elements that go towards this, but for this meet-up, we will concentrate on:- 'Show, Don't Tell' and 'Evocation.'

This session will delve into these key elements that go towards an effective writing style.

-----------------

NOTE: This will be an interactive session online, so you will discuss and engage with other members of the meeting.

This session is suited more towards new writers, but is also open to those who are more experienced and looking for a refresh, or a discussion on these topics.

------------------

AGENDA:

1. Show, Don't Tell (Detail/Specifics).
2. Evocation (Evoking emotions).
3. Cultivation of a Paragraph (bringing your own example).

1. SHOW, DON' TELL:

One of the most commonly discussed aspects of writing style. We will discuss this and then try some examples. Starting with some basic 'tell' sentences and then developing them to see how they can be improved.

In this session, there will be around four or more sentences that will be given to the group for jumping-off points. Some time will be allowed for the group to chat and come up with suggestions for how the sentence(s) can be developed.

E.G.

- 'John walks down the street to his grandmother's house.'

Nothing wrong with the above sentence, but it may not be engaging with the reader.

Instead, try writing:

- 'Every step was like walking through mud, as sweat rolled down his cheeks and an impending feeling of doom saturated John’s mind, for he knew that soon he will be at his grandmother’s house.'

2. EVOCATION:

Evoking emotions. This is a sure-fire way to engage with your audience. There are many ways to do this and (perhaps worryingly at times) newspapers or websites often do this with great effect even though they are not writing fiction.

Creating an impulsive or engaging feeling that draws in the reader. This can be subtle or have a great effect.

We will discuss examples and ways of how to do this. Ways to do this could be show injustice, love, vengeance... etc..

We will also create a paragraph and use that to evoke emotions.

3. YOUR PARAGRAPH:

As part of this meet-up please prepare a paragraph on any subject you wish. (I will bring along one to discuss as well).

Then bring this to the meet-up and at the end of the workshop as a group we will look at this paragraph and discuss how (if possible) it can be built upon.

-----------------

Other Details:

1. This meetup will be held online and I will share the link nearer to the workshop time directly with those that sign up. I will be using https://jitsi.org/

FYI - Jitsi is a super easy to use video conference tool and does not require an account to use.

2. I will share handouts via google docs at the start of the meeting - but I will need an email address to share these, or I will just message them directly over meetup.

3. There are no refunds available for this event, but if you can't make it on the day please get in touch, we may be able to give you a place on a different workshop at a later date.

title: Ghost Stories - How to write a short ghost story in the classic Jamesian style
description:
In the workshop, we will discuss ideas, structure and plot points that relate to classic victorian ghost stories and in particular those of M.R.James.

The aim will be for you to learn how to write in a Jamesian style and if you wish in your own time to proceed and write a short ghost story.

If you already have a lot of experience in this genre, please still feel to join and share your knowledge.

--------------------------------

Agenda:

1. A short introduction to the Jamesian style.

2. Before delving further into ghost stories a short look at ways to make your writing suspenseful:

2.1 Limit the POV.
2.2 Style and form.
2.3 Dramatic irony.

Then the body of the meetup will be for all to discuss and come up with ideas following the points below - for your own ghost stories.

Participants will be encouraged to engage in the discussion, so please feel free to add your thoughts and questions.

3. The Jamesian Style:
3.1 Location and setting.
3.2 The main protagonist.
3.3 An object.

I will bring some specific examples of characters and settings from some of James stories.

--------------------------------

To create the perfect Jamesian ghost story you will need the ingredients below:

1. A quaint, ancient setting. Such as a twee English country village, an estranged seaside town or a stately Abbey. James loved to utilise the antiquity of a colourful setting with an isolated atmosphere.

2. A lady or gentleman protagonist. Many of James’ characters are naive reserved scholars, who are often not convinced something strange is happening until the final climax of the story.

3. A pivotal antiquarian object. Whether an old book or an antique, the discovery of a mystery object that unlocks and attracts an unwelcome figure from beyond the grave is a signature mark of James’ stories.

-------------------------

The story that you produce will be after the meetup, will be at your own pace and in your own time, but it would be great to see your short stories if you wish to share them.

-------------------------

James was a lecturer at Cambridge University and at Christmas time he became well known for reading back his ghost stories.

He was master of the uncanny, the purveyor of the uncomfortable and a writer renowned for his atmospheric ghostly tales. It was also in Victorian times a tradition to tell ghost stories and one of the most famous ghost stories of all time was set in the Christmas period - that, of course, being "A Christmas Carol" by Charles Dickens.

Jameson ghost storytelling was straight down the line and revolved around the idea of real ghosts, not psychological illusions or paranoid affects of the human mind. So if you prefer writing psychological type ghost or horror stories then this workshop may not be for you.

- Just to note - although Jame's stories were published in the Edwardian period, he wrote and shared them primarily during at the end of the Victorian period.

--------------------------------

The writer M.R. James once said: “Two ingredients most valuable in the concocting of a ghost story are the atmosphere and the nicely managed crescendo.… Let us, then, be introduced to the actors in a placid way; let us see them going about their ordinary business, undisturbed by forebodings, pleased with their surroundings; and into this calm environment let the ominous thing put out its head, unobtrusively at first, and then more insistently, until it holds the stage.”

-------------------------

1. This meetup will be held online and I will share the link nearer to the workshop time directly with those that sign up. I will most likely be using https://jitsi.org/ or Google Meet.

FYI - Jitsi is a super easy to use video conference tool and does not require an account to use.

2. There are no refunds available for this event, but if you can't make it on the day please get in touch, we may well be able to give you a place on a different workshop at a later date.

description:

This meeting will be held over Jitsi video Conference.

title: Creative Writing Workshop: Plotting your story's emotional arc
description:
A story is so much more than Plot and Things That Happen.

A story is first and foremost about character and WHY the events of the plot matter to them.

This fun and highly informative creative writing workshop will seek to dispel common creative writing myths and help you to understand not only WHY you need to know your story's emotional arc, but HOW to go about achieving this and weaving emotional significance into every step of your story.

Having a solid emotional arc is essential for so many reasons: (1) It keeps readers hooked because they want to find out WHAT HAPPENS NEXT, (2) It makes YOU a better writer because you will know your characters intimately, making it less likely that you will lose steam or come up against the dreaded writers block, and (3) It means that your story will flow organically and naturally from start to finish, leading to a seamless and deeply satisfying end product.

We will start by thoroughly exploring what emotional arc means and why your story needs an emotional core. We will then guide you through the experience of building your story's emotional arc, and you will leave the workshop with a toolbox of tips, tricks, and exercises that you will be able to use again whenever you need.

This workshop is perfect for writers of all levels of experience, and it may be especially useful for those of you who are taking on NaNoWriMo! Come ready with a notebook, pen, computer, whatever you prefer to write with -- and a willingness to play and explore! Bring a work-in-progress you'd like to develop, or use this workshop to discover and build an entirely new project.

Enter the online meeting room from 2pm for a 2:15ish start. The meetup will be conducted on Zoom. Any questions about Zoom, just ask!

description:

Hopefully, this workshop will inspire you to write and tell a few of your own ghost stories. - Around Christmas time.

I will bring some specific examples of characters and settings from some of James stories.

--------------------------------

2. A lady or gentleman protagonist. Many of James’ characters are naive reserved scholars, who are often not convinced something strange is happening until the final climax of the story.

3. A pivotal antiquarian object. Whether an old book or an antique, the discovery of a mystery object that unlocks and attracts an unwelcome figure from beyond the grave is a signature mark of James’ stories.

Jameson ghost storytelling was straight down the line and revolved around the idea of real ghosts, not psychological illusions or paranoid affects of the human mind. So if you prefer writing psychological type ghost or horror stories then this workshop may not be for you.

- Just to note - although Jame's stories were published in the Edwardian period, he wrote and shared them primarily during at the end of the Victorian period.

The writer M.R. James once said: “Two ingredients most valuable in the concocting of a ghost story are the atmosphere and the nicely managed crescendo.… Let us, then, be introduced to the actors in a placid way; let us see them going about their ordinary business, undisturbed by forebodings, pleased with their surroundings; and into this calm environment let the ominous thing put out its head, unobtrusively at first, and then more insistently, until it holds the stage.”

title: Get Started with a WordPress Website - An online Hub for you as a Writer
description:
Build a free WordPress.Com Website - An online hub for you as a writer:

- In this meetup, you will be taken through the process of setting up your own free WordPress website.

- This process will be using wordpress.com and will cover the setup of a simple website including a homepage, contact and blog page.

- This online workshop is suitable for those who have never used WordPress before or would consider themselves at a beginner level.

--------------------

PLEASE NOTE:

-- This workshop will take place online and the video link will be shared nearer the time of the meetup.

-- You will not need any coding skills for this workshop.

-- As this website will be provided for free from WordPress – the URL (website address) will have WordPress in the title.

E.g. It will be – www.mysite.wordpress.com instead of www.mysite.com.

---------------------

It goes without saying that in the modern-day world a huge amount of communication and information is provided from the internet and accessed through mobile devices and desktop PCs.

By staking a space for yourself online you are creating a central point for where you can share and display your work. And also where you can promote your work and potentially build a community.

This will be a short 2-hour course and by the end of it, you will have a WordPress.com website and will have the basic knowledge to be able to go on and build similar Wordpress.com sites.

------------------
Agenda:

1. Introduction:
1.1 The difference between WordPress.com and Wordpress.org
1.2 Creating a clear vision for your website.
1.3 Listing the key requirements and prioritising.

2. Sourcing design assets and images.

3. Stage 1:
3.1 Setting up the site.
3.2 Choosing a template to start with.

4. Stage 2:
4.1 Initial configuration.
4.2 Adding pages.
4.3 Adding posts.
4.4 Adding a Menu and Customisation.

5. An Agile approach: Don’t aim to be perfect! Some of the best feedback you’ll get is when the site is live.

------------------

Any questions please ask.

(The course will be held by Chris Mitchell who has worked in technology and project management roles for over 10 years and who has built numerous websites, both large and small.)

title: Creative Writing DEEP DIVE: The Secrets of Three-Act Structure
description:
This is the first in a series of DEEP DIVE creative writing workshops that will get you up close and personal with different fundamental aspects of the writing process. These workshops will help you to hone your creative wordsmithing skills as well as increase your understanding of what makes good writing and how to achieve it.

In this deep dive workshop, we will look at THREE-ACT STRUCTURE -- in other words, what a story needs in its beginning, middle, and end. We will go deep into the conventions here and also look at some examples of successful three-act structure in storytelling. We will demystify these rules of thumb as well as empower you to know when to break them, drawing from examples of writing that subverts, flaunts, or otherwise ignores the typical structure.

In addition to the information and examples provided, you can expect a number of practical prompts and exercises that will help you to become better acquainted with three-act structure so that you will be able to skillfully apply these techniques to your own projects. This highly informative and fun workshop will leave you with the understanding and the confidence to structure your own writing in a way that makes your story compelling, organic, and satisfying to an audience.

This workshop is perfect for writers of all levels of experience. Come ready with a notebook, pen, computer, whatever you prefer to write with -- and a willingness to play and explore! Bring a work-in-progress you'd like to develop, or use this workshop to discover and build an entirely new project.

title: CREATIVE WRITING with FREE snacks, a FREE book, and a drink in your hand!
description:
Hi there,

This is a MeetUp for writers and non-writers, alike.

It's a friendly writing workshop and social event.

Come in (at 6:30pm) and buy yourself a drink at the bar. Then make your way upstairs to the large meeting room (pictured) and say hello to some other friendly faces, before we start the workshop (at 7:00pm).

There will be FREE snacks - and a FREE Penguin book for each person to take home and keep.

During the session you will be guided through a number of different writing games and prompts. By the end, you'll have a whole host of new, exciting bits of writing to be proud of.

If you want to make new friends, this event is for you.

If you want to make forays into a new, serious piece of writing, this event is for you.

If you want to have a beer and surprise yourself doing something fun and spontaneous, this event is for you!

***THIS GROUP IS OPEN TO PEOPLE OF ALL LEVELS AND THERE WILL NEVER BE ANY PRESSURE TO READ YOUR WORK IN FRONT OF THE GROUP***

Any questions, please don't hesitate to text or WhatsApp on 07534 981 636.

Can't wait to see you soon.

Cheers!

Sean

title: Let us film you reading your work!
description:
If you have a poem, or a very short story, and you'd like some exposure reading your work for an online audience, please come along to this event.

We would like to film you reading your work and feature it on our Instagram and Facebook pages. A select few people will also be featured in our online journal.

Please send the organiser the poem, or the piece, that you'd like to read (recordings can be anything between 10 seconds and 3 minutes, so please make sure your reading fits into this parameter).

If you're somebody who'd like to raise a profile, this will be perfect for you - you'll always be able to link to this video. If you'd like to do this just for fun - to show your friends and family - that's also great. We'd love to have you there!

There will be a limited number of spaces, so please RSVP and confirm your interest with the organiser if you know for certain you'd like to attend. All poems and short fictions must be approved before the date of the filming.

As always, feel free to text us on 07534 981 636 if you have any questions and/or would like to be added to our WhatsApp community for updates.

Cheers!

*This event is free to attend. Since it will likely be held in a café/restaurant/bar, however, we would appreciate if you don't bring any of your own food or drink, and if instead you could please support our patrons, by purchasing any teas, coffees or snacks you'd like once you're there.

title: A Write & a Pint: The 3 Week Course!  (ALL 3 WEEKS ARE INCLUDED IN THE PRICE)
description:
Hi there,

The aim of the 3 Week Course is to produce something more substantial than we’re able to put together in a one-off session.

For you, this might be the beginning of a novel, or a short piece of fiction, a memoir, a series of flash fictions, or maybe even a saga.

Come and meet us at the amazing Courthouse Hotel in Shoreditch at 6:30pm each Thursday. The sessions will begin at 7pm (no later), so this will give you plenty of time to find us and get yourself a drink at the bar.

In the first session there will be a FREE Penguin book for each person to take home and keep. In subsequent sessions, you’ll receive handouts, with guidance and pointers to help you improve your writing. In each session, we'll also provide some free snacks. This will help you enjoy your drink (and your writing) just that little bit more!

We’ll work together on character, perspective, tone, and dialogue, and instead of using a rigid plot structure, we’ll be using methods that encourage spontaneity.

By the end of the three weeks, you ought to have a fair amount written. We'll even invite you to publish all or part of it in our online journal (though, of course, you won't have to if you don't want to!).

.....

If you want to make new friends, this event is for you.

If you want to make forays into a new, serious piece of writing, this event is for you.

If you want to have a beer or a glass of wine (during/after each session) and surprise yourself doing something fun and spontaneous, this event is for you!

***THE GROUP IS FOR EVERYBODY FROM COMPLETE BEGINNERS TO SEASONED PROFESSIONALS. THERE WILL NEVER BE ANY PRESSURE TO READ YOUR WORK IN FRONT OF THE OTHER PEOPLE THERE***

title: Surrealism and Writing: The All Day Sesh!
description:
This is a special, SURREAL edition of the All Day Sesh!

Surrealism is the most dramatic and thrilling of the modernist cultural movements of the 20s and 30s. It is best known for its dream-like visual artworks, but it’s writings are also magnificent, marked by strange juxtapositions, tangential ramblings, partial or broken meanings and oblique allusions to political or emotional states.

To work in the surrealist mode is to dream big, to unearth the most exciting and hidden elements of the unconscious, to access hitherto latent parts of what feels like a foreign part of the psyché.

For this special edition of the All Day Sesh! will be looking at parts of the surrealist manifesto by Andre Breton, some poems by Paul Eluard, some surrealist prose fiction, and examples of surrealism in contemporary writing. You will also have the opportunity to try surrealist writing for yourself!

“Surrealism is destructive” said Salvador Dali, “but it destroys only what it considers to be shackles limiting our vision.”

Come and join us and experience the mesmerising power of surrealist writing, first hand. Produce your own surrealist work. Take a leap into the unknown. Emerge changed and fascinate!

***NO EXPERIENCE NECESSARY. ALL WILL BE REVEALED***

This event includes:

1 x two-hour workshop (on SURREALISM IN LITERATURE)
1 x free book
1 x free breakfast
1 x free tea or coffee
3 x 40-minute writing sessions (with breaks in between)
1 x free early evening drink
1 x bunch of new writing buddies!

As always, this is a group for writers and non-writers, alike. No experience necessary. If you're already writing a novel - great! If you've never written anything in your life - that's also great!

When we've had our breakfast and we're sipping tea or coffee, we’ll have a 2 hour workshop on SURREALISM IN LITERATURE.

At 1:30pm, we’ll sit down and have 3 x 40-minute writing sessions, using the Pomodorro technique (this means you'll get a 15-minute break between each stint of writing, and a chance to relax and confer with others, or whatever it is you feel like doing).

*Note: there may be a tiny bit of background noise, but we’ll provide earplugs for you. Please bring your own headphones, if you’d prefer to use these.

To finish the day off, we'll go together for a FREE, early-evening drink in a bar (also very nearby).

You'll be more than welcome to have the one drink, or to sit and have another couple with the crew, for as long as people want to stay.

...

15 people, max.

title: DEATH in literature + A FREE book and some FREE snacks! @Waterstones
description:
Welcome to this morbid-but-literary edition of A Write & a Pint!

We have been invited to host the session in the basement café/bar of Waterstones, Tottenham Court Road - so we'll be surrounded by books!

This will be a 2-hour creative writing session on the subject of "Death in Literature". We'll be looking at incredible passages from famous literary works and trying to emulate styles.

As always, there will be handouts, some free snacks and a free book, for you to take home and keep!

If you're a complete beginner, this event is for you.

If you're a seasoned prose writer, this event is for you.

If you're looking to do something spontaneous and fun, make friends and try something different, this event is for you!

You will never be pressured to read your work out in front of the group.

We assure you, you'll go away buzzing with ideas and full of warmth and happiness (in spite of the deathly theme, itself!)

Feel free to invite your friends to sign up, too. The more the merrier.

*No experience necessary.

Text or WhatsApp on 07534 981 636 if you have any questions, and/or would like to be added to our WhatsApp group for updates about future events.

Join us on instagram (search: "writeandpint"), or book directly with our website: www.writeandpint.com (you can also subscribe on our website for email updates if that's easier for you).

**Please note: there is a strict no-refund policy for this event. Refunds are only agreeable if we're able to refill your space.

title: Poetry Writing for Beginners: the All Day Sesh!
description:
This is an all day event for people who want to learn to write poetry!

As always, it is a group for writers and non-writers, alike. Beginners and professionals. Whoever you are. No experience necessary.

A Saturday full of food and drink and fun, exciting writing exercises.

A FREE Breakfast, a FREE book… and plenty of time for writing.

...

Meet us at 10:45am at Finch's Pub in Old Street/Moorgate, for breakfast.

When we've had our breakfast and we're sipping tea or coffee, we’ll have a 2 hour workshop on poetry (rhythm, rhyme, stanza formation, metaphor, line-breaks, etc.).

At 1:30pm, we’ll walk together to a very nearby café where we'll sit down and have 3 x 40-minute writing sessions, using the Pomodorro technique (this means you'll get a break between each stint of writing, and a chance to relax and confer with others, or whatever it is you feel like doing). You can use these writing sessions to work on your own thing, in your own time.

At the end of the day, we'll invite you to stay for a drink with the crew, to celebrate (though this is not compulsory).

You'll be more than welcome to just have the one drink, or to sit and have another couple with the crew, for as long as people want to stay.

...

Included in this event is:

1 x two-hour workshop
1 x free book
1 x free breakfast
3 x 40-minute writing sessions (with 15-minute breaks in between)
1 x bunch of new writing buddies!

This is a full day event (11am — 6pm, approx.)

You will never have to read your work in front of the group!

***PLEASE NOTE: there is officially a no refund policy for this event. However, if you cancel a number of days in advance and we're able to refill your space, we will indeed refund you. Similarly, moving a cancelled RSVP over to a future event is contingent upon being able to refill the space that you vacate.

description:

We're usually busy hosting workshops, Q&A's, social events, and one-to-one sessions. But we're still looking to work with more people!

If you're somebody who is (or would like to be) working on a novel, a short story, or some poems, we might be able to help you.

A Write & a Pint offers one-to-one sessions in creative writing and editorial feedback:

We charge £40 for a 2-hour session (*note: this is if you would like to be guided through creative writing exercises and receive feedback, one-to-one + handouts, excerpts, advice, and a free book).

title: Breakfast + Workshop + ***MEET THE AUTHOR / Q&A***
description:
[***NOW OPEN FOR BOOKING. The event will cost £29.99 per person (we usually charge less than this, but since the event includes a £12.99 hardback book, we have needed to increase the cost on this occasion).]

......................

This is a very special event, featuring the widely celebrated debut novelist, Gareth Rubin.

Rubin's work is published by Penguin and belongs to the historical fiction genre. It is also an excellent example of the page-turning thriller.

......................

The day itself will include:

- a breakfast
- a tea or coffee
- a 2-hour workshop on story and setting
- a hardback copy of Rubin's book, Liberation Square, which he will be happy to sign and/or dedicate for you!
- a 1-hour lunch break
- a casual, friendly Q&A with the author himself
- an hour of reflective, personal writing, to consolidate what you've learned, and where you'd like to take your work from here
- the opportunity to stay behind for an early evening drink!

......................

We will meet at 10:45am, have breakfast together, followed by a 2-hour workshop on Rubin's writing, alongside some other examples of historical fiction, then a lunch break, before the author will join us for a friendly Q&A session. Once this is done, we will have an hour of quiet, reflective writing, so that you'll be able to get your ideas together and make any notes you'd like to make, on everything you've learned.

If you'd like to hear about the mechanics of a published author's approach to writing, this event is for you.

If you'd like to hear about a published author's experience of getting published, this event is for you.

If you'd like a signed, hardback copy of a bestselling, brilliantly reviewed historical fiction thriller, this event is for you.

***NO EXPERIENCE OF WRITING IS NECESSARY FOR THIS EVENT***
***BEGINNERS ARE ABSOLUTELY WELCOME***

We hope to see lots of your there!

[*There are no refunds for this event].

title: Creative Writing / Slang & Dialect + a FREE book + some FREE snacks + handouts
description:
***2-Hour Creative Writing Workshop on Slang and Dialect***

Hi there,

If you’re free next Thursday evening (11th July), whoever you are, please feel free to RSVP and join us for our 2-hour creative writing workshop + free book + some free snacks.

…………………………………………………………………………………………………………………

Slang and dialect are how we all speak from time to time… with our friends, our families, at home, in the city.

So, why don’t we write this way, too?

From Trainspotting to Finnegans Wake, some of the greatest stories are written in slang or local dialects.

From patois to pigeon English, from Cockney to Scouse to Geordie, our world is alive with the sound of local community.

If you’re struggling to find your voice as a creative writer, join us next Thursday, 11th July, from 6:45–9pm, for this special, informal edition of A Write & a Pint.

No experience is necessary.

We’ll be showing you some excellent examples of slang and dialect in existing literature. Then we’ll be using some playful writing prompts to get you writing in your own style.

For one night, forget the Queen’s grammar, forget Oxford syntax… be free to ramble away in the unique cadence of your own voice.

You will never be pressured to read your work aloud to the group, and you are not expected to have any knowledge of any particular dialect or slang.

As William Faulkner once said: “Write what you know”.

Indeed: write what you know in the only voice you’ve ever known it: your own.

If you’d like to come to this workshop, you’ll receive:

1 x free book
1 x 2-hour workshop on slang and dialect in creative writing
1 x free snacks
1 x handout

+ the invitation to stick around for an evening drink afterwards, to celebrate everything you’ve achieved.

As always please text or WhatsApp us on 07534 981 636 if you have any questions about this event (or any other), or if you would like to be added to our WhatsApp community for updates.

Don’t be shy—we’d love to hear from you!

Cheers.

Sean :)

title: One-to-one writing consultation (*let's arrange a time!)
description:
[RSVP here to show an interest! See our contact details at the bottom to arrange a meet]

We're usually busy hosting workshops, Q&A's, social events, and one-to-one sessions. But we're still looking to work with more people!

If you're somebody who is (or would like to be) working on a novel, a short story, or some poems, we might be able to help you.

A Write & a Pint offers one-to-one sessions in creative writing and editorial feedback:

We charge £40 for a 2-hour session (*note: this is if you would like to be guided through creative writing exercises and receive feedback, one-to-one + handouts, excerpts, advice, and a free book).

We charge £80 for a detailed analysis of up to 8,000 words + a 2-hour session to talk it all over (*note: this is if you're already writing something and would like advice and coaching as to where you can make improvements and take new directions in your work).

If you'd like to include a friend and bring them along with you for a 3-person session, we can reduce the price! Just let us know.

As always, please feel free to join us by subscribing at: www.writeandpint.com to learn about new workshops, courses, retreats, social events, and discounts.

To set a fee and arrange a meeting, text or WhatsApp on 07534 981 636.

We hope to hear from you soon!

Cheers :)

title: Dating & Creative Writing (+ a Q&A with Luke Tredget + a Signed Copy)
description:
Hi there,

This is a creative writing event for writers and non-writers, alike. It is for anybody interested in developing their style, of any level - beginners are absolutely, 100% more than welcome.

Included in the event is:

1 x free breakfast
1 x 2-hour creative writing workshop on dating and creative writing (don't worry if you're not dating *right now* - you can draw on previous experience)
1 x ***free, signed copy of Luke Tredget's novel Kismet***
1 x lunch break
1 x friendly Q&A session with Luke (about his novel, about style, about getting published, about dating apps, about... anything else we can think of to ask him on the day)
1 x 40 minute private writing session, to put into practice everything you've learned
+ the opportunity to stick around for an evening drink to celebrate!

As always, there is ***NEVER ANY PRESSURE TO READ YOUR WORK ALOUD IN FRONT OF THE GROUP... EVER***.

Attendees will arrive at 10:45am, to begin at 11am. Here, we will take your breakfast + tea or coffee order. Then after breakfast, we will guide you through a series of playful creative writing exercises, so that you can begin to formulate your own ideas, in your own unique style.

After breakfast and our 2-hour writing workshop, we will have a lunch break. After this, author Luke Tredget will arrive and we will reconvene for a friendly Q&A with him (*Note: don't worry. You won't be expected to ask questions or have anything to say. If nobody has any questions, you can just listen to Luke and your workshop host, Sean, in conversation about Luke's novel, Kismet, and about everything to do with publication, from writing approaches and style to finding an agent, sending off a manuscript and seeing your name in print).

Luke has agreed that he will sign a free copy of his book for you, to take away and keep!

If you have any questions about this event (or any other), please don't hesitate to text or WhatsApp us on 07534 981 636 - we'd love to hear from you.

We hope to see you there for this incredible opportunity.

Until then...

Cheers! :)

...........................................

Praise for Luke's novel:

"Sharp, witty and full of tension...an intelligent and highly readable novel."―Irish Times

"Tredget's trenchant, entertaining debut traces how big data and social media have become an obstacle for healthy relationships...An incisive view of the uncertainties of contemporary adulthood."―Publishers Weekly

"Kismet is compelling for more than its unflinching study of the infiltration of romance by technology and algorithms. At its heart this novel is about what endures in spite of all that; a modern love story of exceptional warmth, intelligence and humanity."―Luke Kennard, author of The Transition

"Tredget writes a funny, timely story, with flawed and relatable characters, about how technology affects our desires and what it means to 'settle.' Though he satirizes modern dating and the idea of perfection in a relationship, he writes with an engaging warmth and lightness. Readers will surely enjoy this witty modern love story."―Booklist

title: FREE Social Event for Writers and Readers of London!
description:
If you're a writer, a reader, a beginner or professional... please RSVP now and come along to A Write & a Pint's ***FREE Social Event***.

No workshop.

No experience necessary.

No big introductions.

Just you, us, people... drinking, chatting, sharing ideas and getting to know one another.

If you've been to one of our social events before you'll know how fun they can be, and how useful and inspirational it can be to meet other people who are also interested in reading or writing.

We regularly have attendees who are working in fields as diverse as journalism, fashion, marketing... people who are novelists, playwrights, screenwriters, poets... but also (and perhaps mainly) people who are only just starting out, attempting to write their first short story, or something similar.

Whoever you are, we promise you there will be no pressure and you'll be more than welcome. We can't wait to meet you.

If you have any questions at all, please don't hesitate to text or WhatsApp us on 07534 981 636. We're happy to help!

Hope to see you there!

Cheers :)

title: Creative Writing & Eating & Drinking + a FREE book!
description:
Hi there,

This is a MeetUp for writers and non-writers, alike.

It is a friendly writing workshop and social event.

Come in at 6:45pm; buy yourself a drink at the bar, then come and find us in the Talbot Room, and say hello to some other friendly faces, before we start the workshop at 7:00pm.

There will be FREE snacks - and a FREE Penguin book for each person to take home and keep.

The theme of this workshop will be RANDOMNESS and SPONTANEITY (if you've come to one of these workshops before, don't worry, they'll be new exercises, and if you haven't come before, don't worry, it is all suitable for absolute beginners)!

During the session you will be guided through a number of different writing games and prompts. By the end, you'll have a whole host of new, exciting bits of writing to be proud of.

If you want to make new friends, this event is for you.

If you want to make forays into a new, serious piece of writing, this event is for you.

If you want to have a beer and surprise yourself doing something fun and spontaneous, this event is for you!

***THIS GROUP IS OPEN TO PEOPLE OF ALL LEVELS AND THERE WILL NEVER BE ANY PRESSURE TO READ YOUR WORK IN FRONT OF THE GROUP***

Any questions, please don't hesitate to text or WhatsApp on 07534 981 636.

Can't wait to see you soon.

Cheers!

Sean

***PLEASE NOTE: there is officially a no refund policy for this event. However, if you cancel a number of days in advance and we're able to refill your space, we will indeed refund you. Similarly, moving a cancelled RSVP over to a future event is contingent upon being able to refill the space that you vacate.

title: Life Writing: from Autobiography to Fiction (+ a FREE book & some FREE snacks!)
description:
Hi there,

This is a MeetUp for writers and non-writers, alike.

It's a friendly writing workshop and social event.

Come in at 6:45pm; buy yourself a drink at the bar, have a seat. Then say hello to some other friendly faces, before we start the workshop at 7:00pm.

There will be FREE snacks - and a FREE Penguin book for each person to take home and keep.

During the session you will be guided through a number of different writing games and prompts, but we'll be focusing specifically on Life Writing: from Autobiography to Fiction. This is ideal for anyone struggling to produce ideas for fictional stories, but also incredibly useful for adding detail and depth to any existing fictional characters you might be creating. It is also perfectly suitable for people who haven't yet started writing anything at all! There will be handouts, as well to keep you inspired. By the end, you'll have a whole host of new, exciting bits of writing to be proud of.

If you want to make new friends, this event is for you.

If you want to make forays into a new, serious piece of writing, this event is for you.

If you want to have a beer and surprise yourself doing something fun and spontaneous, this event is for you!

title: Day of Poetry + Breakfast, tea/coffee, a free book & LOADS of writing!
description:
This is an all day event for people who want to learn to write poetry!

As always, it is a group for writers and non-writers, alike. Beginners and professionals. Whoever you are. No experience necessary.

A Saturday full of food and drink and fun, exciting writing exercises.

A Breakfast, a tea or coffee, a free book… and plenty of time for writing.

...

Meet us at 10:45am at Finch's Pub in Old Street/Moorgate, for breakfast.

When we've had our breakfast and we're sipping tea or coffee, we’ll have a 2 hour workshop on poetry (rhythm, rhyme, stanza formation, metaphor, line-breaks, etc.).

At 1:30pm, we’ll walk together to a very nearby café where we'll sit down and have 3 x 40-minute writing sessions, using the Pomodorro technique (this means you'll get a break between each stint of writing, and a chance to relax and confer with others, or whatever it is you feel like doing). You can use these writing sessions to work on your own thing, in your own time.

At the end of the day, we'll invite you to stay for a drink with the crew, to celebrate (though this is not compulsory).

You'll be more than welcome to just have the one drink, or to sit and have another couple with the crew, for as long as people want to stay.

...

Included in this event is:

1 x two-hour workshop
1 x free book
1 x free breakfast
3 x 40-minute writing sessions (with 15-minute breaks in between)
1 x bunch of new writing buddies!

This is a full day event (11am — 6pm, approx.)

You will never have to read your work in front of the group!

***PLEASE NOTE: there is officially a no refund policy for this event. However, if you cancel a number of days in advance and we're able to refill your space, we will indeed refund you. Similarly, moving a cancelled RSVP over to a future event is contingent upon being able to refill the space that you vacate.

title: Novel Beginnings - How to Start Your Story + food, drink, and a FREE book!
description:
# Novel Beginnings - How to Start Your Story + food, drink, and a FREE book!

[BOOK YOUR SPOT AT www.writeandpint.com/workshops]
...

***"It’s such a confidence trick, writing a novel. The main person you have to trick into confidence is yourself. This is hard to do alone". – Zadie Smith***

...
Let's get together and learn how to write the perfect beginning.

Whether you've already written your novel/short story or you're starting something afresh, this is the perfect workshop to hone your style, tone, tempo, and general approach.

We'll be looking at everybody from Zadie Smith to John Cheever, Francois Sagan to Katherine Mansfield, Chimamanda Ngoze Adichie to Jorge Luis Borges.

We'll be looking at what agents and publishers might want from the opening chapter.

We'll be setting you up with some fun, exciting writing exercises, to make sure you get the chance to finesse your approach and leave with something new and brilliant, ready to take home and edit.

First of all though, we'll be ordering teas, coffees and brunch, before we settle in for a warm-up exercise, to get our imaginations flowing.

No experience of writing is necessary for this workshop.

No pressure to read or share your work with the group.

Just sit back, listen, learn, read, write, eat, drink, and come away full of new knowledge and expertise in the art of writing.

***"The scariest moment is always just before you start". – Stephen King***

So please feel free to text us on 07534 981 636 if you have any questions at all - we'll be more happy to help :)

title: <<ONLY £12 PER SESSION>> POD 1 .  5-Week BEGINNERS' Course + PUBLICATION
description:
The full price for this course is £60. That's equivalent to £12 for each two-hour session (+ at the end of the 5 weeks, you will have the opportunity to publish your work and receive ongoing feedback on The New Machine's website, for FREE).

...

Pod No. 1 (beginners) 5-week short story course

[There will only be 6 places in a Pod. Regular creative writing classes consist of between 10 – 15 people. A 6-person pod ensures you will each receive closer attention to the details of your work. You will never have to read your work in front of the group – it will merely be discussed by the group in a friendly, constructive manner (a manner consistent with a blueprint for critique that I will set out in week 3). Each session will last for approx. 2 hours + there will be a very short piece of homework, designed to ensure that you’re progressing nicely throughout the course. By the end of the 5th week you will have produced a final edit of a short story you’ve been working on and have the opportunity to publish it on the New Machine’s website]

Week 1 - Point of view

We will be looking here at the relationship between the reader and the narrator. You will learn what it means to write in the 1st, 2nd and 3rd person (+ variations). I will introduce you to some the textual nuances that authors deploy within these narrative modes. You’ll then have an opportunity to explore this yourself, in writing.

In this session we will be looking at excerpts from: Brett Easton Ellis, Chimamanda Ngoze Adichie, Elizabeth Gaskell and JM Coetzee.

Week 2 - Style/tone and dialogue

In the second week, we will examine three different narrative styles. You will have an opportunity to emulate these in a writing exercise. We will then discuss dialogue and explore this using a free writing technique. In this session we will be looking at excerpts from: Charles Dickens, Katherine Mansfield and Albert Camus.

Week 3 – Character development and plot

This session will help you generate ideas for characters and plot. You will be begin to see your own short story emerging.

The homework will be to write a 2000-word short story based on everything you’ve learned so far.

Week 4 - How to critique

We will look at a short story here together and learn how to critique it in terms of its themes, its character development(s), its style/type of narration, its plot and structure, its dialogue, etc. You will learn to distinguish what you think is effective and what needs work in other peoples’ writing (this will in turn inform your own writing and allow you to proceed with more clarity).

Week 5 - Feedback

Here you will receive a compassionate critique of your work, and will partake in a discussion of other peoples’ work (+ you will have an opportunity to take your story away with you, produce a final edit, and publish it on The New Machine’s website).

venue.address: 131 Lower Marsh, Lambeth, London SE1 7AE, London

We will look at a short story here together and learn how to critique it in terms of its themes, its character development(s), its style/type of narration, its plot and structure, its dialogue, etc. You will learn to distinguish what you think is effective and what needs work in other peoples’ writing (this will in turn inform your own writing and allow you to proceed with more clarity).

Week 5 - Feedback

Here you will receive a compassionate critique of your work, and will partake in a discussion of other peoples’ work (+ you will have an opportunity to take your story away with you, produce a final edit, and publish it on The New Machine’s website).

title: POD-101: THE ADVANCED COURSE
description:
The full price for this course is £60. That's equivalent to £12 for each two-hour session (+ you will have multiple opportunities to receive feedback on your work. At the end of the 5 weeks, you will also have the opportunity to PUBLISH PART OF YOUR WORK and receive ongoing feedback on The New Machine's website, for FREE).

POD-101: “THE ADVANCED COURSE”

The aim of this course is for you to plan and write a novel.

Week 1. (Planning your novel)

In the first week, you’ll be generating an idea for your novel. You will then flesh-out/develop this idea using a narrative arc. This arc will ensure that you’re able to produce a compelling and dynamic story for whomever your readership is intended to be. You can take the arc home, develop and/or discard it, depending on your personal preference. Either way, the arc is an essential aspect of good storytelling, and the strategy you receive here will benefit your writing immensely.

Week 2. (Narrative Perspective + Chapters 1 & 2)

In the second week, you’ll be invited to plan your first two chapters, in greater depth. You will also partake in a creative writing exercise that will help you decide which narrative perspective (and which tense) to write your novel in.

Week 3. (Dialogue + Chapters 3, 4 & 5)

In the third week, you’ll be invited to plan and/or write your next three chapters. You will also partake in a creative writing exercise that will ensure you’re using dialogue effectively in your work.

Week 4. (Feedback + Chapters 6, 7 & 8)

In the fourth week, you will receive feedback for up to 3000 words of the writing you have done so far. You will also be invited to plan and/or write your next three chapters.

Week 5. (Feedback + Chapters 9 & 10 + Re-visiting the arc)

In the final week, you will plan and/or write your 9th & 10th chapter. You will also re-visit the narrative arc you made for your work at the beginning of the course. This will enable you to consolidate a final first draft or plan for your entire novel.

***Note: your novel may not be precisely 10 chapters. This is, of course, entirely up to you. POD-101/THE ADVANCED COURSE is here to provide you a 5-week structure within which to complete as much of your novel as possible. If you’re extremely motivated, you may finish an entire first draft. Most people, however, will produce an entire plan/outline + only *some* of their first draft. Either way, POD-101 will be running on a rolling basis. So you will have the opportunity to RSVP again for the next 5-weeks, and continue working on your novel. To avoid the workshop becoming stale and un-productive, participants should not sign up for more than two consecutive POD-101’s.

If you would like to do this course, but you have some questions, please contact the organiser first, by texting 07534 981 636.
