description:
Hi guys,

This is an event for those of you who are currently on a course with The New Machine (Creative Writing). It is not compulsory. It's just an opportunity for you to meet up with the rest of the group and make sure you get some writing done.

I won't be teaching anything here; there won't be any exercises. Just a block of 3 hours for us to sit together in a quiet café and get some work done towards our short stories and novels.

I hope to see lots of you there!

All the best,

Sean

title: POD-1: WRITE + PUBLISH YOUR FICTION IN 5 WEEKS!!!  <<£10 DISCOUNT>>
description:
£10 DISCOUNT!!!

The full price for this course is usually £60. That's equivalent to £12 (but only £10, this time) for each two-hour session (+ you will have multiple opportunities to receive feedback on your work and, at the end of the 5 weeks, you will also have the opportunity to PUBLISH YOUR WORK and receive ongoing feedback on The New Machine's website, for FREE).

If you would like to do this course online, it's ONLY £40!!! But please contact the organiser first, by texting 07534 981 636.

**********

THIS COURSE WILL HAVE A BREAK OVER XMAS. SO THE DATES OF THE SESSIONS WILL BE: 7th Dec, 14th Dec, 21st Dec---BREAK---4th Jan, 11th Jan.

**********

...

Pod No. 1 (beginners/intermediate) 5-week short story course

[There will only be 6 places in a Pod. Regular creative writing classes consist of between 10 – 15 people. A 6-person pod ensures you will each receive closer attention to the details of your work. Each session will last for approx. 2 hours + there will be a very short piece of homework, designed to ensure that you’re progressing nicely throughout the course. By the end of the 5th week you will have produced a final edit of a short story you’ve been working on and have the opportunity to publish it on the New Machine’s website]

Week 1 - Point of view

We will be looking here at the relationship between the reader and the narrator. You will learn what it means to write in the 1st, 2nd and 3rd person (+ variations). I will introduce you to some the textual nuances that authors deploy within these narrative modes. You’ll then have an opportunity to explore this yourself, in writing.

In this session we will be looking at excerpts from: Brett Easton Ellis, Chimamanda Ngoze Adichie, Elizabeth Gaskell and JM Coetzee.

Week 2 - Style/tone and dialogue

In the second week, we will examine three different narrative styles. You will have an opportunity to emulate these in a writing exercise. We will then discuss dialogue and explore this using a free writing technique. In this session we will be looking at excerpts from: Charles Dickens, Katherine Mansfield and Albert Camus.

Week 3 – Character development and plot

This session will help you generate ideas for characters and plot. You will be begin to see your own short story emerging.

The homework will be to write a 2000-word short story based on everything you’ve learned so far.

Week 4 - How to critique

We will look at a short story here together and learn how to critique it in terms of its themes, its character development(s), its style/type of narration, its plot and structure, its dialogue, etc. You will learn to distinguish what you think is effective and what needs work in other peoples’ writing (this will in turn inform your own writing and allow you to proceed with more clarity).

Week 5 - Feedback

Here you will receive a compassionate critique of your work, and will partake in a discussion of other peoples’ work (+ you will have an opportunity to take your story away with you, produce a final edit, and publish it on The New Machine’s website).

venue.address: 131 Lower Marsh, Lambeth, London SE1 7AE, London

title: POD-101: WRITE A NOVEL IN 5-WEEKS!
description:
The full price for this course is £60. That's equivalent to £12 for each two-hour session (+ you will have multiple opportunities to receive feedback on your work. At the end of the 5 weeks, you will also have the opportunity to PUBLISH PART OF YOUR WORK and receive ongoing feedback on The New Machine's website, for FREE).

POD-101: “THE ADVANCED COURSE”

The aim of this course is for you to plan and write a novel.

Week 1. (Planning your novel)

In the first week, you’ll be generating an idea for your novel. You will then flesh-out/develop this idea using a narrative arc. This arc will ensure that you’re able to produce a compelling and dynamic story for whomever your readership is intended to be. You can take the arc home, develop and/or discard it, depending on your personal preference. Either way, the arc is an essential aspect of good storytelling, and the strategy you receive here will benefit your writing immensely.

Week 2. (Narrative Perspective + Chapters 1 & 2)

In the second week, you’ll be invited to plan your first two chapters, in greater depth. You will also partake in a creative writing exercise that will help you decide which narrative perspective (and which tense) to write your novel in.

Week 3. (Dialogue + Chapters 3, 4 & 5)

In the third week, you’ll be invited to plan and/or write your next three chapters. You will also partake in a creative writing exercise that will ensure you’re using dialogue effectively in your work.

Week 4. (Feedback + Chapters 6, 7 & 8)

In the fourth week, you will receive feedback for up to 3000 words of the writing you have done so far. You will also be invited to plan and/or write your next three chapters.

Week 5. (Feedback + Chapters 9 & 10 + Re-visiting the arc)

In the final week, you will plan and/or write your 9th & 10th chapter. You will also re-visit the narrative arc you made for your work at the beginning of the course. This will enable you to consolidate a final first draft or plan for your entire novel.

***Note: your novel may not be precisely 10 chapters. This is, of course, entirely up to you. POD-101/THE ADVANCED COURSE is here to provide you a 5-week structure within which to complete as much of your novel as possible. If you’re extremely motivated, you may finish an entire first draft. Most people, however, will produce an entire plan/outline + only *some* of their first draft. Either way, POD-101 will be running on a rolling basis. So you will have the opportunity to RSVP again for the next 5-weeks, and continue working on your novel. To avoid the workshop becoming stale and un-productive, participants should not sign up for more than two consecutive POD-101’s.

If you would like to do this course, but you have some questions, please contact the organiser first, by texting 07534 981 636.

title: Day of Writing (Exclusively for People on a Course with TNM)
description:
Hi guys,

This is an event for those of you who are currently on a course with The New Machine (Creative Writing). It is not compulsory. It's just an opportunity for you to meet up with the rest of the group and make sure you get some writing done.

I won't be teaching anything here; there won't be any exercises. Just a block of 3 hours for us to sit together in a quiet café and get some work done towards our short stories and novels.

If you do decide to come, please come prepared to write. I will be giving us a timed 45 minute window, followed by a 15 minute break, to ensure progress. You can chat to each other during the breaks, but it would be great to stick to writing for the time allotted to it, so that we don't distract each other.

I hope to see lots of you there!

All the best,

Sean

P.S. as there will be other people around, you may wish to bring earphones, to cut out the background noise.

title: DAY OF POETRY (beginners and intermediate level) ***SPECIAL PRICE - £15***
description:
[The Day of Poetry is normally £20. This time it is £15 for the 4 hour session, so that's only £3.75 per hour!!!]

********************************************************************************************

Hi there,

If you're a poet (or if you'd like to be!) please RSVP and come along to The New Machine's "DAY OF POETRY".

If you're a complete beginner, no problem. Throughout the 4-hour session, we'll be learning the poetry basics, from scratch. Things like:

• Line breaks

• Stanza formation

• Rhythm

• Free verse

We will be looking at poetry by Samuel Beckett, Sharon Olds, Margaret Atwood, Frank O'Hara, Langston Hughes, Matsuo Basho, and William Shakespeare.

By the end of the day, you'll have a small handful of your own poems, either complete or to take home and work on.

If you're an intermediate level poet, this workshop will also be enormously beneficial to you. We'll be generating ideas together and you'll have the fixed structure of the day to compel your progress!

Any questions, don't hesitate to ask (either reply here or text Sean on: 07534 981 636).

Hope to see you soon! :)

title: Novel Beginnings - How to Start Your Story + food, drink, and a FREE book!
description:
[BOOK YOUR SPOT AT www.writeandpint.com/workshops]

...

***"It’s such a confidence trick, writing a novel. The main person you have to trick into confidence is yourself. This is hard to do alone". – Zadie Smith***

...

Let's get together and learn how to write the perfect beginning.

Whether you've already written your novel/short story or you're starting something afresh, this is the perfect workshop to hone your style, tone, tempo, and general approach.

We'll be looking at everybody from Zadie Smith to John Cheever, Francois Sagan to Katherine Mansfield, Chimamanda Ngoze Adichie to Jorge Luis Borges.

We'll be looking at what agents and publishers might want from the opening chapter.

We'll be setting you up with some fun, exciting writing exercises, to make sure you get the chance to finesse your approach and leave with something new and brilliant, ready to take home and edit.

First of all though, we'll be ordering teas, coffees and brunch, before we settle in for a warm-up exercise, to get our imaginations flowing.

No experience of writing is necessary for this workshop.

No pressure to read or share your work with the group.

Just sit back, listen, learn, read, write, eat, drink, and come away full of new knowledge and expertise in the art of writing.

***"The scariest moment is always just before you start". – Stephen King***

So please feel free to text us on 07534 981 636 if you have any questions at all - we'll be more happy to help :)

title: London Writers Cafe June Meetup
description:
This will be the very first Meetup for London Writers Cafe! We've chosen All Bar One on Dean Street as its central and we can discuss future places to meet on our first night!

This is our first opportunity to get to know each other, talk about writing, discuss writers resources and get some inspiration from each other. Look forward to seeing you all!!

title: London Writers Cafe Hyde Park Meetup
description:
Everyone!

Ok, the next meetup will be in Hyde Park! Hopefully the weather will be good, if not, I'm going to arrange an alternative location for us.

Right, I thought it would be a good idea to meet at the Bandstand near the Dell at the Hyde Park entrance. There are some good facilities round here and plenty of space for us! (A map is attached).

If you would like some feedback from the other members, bring some work with you and perhaps we could do read throughs for each other.

Hope you can all make it and I look forward to seeing you all.

PS. REMEMBER TO BRING SOMETHING TO DRINK AND FOOD IF YOU FANCY!

Bohemia

For more information, see https://www.royalparks.gov.uk/docs/park_maps/hyde_park.pdf

title: London Writers Cafe Meetup
description:
CHANGE OF DAY TO WEDNESDAY 6TH SEPTEMBER!!

Hello Everyone!!

Our next London Writers Cafe Meetup will be at 6.30pm onwards on Wednesday September 6th 2006 at The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch.

We have our own room upstairs which will be excellent for our group! We can have readings, discussions and a good chat without being disturbed. Also the bar has a good range of beers and food is available too.

Please feel free to bring your 'Writing' with you!

Its quite central and very easy to get to. Please see below for directions etc.

Do contact me via email if you have any questions or get me on my Mobile: 07941 471563.

I look forward to seeing you all there!

Bohemia.

title: London Writers Cafe Meetup!
description:
Hello Everyone!!

Our next London Writers Cafe Meetup will start around 6:30pm to 7pm on Tuesday October 10th 2006.

The venue is The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch, which will now be our regular location for these meetups as we have a room upstairs just for us!

For this meetup we are asking people to write up to A MAXIMUM OF 500 words on the subject of 'Sex' (Good starting point eh)! Remember, not too long as we will end up reading them into the wee small hours!!

Rules:

This can be drama, poetry, comedy, fiction, non-fiction, anything you like, even a song!
DONT put your name on it, USE A PSEUDONYM (spare those blushes).
All of the group will be reading each others work (sigh of relief)
May even be a prize for the best piece????

Please feel free to bring any other writing which you would like to share with the group too!

Also we have a Guest Speaker at this event! Emma Stroud the Artistic Director of Abandon Theatre will be joining us for a chat, giving us an insight into her work, particulary her interest in new writing.

I look forward to seeing you all there!

Bohemia.

title: London Writers Cafe Meetup for 6th Feb is back on!
description:
Everyone!

I'm pleased to announce we are still going to have a meetup on Tuesday 6th February 2007. All thanks to Hugh, who found a venue for us and checked it out. Big Thanks Hugh!!

Details as follows:

The venue is The Pitcher and Piano at Holborn and we have the back room on the main floor. We start at 6:30pm!

For this meetup I'm inviting you (if you want to) to bring a piece of work to the group. Something under 500 WORDS or an extract from something larger would be great.

It can be poetry, short story, factual, a song, anything you like, just make sure you keep to the word limit so we have plenty of time for feedback and dicussion.

The subject will be 'LOVE' aaahhhhh, ain't that nice? Don't worry about reading or performing your own work, quite often we read each others.

So come and join us for drinks, discuss your work and meet other writers. You will be warmly welcomed.

I look forward to seeing you all there!

Bohemia.

Directions:

From the Holborn underground station, turn south on Kingsway (left out of the underground station main exit) and go approx. 200 meters. Pitcher and Piano is on the left at 42 Kingsway.

title: EVENT - Guest Speaker Simon Trewin - Literary Agent
description:
Everyone,

THIS EVENT IS NOW FULL. ANY PLACES WHICH BECOME AVAILABLE, I WILL CONTACT THOSE ON THE WAITING LIST!!

Many thanks.

Bo

'm pleased and very excited to announce this new Guest Speaker event which will take place on Tuesday 20th February at 7pm. I would like to introduce Simon Trewin from PFD, one of the leading literary and talent agents in Europe.

The event will take place in the conference room at NESTA (my place of work) and will start with Simon discussing the role of an Agent and about his work. This will follow with a Q&A session for you. It should wrap up at about 9pm.

Please note, this event has a maximum of 40 places only, so please make sure you RSVP. If you change your mind at any time, please amend your RSVP to free up a place for someone else.

The event will start at 7:30pm prompt, so please aim to get to the venue at 7pm.

Some info about Simon Trewin......

EVERYTHING YOU EVER WANTED TO ASK ABOUT GETTING AN AGENT AND GETTING PUBLISHED......BUT NEVER DARED ASK

Literary Agent Simon Trewin from Europe's leading literary and talent agency Peters, Fraser and Dunlop talks candidly about the Do's and Don'ts of taking the first step from prose to publication. Leave your pre-conceptions outside and come prepared for a lively interactive sessions with plenty of opportunities for questions - from the basic to the pretentious.

Simon Trewin clients include Jeremy Dyson, Mike Gayle, Danny Wallace, Scarlett Thomas, Andrew Miller and Steven Hall.

Details of how to get to NESTA are below:

NESTA
1 Plough Place
London
EC4A 1DE

Switchboard:
020 7438 2500

Plough Place is located between Fetter Lane and New Fetter Lane

Nearest tubes:
Chancery Lane (Exit 3) - 4mins
Farringdon - 8mins
Aldwych - 12 mins
Holborn - 13mins

Buses:
8, 17, 25, 45, 46, 242, 341 or 521 to Holborn Circus

MAP and DIRECTIONS: https://www.nesta.org.... (https://www.nesta.org.uk/about/contact_us/location_map.aspx)

title: London Writers Cafe Meetup 13th March 2007
description:
Hello Everyone

Our next London Writers Cafe Meetup will start around 6:30pm on Tuesday 13th March 2007.

The venue is The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch and we have a room upstairs just for us!

For this meetup I'm inviting you (if you want to) to do a piece of work with the title - 'Beware The Ides of March - or Mad as a March Hare' as March is a time of Madness supposedly!! Sascha's Idea - I think it's a good one!

But you have to include these words in your work:

March, pots, scum, tea, eyes, lava, dragon, stick, paper, pepper, baby, water, tongue, wrong, slick, darkness and painter.

REMEMBER THE WORD LIMIT IS 500.

Don't worry about reading or performing your own work, quite often we read each others.

It can be poetry, short story, factual, a song, anything you like but remember, not too long as we will end up reading them into the wee small hours!!

I look forward to seeing you all there!

title: London Writers Cafe - Prose Unplugged!
description:
Hello Everyone

Our next London Writers Cafe Meetup will start around 6:30pm on Thursday 26th April 2007.

The venue is The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch and we have a room upstairs just for us!

PROSE UNPLUGGED!

Right you lot, we are going to have a bit of a 'stand up to the mic' session this week.

What I'd like you to do, (if you want to) is to prepare a piece on the topic of 'COMPLAINING'.

We had the pleasure of hearing James and his piece about London Underground which was hilarious, so I thought I want some more of that! Now its your turn!

It can be anything you like, poetry, short story, a song! Try and stick to UNDER 500 words. This is your opportunity to let us hear your stuff!

If you don't fancy performing your own work, there are plenty of us who are willing to get up there read for you. Such a bunch of performers!

Afterwards there will be the necessary socialising......of course!

I look forward to seeing you all there! Any questions, just email me!

Bohemia.

title: London Writers Cafe Meetup - Guest Speaker & Social Event
description:
Hello Everyone

Come and meet Nick Wastnage our Guest Speaker for this Event on Tuesday May 8th 2007 starting at 7pm

Nick is the author of several books, his first being the Electronic Conspirator about a man who fakes his own death, scams millions from the Internet and re-invents himself in a another part of the world!

The evening will begin with Nick talking about his work and how he got published. I'm sure you will all have many questions for him too!

title: London Writers Cafe - October Meetup!
description:
Hello Everyone

The next meetup will be on Thursday 25th October 2007 at 7pm. Guy will be hosting this meetup and he aims to put the "ass" back into Assistant Organiser!

This week's topic is Money Money Money! Who's got it? Who wants it? Who gives and Who gets? Root of all evil or source of all happiness?

Stuck for ideas? Why not take some inspiration from these pioneering poets:

There's nothing wrong with letting the girls know that you're money and that you want to party. - Vince Vaughan

If you wana look good and not be bummy, girl you better give me that money - Ol' Dirty Bastard

Money, it's a hit, don't give me that do goody good bullshit - Pink Floyd

The venue is The Carpenters Arms pub near Marble Arch and we have a room upstairs just for us!

This can be in a poem, short story or perhaps a song! Anything you like. Remember, you don't have to bring any work with you at all, just come along and hang out with us and listen to what others have written!

IMPORTANT - PLEASE KEEP THE WORD COUNT TO A MAXIMUM OF 500 WORDS!!

Everyone will have about 5- 7 mins reading their work which will give us all time to give you feedback if you want it.

Don't worry about reading or performing your own work, someone else is always willing to perform for you!

Our evenings are always followed by much socialising and many trips to the bar, so please come and join us.

I look forward to seeing you all there!

Guy

description:
Hello Everyone

I have decided to step down as Organiser of the London Writers Cafe as I want to concentrate on my Theatre work and writing. So this will be my last meetup!

However, your new organiser will be Guy, who will be taking over from December and will whip you all into shape. He will be just brilliant!

So, lets have a good old pre-christmas do on Thursday 29th November at the Carpenters Arms at 7pm. We have a room upstairs just for us!

The subject for you all is 'What I hate about Christmas' (How festive).....I want to hear about your christmas nightmares, throwing mince pies at your granny and the time you showed your knickers at the office party! You've all done it......

This can be in a poem, short story or perhaps a song! Anything you like. Remember, you don't have to bring any work with you at all, just come along and hang out with us and listen to what others have written!

IMPORTANT - PLEASE KEEP THE WORD COUNT TO A MAXIMUM OF 500 WORDS!!

title: Writer's Café Winter Bonanza!
description:
Our first meet-up for the year!

Brave the winter chill, and help to usher in the glorious new LWC regime at our time-honoured venue, The Carpenter's Arms. For those unfamiliar with the pub, it's at 12 Seymour Place, right around the corner from Marble Arch tube station.

For a map, click here (https://www.allinlondon.co.uk/mapping/map.php?pc=W1H+7NE)

We'll be rolling in from 7pm, but things probably won't get going till 7.30 or 8, depending on turn-out. Still, get in early for nibbles and contraband shop-bought red wine! The Writer's Group is upstairs, so just navigate your way through the hoardes of rowdy public servants propping up the bar, up the trecherous staircase, through the dank, unlit corridors to our glorious creative sanctuary!

The topic for our inaugural 2008 meet-up is "Secrets". So think of a short story, poem, performance piece or anything else that fits the topic. Note, for first-timers, the topic is applied very loosely!

It could be about secret pasts, secret lovers, or a yearning paean to the discontinuation of the Cadbury Secret bar. There's no word limit, so just bring whatever you're comfortable with sharing.

We normally read out our own work, but if you'd rather remain anonymous, get in touch with me directly through Meetup.com and I'll arrange to have one of our many fine public-speakers read it out for you.

Any questions, please email me: guy *underscore* kerr *at* hotmail.com (email removed due to swarms of Burkina Faso bankers offering millions)

Cheers and hope to see you all there!

Guy

title: London Writers Cafe Tuesday Shindig!
description:
Hi guys, apologies over the delay in scheduling our next meet up. We've had some dramas with our favourite pub, The Carpenters Arms, which is no longer our little secret and has been booked out by all kinds of wacky groups (London Chess Society, anyone?).

So....we've moved our meet up night to Tuesday, 29th April. Hopefully the proximity to the start of the working week won't dissuade our staunch squadron of writers from attending! And it's still at our favourite little not-so-underground-anymore pub, The Carpenters Arms. 12 Seymour Place, a stone's throw from Marble Arch tube and Oxford Street Primark. Click here for a map (https://www.allinlondon.co.uk/mapping/map.php?pc=W1H+7NE)

The theme this time around is Climbing. Could be Social Climbing, Mountain Climbing, Climbing Plants, or just the eternal struggle to climb from one's bed each morning! Please note, the topic is applied very loosely and is just a guide! Your writing can come in many forms, poem, short story, puppet show, up to you! Please try to keep it to under 10 minutes in length, unless you're really good :)

The official start time is 8, but I'll be there just after 7 preparing everything. The Writer's Group is upstairs, so just navigate your way through the hoardes of rowdy public servants propping up the bar, up the trecherous staircase, through the dank, unlit corridors to our glorious creative sanctuary!

Once again, any questions, please email me: guy *underscore* kerr *at* hotmail.com. And apologies for the delay once again, hopefully you're all chomping at the bit to step up and share your work with the world!

Cheers and hope to see you all there!

Guy

title: First meetup of 2009
description:
The new meetings will have a slightly different format to the old ones.

First, there will be time-slots that people can use either to get feedback on a short piece of writing, or to describe a challenge they are facing (plot difficulties, etc) and get suggestions on that. From the poll (https://www.meetup.com/londonwriterscafe/polls/164322/), there is equal interest in both.

Second, there will be no set themes for the readings. I see the primary aim of the group as helping people with their existing work, so priority will be given to those who want feedback on a live project they are working on. Although I'll post a suggested theme each month, this is only for those who are not working on something of their own, and those readings will take a lower priority (ie. we'll come onto them if we have time).

The suggested theme, as befits a new year, is 'new beginnings'. But please, if you are working on something of your own, bring that instead.

The format will be time slots of 15 minutes, which are yours to use as you please. For example, you could do a 5-minute reading and have time for 10 minutes of feedback, or present a plot problem in 2 minutes and have 13 minutes of suggestions. It's entirely up to you, but remember that the more of your time you spend talking, the less time there is left for feedback and input!

The group will run for 2.5 hours, which will allow 10 time-slots. If more than 10 people request a slot, priority is given to those who want input on their own work. If there are more than 10 of those, names will be picked out of a hat (metaphorically speaking; I don't actually own a hat ...).

Payment by Paypal must be made when you RSVP. Funds are used for meetup fees, with any balance going into a pool to buy drinks for the assistant organisers.

This first meeting will run from 7.30-10pm to allow time for the volunteer co-organisers to meet beforehand; future meetings will run from 7-9.30pm.

The Shooting Star is less than 5 mins walk from Liverpool Street station, on the central Line:
https://www.pubandbar-... (https://www.pubandbar-network.co.uk/pubs/directions_london_liverpool%20st_shooting%20star_356.html)
Take the Bishopsgate exit from the main rail concourse, cross the road, turn left and Catherine Wheel Alley is 2nd right. The pub is about 100 metres down on the right-hand side, and we meet in the function room downstairs

venue.address: 125 Middlesex Street, Next to Catherine Wheel Alley

title: April meeting
description:
WHAT?
A monthly get-together for London writers who want input on their work.

The meeting takes the form of six time-slots of 20 minutes. You can use this slot in whatever way would help your writing. You might want to:
- read (or bring) a short piece of writing and get feedback on it
- describe a plot problem and get input on it
- get ideas on how to break through writers' block
- or something else entirely

If you are doing a reading, bear in mind that your total slot is 20 minutes, so I recommend your reading is an absolute maximum of 10 minutes, to allow sufficient time for feedback. For poetry, or any work where it can be important to see the printed format of the piece, I recommend bringing along 20 copies of the piece so that we can see it as well as hear it.

WHO?
Anyone who is currently writing, or would like to be.

HOW?
Slots are booked on the night on a first-come, first-served basis. Please arrive before 7pm if you would like to book one. I am there from 6.45pm.

There are no themes for these meetings - just bring whatever you are currently working on.

WHERE?
The Shooting Star is less than 5 mins walk from Liverpool Street station, on the central Line.
*** Meetup's map is wrong, so please follow these directions ***
Take the Bishopsgate exit from the main rail concourse, cross the road, turn left and Middlesex Street is 2nd right. The pub is about 100 metres down on the right-hand side, and we meet in the function room downstairs.

WHEN?
Please arrive before 7pm so you have time to buy a drink at the upstairs bar beforehand and we can start promptly at 7pm. (This hasn't ever happened yet, but I'm a hopeless optimist.)

The formal part of the meeting runs until approximately 9.15pm. At that point, we move upstairs to the bar for general chat and the consumption of liquid sustenance.

IMPORTANT:
Places are limited, so if you RSVP 'Yes' and then find you cannot make it, please change your RSVP to 'No' as soon as you know - and by the night before at the latest. If you RSVP 'Yes' and then fail to show up, you are denying a place to a fellow member who would love to have been there. For this reason, no-shows are suspended from the group.

(Meetup fees for the year have already been covered, so there will be no charge for the rest of the year. I have, however, never been known to refuse a drink!)

venue.address: 125 Middlesex Street, Next to Catherine Wheel Alley

title: How to get published
description:
This meeting is for those who have finished writing an unpublished book. The main focus of the evening will be on finding a publisher for a novel, and priority will be given to those who have written a novel.

Speakers will be:
Maria McCarthy: https://www.mariamccar... (https://www.mariamccarthy.co.uk)
Katherine Bling: https://www.singleholi... (https://www.singleholic.com)
Lisa Goll: worked in marketing for publishers (HarperCollins, Harlequin) for 6 years
We are also hoping that an editor from a publisher will be speaking

When you have RSVP'd Yes, you are asked to make a £10 donation to Unicef to secure your place:
https://www.justgiving... (https://www.justgiving.com/how-to-get-published)

Please click on the justgiving link, make your donation then edit your RSVP to include 'Donated' in the comments field here. (To do this, click 'Changed your mind about attending?', leave it as Yes and add your comment.)

Please note that places are limited to 35, and it's now first-come, first-served. Once 35 people have donated, all remaining Maybe RSVPs will be changed to No and the event will be closed.

title: LWC meetup - Thursday nights
description:
New - come along to LWC for Thursday night fun. My thanks to everyone who liked this idea.

London Writers' Cafe is a monthly get-together for London writers who want input on their work.
Attendees can reserve a time-slot of roughly 10 minutes each to read out their work and then 10 minutes for feedback.

You can use this slot in whatever way would help your writing.

You might want to:
- read (or bring) a short piece of writing and get feedback on it
- describe a plot problem and get input on it
- get ideas on how to break through writers' block
- or something else entirely

Slots are booked on the night on a first-come, first-served basis. Please email me (lisagoll@hotmail.com) if you'd like to read so I can reserve your space. If possible, please bring copies for group members as this gives better feedback.

If you don't have access to a printer - please email it to me and I'll print copies for you.

Looking forward to seeing everyone again :)
Lisa

Costs: £2 per session; paying by cash on the night or PayPal is set up when you RSVP.

Location:
The Book Club EC2 4RH
100 Leonard Street

description:

title: LWC meetup - Monday nights
description:
London Writers Cafe is on again...

LWC is a friendly get-together for London writers who want input, encouragement or feedback on their work. It's open to all writers; those who have just started to those who have had work published.

BTW - At this one, I'll be doing a quick session on online marketing techniques every writer can use. This will include; websites to post your work and build a following, how to start and use a blog, search engine marketing, social networks and how to find your audience.

Then we'll get back to regular schedule programming...

The meeting consists of six time-slots of 20 minutes. You can use this slot in whatever way would help your writing.

You might want to:
- read (or bring) a short piece of writing and get feedback on it
- describe a plot problem and get input on it
- get ideas on how to break through writers' block
- hear about writing events, news and website tools to use
- network with other writers

Please bring ten copies for group members to share. If you don't have access to a printer, don't worry - please email it to me and I'll print copies for you.

If you are doing a reading, bear in mind that your total slot is 20 minutes, so I recommend your reading maximum of 10 minutes and allowing sufficient time for group feedback.

Slots are booked on the night on a first-come, first-served basis. Please email me asap if you'd like a spot. We get booked up fast these days!

Costs: £2 per session; paying by cash on the night or PayPal is set up when you RSVP.

Location:
The Shooting Star is less than 5 mins walk from Liverpool Street station, on the central Line.

Directions: Take the Bishopsgate exit from the main rail concourse, cross the road, turn left and Middlesex Street is 2nd right. The pub is about 100 metres down on the right-hand side, and we meet in the function room downstairs.

Please call or text me on 07967175578 if you need directions.

Looking forward to seeing everyone again :)

best,
Lisa (LWC Crowd Controller)

title: Getting published talk with guest authors plus Q&A
description:
A special event comes to the London Writer's Cafe!

Come along to hear talks from three successfully published authors; Sue Moorcroft, Karen Mahoney and Leigh Russell. We'll also have an fiction editor from HarperCollins UK followed by a panel discussion of Q&As from the audience.
This event aims to unveil some of the most common myths around getting published and tips from those who have made it

A bit more about our guest authors:
Sue Moorcroft (https://www.suemoorcroft.com/)
In her own words: I'm a writer. I spend most of the week - and part of the weekend, and also some evenings - writing, mainly romantic fiction. The family are used to me and no-one ever suggests I get A Proper Job.

Karen Mahoney (https://kazmahoney.com/)
In her own words: I write mostly for young adults, but have a number of projects underway and am always looking to challenge myself with new things. Visit the Books section to learn more about my forthcoming publications and works in progress. My first YA novel, The Iron Witch, will be published in the US in February 2011 and in Australia, March 2011.

Leigh Russell (https://leighrussell.blogspot.com/)
CUT SHORT, her first novel, has broken sales records in bookshops around the UK. A schedule of her other appearances can be found on her publisher's website.
In her own words: You may have heard me interviewed on one of many BBC Radio stations, or seen me featured or quoted in a newspaper. I am a member of the Curzon Group and post regularly on their blog. ROAD CLOSED, the second in the series, will be published in June 2010.

Laura Deacon, Fiction Editor
We'll also have Laura Deacon, editor at Blue Door Books (https://www.harpercollins.co.uk/about-harpercollins/Imprints/blue-door/Pages/Blue-Door.aspx), talking about the submission and publishing process. She'll also be there to answer questions from guests from an editorial perspective.

Spaces will be capped at 40 people so please RSVP early.
The normal meetup time has changed to 6:30 so we have enough time to get through the talks and get to question time. As a courtesy to the speakers, please be on time.

Please feel free to invite friends to this meetup and share the event on your social networks, if you have them :)

Active members of LWC will be given first priority. A £6.50 charge for this event will be to cover costs of the speakers attending. Please pay by PayPal when you RSVP or email me that you'd rather pay on the night in cash.

Any questions, please get in touch by email. Hopefully, this event will be just as successful as the last one!

Take the Bishopsgate exit from the main rail concourse, cross the road, turn left and Middlesex Street is 2nd right. The pub is about 100 metres down on the right-hand side, and we meet in the function room downstairs.

title: LWC meetup with special guest - Jill McGivering
description:
Special guest: Jill McGivering is a BBC foreign news journalist who’s specialised in Asia for more than 20 years. She’s been the BBC Correspondent in Hongkong, Delhi and Washington – and is now based in London but reporting frequently from the region.

Her first novel, THE LAST KESTREL, is set in Helmand Province in Afghanistan and draws on her own experiences there.

venue.address: 125 Middlesex Street, Next to Catherine Wheel Alley

title: Which Stories Make the Best Screen Sensations with Agent Hannah Weatherill
description:
Agent Hannah Weatherill joins us to share what makes a novel fit for the big screen and how agents work with film and TV producers all over the world to find the next screen sensation.

For debut writers and authors, the landscape of film and TV production can seem a bit of a mystery but Hannah's experience of working and reading for the industry to find the hottest new talent means we'll know a lot more after this event. If you're thinking that your novel or short story would make an excellent film or Netflix series, come along and find out more about how your future agent could make that happen!

Hannah and I will talk for about an hour and then open up to questions from all of you. Hannah's happy to answer any general questions about submitting to her and her colleagues at Northbank Talent during the Q&A too.

Hannah is responsible for Northbank’s fiction representation, spanning all genres of adult fiction. She also heads up our book-to-screen rights business, representing film & tv rights both for Northbank’s clients and on behalf of selected third party literary agencies. Hannah has extensive experience of the book, film & tv markets both in the UK and internationally, having previously worked as a literary scout for the UK market on behalf of production companies and foreign language publishers and as both an editor and translator.

**Northbank Talent Management** is a talent and literary agency based in central London representing thought leaders, broadcasters, writers and content creators across all media throughout the world. Their team has decades of collective experience in the publishing, broadcast, brand licensing and corporate speaking industries which makes for a powerful offering in full-service talent representation. **They are actively seeking new clients and welcome all submissions whether from debut or established talent.** View the submission guide here: https://www.northbanktalent.com/contact/

TICKETS: £18 and please follow the steps to pay via PayPal when you RSVP. NOTE: Refunds will only be provided if the meetup is cancelled by us. No exceptions. We cannot offer credit for another session if you decide not to attend on the day. Please change your status to NOT GOING if you no longer plan to attend. We often have people on the waiting list and we'd hate for them to miss out.

Location: Williamsons Tavern is located in a courtyard off Bow Lane in Cheapside, closest tube station is Bank. Address: 1 Groveland Ct, London EC4M 9EH. Come down to Martha's cellar.

*Any questions, please post a comment below, and I'll respond as soon as possible.*

Try the official Meetup app to receive last-minute updates and notifications about our events as they happen to your phone: **https://www.meetup.com/apps/**

title: *Central* Creative Writing Workshop (In Person)
description:
In these fiction writing workshops, we have 3-4 writers reading their work aloud for editorial feedback, advice and encouragement. You're very welcome to come along to listen as you'll not be asked to contribute to the group feedback until you decide to do so. Most writers come along to a few sessions before offering feedback, commenting or requesting to read. Observe first and contribute whenever you want to, that's completely all right by us. You'll be surprised by how much you can learn by listening to others' work and feedback.

For people reading, pieces must be 3,500 words or less as you'll have 15-20mins reading time and 10mins of group feedback (30mins total) and all discussion is moderated by your host. We ensure that all writing feedback is constructive and respectful and we've been running these workshops as a safe place for writers since 2006.

If you'd like to read, please post a comment below. Spots are given on a first ask, first given basis with a couple of reserve spots. You must have booked your place before making a request to read.

If you are reading, please bring 5-10 copies of your pages so members can make additional editing notes for you during the reading. Please notify us by commenting below if you have to pull out of reading after your place has been confirmed. Pulling out too many times may result in us refusing your next request to read.

TICKETS: £8.50 and please follow the steps to pay via PayPal when you RSVP

NOTE: Refunds will only be provided if the meetup is cancelled by us. No exceptions. We cannot offer credit for another session if you decide not to attend on the day. Please change your status to NOT GOING if you no longer plan to attend. We often have people on the waiting list and we'd hate for them to miss out.

Location: Williamsons Tavern is located in a courtyard off Bow Lane in Cheapside, closest tube station is Bank. Address: 1 Groveland Ct, London EC4M 9EH. Come to the basement room downstairs.

Try the official Meetup app to receive last-minute updates and notifications about our events as they happen to your phone: **https://www.meetup.com/apps/**

Any questions, please post a comment below, and I'll respond as soon as possible.

title: Special Creative Writing Workshop (In Person) for First Timers Only
description:
**A creative writing workshop exclusively for writers who have NEVER BEEN to any of our other events before, please feel welcome!** We're putting on this event for any writer who finds it comforting to know that everyone there is a newbie like them. We understand how daunting it can be to enter a group where others know each other so we're trying this out!
In this workshop, we invite two first-timers attending to read a piece of their work (up to 3,000 words) for feedback, advice and encouragement from the rest of the group. We can offer feedback on any storytelling form - part of a novel, short stories, screenplays or scripts - so long as it is under the word count. All feedback is constructive and respectful and moderated by your host. We've been holding these sessions as a safe space for writers of all kinds since 2006.

An example of what constructive feedback looks like: *'I liked this section for its energy, but have you thought about pacing it differently in this bit? I found it lagged because of too many adjectives.**'***
We always refer to what's on the page to give specific examples on the strengths and weaknesses of the storytelling or writing. Feedback is never personal nor offered without some evidence wherever possible.

You're very welcome to come along to listen, as you'll not be asked to contribute to the group feedback until you decide to do so. Observe first and contribute whenever you want to, that's completely all right by us. You'll be surprised by how much you can learn by listening to others' work and feedback.

For people reading, pieces must be 3,000 words or less as you'll have 35mins in total to read your piece and hear the feedback from the group. For the rest of the time, we'll spend talking about our writing projects, struggles and goals, so this session will be more relaxed than our regular workshops. Normally, we'll gather in the bar after the session for a few drinks and a chat too.

**If you'd like to read at this workshop,** please post a (the) comment below (in the event discussion) *'I'd like to read'* and we'll confirm. Spots are given on a first ask, first given basis, with a reserve spot in case someone drops out. If you are reading, please bring 5-10 copies of your pages so the others can make additional notes and comments for you during the reading. Please notify us ASAP by commenting below if you have to pull out of reading after your place has been confirmed.

You must have booked your place before making a request to read.

TICKETS: £8.50 and please follow the steps to pay via PayPal when you book your place. T&Cs NOTE: This event is for first timers only and we can see who is a first-timer or not. Refunds will only be provided if the meetup is cancelled by us. No exceptions. We cannot offer credit for another session if you decide not to attend on the day. Please change your status to 'not going' if you no longer plan to attend.

Location: Williamsons Tavern is located in a courtyard off Bow Lane in Cheapside, closest tube station is Bank. Address: 1 Groveland Ct, London EC4M 9EH. Come to the basement room downstairs.

Try the official Meetup app to receive last-minute updates and notifications about our events as they happen to your phone: **https://www.meetup.com/apps/**

Any questions, please post a comment below, and I'll respond as soon as possible.

title: Meet the Children's Publisher: Elaine Bousfield of ZunTold Publishing (Online)
description:
Drop in to this exclusive discussion and Q&A with Elaine Bousfield of Zuntold Publishing, a new-ish publisher based in Manchester, as she talks about publishing middle grade and young adult fiction that supports mental health and her relentless search for new talent.

Elaine's plan is to publish books that emphasise some aspect of our mental health which means she's actively looking for new authors writing books with a story, character or setting that tackles or touches on the issues around our mental wellbeing, capacity and behaviour. Ideally, beautifully written stories with a lot of heart. If you think your book might be a good fit please do come along and find out more.

[ZunTold](https://www.zuntold.com/index.php?route=information/information&information_id=8) is an independent publishing company, based in Manchester, focusing on publishing good fiction to support mental health and wellbeing. They publish Middle Grade and YA fiction and love working with established voices as well as debut authors. Their authors have been nominated for literary prizes, including the Carnegie Medal, and won prestigious awards too, like the Lancashire Book of the Year Award, chosen solely by young people aged 13-14 years of age. They regularly work with agented authors, but, twice a year, they open our doors to unagented authors of Young Adult (YA) in June and Middle Grade in December. They don't publish picture books at the present time.

This workshop is suitable for writers of all levels.

Costs: £10 per person. Follow the steps to pay via PayPal when you RSVP and refunds will only be offered if the meetup is cancelled by admin. After you RSVP you'll see a link in the event location box. Just click on this at the time and date of the workshop. Google Meets will then automatically connect your computer to the session. Google meets works best with Chrome, so use this browser if possible.

Try the official Meetup app to receive last-minute updates and notifications about our events as they happen to your phone: **https://www.meetup.com/apps/**

*Any questions, please post a comment below, and I'll respond as soon as possible.*

title: Friday night write @ St James!
description:
Where better to write than London's (and supposedly Europe's!) largest bookshop? Come for a productive hour of writing in the beautiful Jermyn St Café before you begin your weekend.

Whatever you are working on - be it a book, essay, CV, annual report, taxes (want to do mine?) - you are welcome here! No one will see your work, or give you unsolicited advice. This is a group where we write quietly side by side - it is surprising how much more effective this is than doing it alone (also, when there's scones).

SCHEDULE:

17.30 - arrive, order yourself a drink or pastry, get set up

17.45 - quick intros: your name & goal for the session (if you want to share!)

17.50 - timer starts! 1 hour writing block begins

18.50 - quick recap: how'd it go?

Those who'd like are welcome to stay on and write. The cafe is open until 21.30 (noting our table is only reserved until 19.00).

WHERE: Jermyn St Café & Gallery on the mezzanine level of Waterstone's Piccadilly, at the long table in the back. I will have a sign on the table to identify us.

FAQ:
- Is it free? Yes! But please show your gratitude to our hosts by purchasing something to eat or drink.

- What if I arrive late? Don't worry about it! Come to the table, grab a seat, and quietly start your writing.

- Are there outlets? Unfortunately not at this venue - please come with your device fully charged, or bring some old school pen & paper.

- Is there wifi? Yes, but it is temperamental - please be prepared to work without it, or to use your phone as a hotspot.

- I can't make this time/location/week - will there be more? Yes! Keep your notifications on for this group; there will be more events scheduled at different times and venues.

- I'm shy/don't want to talk about my writing - should I still come? Yes! There will be no pressure to engage, or to talk about your work, although those who would like to are welcome to do so after the writing block ends.

I hope to see you there!

title: Covent Garden: Write with team members from Shut Up & Write HQ!
description:
Dear writers,

A big hello from Shut Up & Write Headquarters!

Two members of our team have flown out to London from San Francisco, and we'd love to take this opportunity to meet more of you in person. We can get some writing done together, as well as answer any questions about what it might be like to host your own event as part of the official Shut Up & Write chapter in London.

SCHEDULE:
10:00: Introductions and Q&A
10:30: Start writing
11:30: Stop writing, and more Q&A if needed

What Should I Bring?
Whatever you need to be able to write!
Bring earbuds/earplugs if you want to block the cafe’s overhead music or the occasional conversation by other patrons.
There may not be outlets available so please come with your laptops pre-charged.

We look forward to meeting you!

~Malaika & Jeremy from the Shut Up & Write Team

title: Get down and write @ St James! (Lower level cafe, lower quality puns!)
description:
Where better to write than London's (and supposedly Europe's!) largest bookshop? Take a break from the hustle & bustle and start your week with a productive hour of writing in the beautiful Embertons Café.

Whatever you are working on - be it a book, essay, CV, annual report, taxes (want to do mine?) - you are welcome here! No one will see your work, or give you unsolicited advice. This is a group where we write quietly side by side - it is surprising how much more effective this is than doing it alone (also, when there's scones).

SCHEDULE:

18.00 - arrive, order yourself a drink or pastry, get set up

18.15 - quick intros: your name & goal for the session (if you want to share!)

18.20 - timer starts! 1 hour writing block begins

19.20 - quick recap: how'd it go?

Those who'd like are welcome to stay on and write. The bookstore is open until 22.00.

WHERE: Embertons Café in the basement of Waterstone's Piccadilly, at the long table on the left. I will have a sign on the table to identify us.

FAQ:
- Is it free? Yes! But please show your gratitude to our hosts by purchasing something to eat or drink.

- What if I arrive late? Don't worry about it! Come to the table, grab a seat, and quietly start your writing.

- Are there outlets? There is a limited number of outlets at this venue - please come with your device fully charged, or bring some old school pen & paper.

- Is there wifi? Yes, but it is temperamental - please be prepared to work without it, or to use your phone as a hotspot.

- I'm shy/don't want to talk about my writing - should I still come? Yes! There will be no pressure to engage, or to talk about your work, although those who would like to are welcome to do so after the writing block ends.

I hope to see you there!

title: Remote Write!
description:
Social isolation doesn't have to be isolating! Come back to this page at 18.00 tonight for our usual Monday evening writing session (instructions below). If enough people are keen to continue remotely, I will schedule more frequent sessions (there are only so many films on Netflix) and we can consider using a more interactive platform.

Please feel free to forward this page to anyone else (whether London-based or not) who might benefit from some creative interaction online.

SCHEDULE (all times GMT):

18.00 - sign in (by replying to the first comment thread I'll create below), get set up, make yourself some tea, change out of your PJs (optional)

18.15 - share your goal for the session (using second comment thread below)

18.20 - timer starts! 1 hour writing block begins

19.20 - quick recap: how'd it go? (using third comment thread below)

I hope you're all keeping well and hope to "see" you tonight!

***Early bird special - two writing blocks!*** Join us for both or either. We're using a high-tech 1990s-style chatroom for this event - no account or special software needed, just click on this link at 11:00 (or 12:30):

https://tlk.io/suaw16-5

Please feel free to forward this page to anyone else (whether London-based or not) who might benefit from some creative interaction online.

SCHEDULE (all times BST):

11.00 - sign in, get set up, make yourself some tea, change out of your PJs (optional)

11.15 - share your goal for the session(s)

11.20 - timer starts! 1 hour writing block begins

12.20 ------------tea/pee break!------------

12.30 - timer starts! 30 min writing block begins

13.00 - quick recap: how'd it go?

I hope you're all keeping well and hope to "see" you soon!

title: Virtual writers' room: Open day drop-in
description:
Come stop by the virtual writers' room! Writing blocks will be running ad hoc throughout the day; join as and when you'd like. Attendees are welcome to announce their own blocks if one isn't running when they enter, and are welcome to stay beyond the scheduled end time.

We're using a high-tech 1990s-style chatroom for the day - no account or special software needed, just click on this link when you'd like to join:

https://tlk.io/suaw24-5

For new attendees: This is a departure from our normally structured sessions! If you prefer a more disciplined approach, please join us for our standing Monday night session at 18:00 BST, or at any other "remote write" event scheduled during the week.

title: Shut Up & Write!® LONDON / PECKHAM
description:
Join us for an hour of writing! We’ve discovered that it’s strikingly helpful to write with other writers. See if it’s true for you at 18:00 on Wednesday afternoons/evenings.

Be it a book, blog, script, essay, dissertation, resume, melody, poem or just plain work stuff, you are invited to write it with us. No one will see what you've written or give you unsolicited advice. Instead of just thinking about writing, come and get some real writing done.

SCHEDULE:
18:00 - Quick introductions
18:15 - Timer starts: write for 1 hour
19:15 - The End: chat, take off, or keep writing

OPTIONAL SOCIALIZING happens at 19:30. Writing is very solitary. Connecting (and sometimes even commiserating) with other writers is a cool thing.

BEING LATE IS OKAY: just show up and get settled, then check-in with me after the session. (I’ll be the person with the Shut Up & Write! sign.) If you were on time, please be willing to make room for the friendly latecomer.

Happy writing and I look forward to seeing you at the Peckham Pelican!

What Should I Bring?
Whatever you need to be able to write!
Bring earbuds/earplugs if you want to block the cafe’s overhead music or the occasional conversation by other patrons.

Other Important Details:
To be as Covid safe as we can, we will try to sit outside when possible so make sure laptops are charged and perhaps bring a notebook.
Please thank our hosts by purchasing something.

Join us for an hour of writing! We’ve discovered that it’s strikingly helpful to write with other writers. See if it’s true for you at 18:00 on Wednesday afternoons/evenings.

Be it a book, blog, script, essay, dissertation, resume, melody, poem or just plain work stuff, you are invited to write it with us. No one will see what you've written or give you unsolicited advice. Instead of just thinking about writing, come and get some real writing done.

SCHEDULE:
18:00 - Quick introductions
18:15 - Timer starts: write for 1 hour
19:15 - The End: chat, take off, or keep writing

OPTIONAL SOCIALIZING happens at 19:30. Writing is very solitary. Connecting (and sometimes even commiserating) with other writers is a cool thing.

BEING LATE IS OKAY: just show up and get settled, then check-in with me after the session. (I’ll be the person with the Shut Up & Write! sign.) If you were on time, please be willing to make room for the friendly latecomer.

Happy writing and I look forward to seeing you at the Peckham Pelican!

What Should I Bring?
Whatever you need to be able to write!
Bring earbuds/earplugs if you want to block the cafe’s overhead music or the occasional conversation by other patrons.

Other Important Details:
To be as Covid safe as we can, we will try to sit outside when possible so make sure laptops are charged and perhaps bring a notebook.
Please thank our hosts by purchasing something.

title: Saturday 15th January 2022 3.00pm  Classical Chamber Music Hangout Meetup
description:
1. Classical Music & Chamber Music Meet-up: A few of us hangout to play woodwind, brass instruments, harp, classical guitar and strings, accordion. We do not have room for pianos (sorry!)

If you know your way around your classical instrument (cello, violin, flute, clarinet etc), and are interested in meeting like minded instrumentalists to grow and nurture classical ensemble playing- drop us a message with your instrument and repertoire interest!

We play in an independent acoustic atelier cafe space in the London Borough of Lewisham with public transport links. Open to all ages, gender, race and diversity. Under 18s require parental permission and independent transport arrangements.

Players share repertoire before meetup and we work out what to play together following different voice parts and/or arrangements. We are a respectful group and ask the same of participants.

[Max. = 8 instrumental players]

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

title: London Southeast Singer-Songwriters Session Musicians Meet Up
description:
Who Should Join: - gigging acoustic instrumentalists, singer-songwriters, session indie, folk, acoustic players, keen musicians who know their way around their instrument and looking to join in other singers' songs, develop improvisation skills.

What we are not: - we are not an Open Mic. Funk, R'nB', electronica, hip hop and commercial music isn't what we do.

What we do at events: - We are a new independent start-up! We take each others' songs and songwriting and flesh them out from your bedroom solo acoustic pandemic playing to develop a wider session sound. We are a small independent local community of budding musicians who met and performed on the gig circuit and extend a welcome to budding musicians and acoustic singer-songwriters to develop as a community.

How long? - Usually 2 hours long acoustic music sessions limited to a max of 8 musicians. We work on shared and agreed music repertoire and play as an ensemble or session. Longer sessions break into improvisational jam sessions!

Where? We have our own private venue in the London borough of Lewisham with reasonable transport links. Those interested - get in touch. This is not a drop-in session.

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

title: London Southeast [Lewisham] Acoustic Session Musicians Meet Up
description:
Who Should Join: - gigging acoustic instrumentalists, singer-songwriters, session indie, folk, acoustic players, keen musicians who know their way around their instrument and looking to join in other singers' songs, develop improvisation skills and play each others' songs in a band style!

Instruments: Vocalists, guitarists (limits on how many per session); mandolin, flute, cajon, bass (electric), cello, fiddles, bodhran, harp join in the mix.

What we are not: - we are not an Open Mic. Funk, R'nB', electronica, hip hop and commercial music isn't what we do.

What we do at events: - We are a new independent start-up! We take each others' songs and songwriting and flesh them out from your solo acoustic pandemic bedroom playing to develop a wider session sound. We are a small independent local community of budding musicians who met and performed on the gig circuit and extend a welcome to budding musicians and acoustic singer-songwriters to develop as a community. You should be performance ready standard, seasoned or new - we are welcoming and respectful of one another and ask the same of newcomers.

How long? - 2 hours or longer! Acoustic music sessions limited to a max of 8 musicians. Longer sessions break into improvisational jam sessions!

Where? We have our own private venue in the London borough of Lewisham with reasonable transport links. Those interested - get in touch for details.

title: Sunday 23th January 2022 2.00pm London Chinese Chamber Music Ensemble Meet Up!
description:
4. London Chinese Music Ensemble Meet up:

Do you play a chinese instrument like an erhu, guzheng,pipa, liuqin, bawu, dizi or suona?

This is a meet up for our friends in London who play a chinese musical instrument and are familiar with classical chinese folk repertoire: some knowledge of the chinese written music system is required.

The music ensemble regularly meet and perform in concert and follow the annual festivals and its associated music. If you aren't sure of your standard, drop a note. We have some links to chinese music instrument tutors in London.

Bring your instrument and play. Venue in the London Borough of Lewisham - RSVP only. We have our own house guzheng and other less portable instruments.

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

Style is mostly acoustic, singer-songwriter and Americana country like Gregory Alan Isakov whom we aspire to (and fail miserably) and other alternative folk genres. We say alt. folk, which includes traditional folk in contemporary arrangements but not folk music played rigidly.

PM for details of venue. Bring your own instrument. Recorders, brass, woodwind, classical guitar, string instruments welcome. We don't have a piano sorry (!)

PM for venue location details. We meet fortnightly/monthly in the London Borough of Lewisham in our own venue [Max. = 8 instrumental players] All ages welcome. Under 18s require parental consent and independent/own travel arrangements.

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

title: London  Acoustic Indie Session Musicians Meet Up @THE FILM ATELIER SE6 2JT
description:
We're a group of local London southeast musicians/singers/songwriters who meet for an acoustic session on Saturday 5pms.

Instruments: Vocalists, acoustic/electric guitarists (limits on how many per session); mandolin, flute, cajon, bass (electric), cello, fiddles, bodhran, harp join in the mix.

What we are not: - we are not an Open Mic. Funk, R'nB', electronica, hip hop, soul and commercial music isn't what we do.

What we do at events: - we are a mix of singer-songwriters, musicians, band players on the gig circuit and/or open mic'g. We prefer acoustic, indie, folk repertoire. We support one another: jamming experience, singing in the spotlight in front of peers, getting to know each other in a small regular session meet.

How long? - 2 hours. Acoustic music sessions limited to a max of 8 musicians.

Where? We aren't going to post our private venue address online to get gatecrashed by drum n bass types! We are in the London borough of Lewisham with reasonable transport links and parking in the area.. Those interested - PM for details.

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

title: THE FILM ATELIER presents an evening of live acoustic music [OPENING WEEK]
description:
This is our intimate opening week!

We're not like other venues: everything we do is hand-crafted from making coffee, specialising in method coffee; tea; film photography and acoustic music! We do not serve alcohol: under 18s welcome (parental consent).

Come on over for a casual listen at this opening week's acoustic music night is led by **FRANKIE D**, singer-songwriter of intelligent lyrics and amicable alternative folk acoustic followed by musicians **WATCH PAINT DRY** and **GOOD TIMING**

**VENUE: THE FILM ATELIER, 314 Sangley Road LONDON SE6 2JT**
**Nearest Trains:** CATFORD BRIDGE/CATFORD

**Car:** ULEZ Free: stay south of the A205 South Circular Road - free parking in residential streets

**Buses:** Numbers 181/284 from LEWISHAM DLR/BR Station to STOP X directly opposite THE FILM ATELIER

**Music:** Acoustic Music Evening by **Frankie D, Watch Paint Dry, Good Timing**

**Contact:** thefilmatelierse6@gmail.com

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

title: London Southeast [Lewisham] Classical Musicians Meet-Up
description:
Classical Music & Chamber Music Meet-up: London Southeast [London Borough of Lewisham]

We're a friendly group of local classical musicians who meet to jam informally. If you like classical music and know your way around a classical instrument and want to meet up to play with others, come alone! We share some music spanning medieval, renaissance, modern and contemporary - all players welcome to recommend their own repertoire.

Recorders, brass, woodwind, classical guitar, string instruments welcome. We don't have a piano sorry (!)

[Max. = 8 instrumental players] All ages welcome. Under 18s require parental consent and independent/own travel arrangements.

\*\* sorry for late notice \*\*

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

title: BOARD GAMES EVENING @ THE FILM ATELIER!
description:
## Details

Taking a break from music ... we're hosting a Board Games Night this Tuesday 26th July from 5pm onwards!

Some of our regular CAT Cafe @ THE FILM ATELIER 314 Sangley Road LONDON SE6 2JT customers are into Dungeons & Dragons and other board games.

Now inviting applicants for Dungeons & Dragons and .. a Dungeon Master!

The way this works: we check on the sign-up how many are committed to playing: once we have a core minimum number of interested players committed to coming, we set the date on a weekday evening or move the date forward until we get the right numbers!

1\. Dungeons & Dragons
2\. Chess
3\. GO\!
4\. Scrabble
5\. Connect 4

Bring your own games boards - we have space indoors and outdoors in the relaxing surprise garden!

This meet-up is also combined with our languages meet-up so French, Spanish, English, Chinese speakers can practice over board games and botanical tea or organic iced coffee!

Let us know if you have any others!

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

title: Acoustic alt.folk jam session Meetup [London Southeast Lewisham]
description:
Acoustic Alt.folk Meetup [London Southeast]

Wednesday evening acoustic alt. folk meet up in THE FILM ATELIER, 314 Sangley Road, LONDON SE6 2JT [nearest station Catford/Catford Bridge; Buses 181/284 from Lewisham station stop X directly adjacent)

Style is mostly acoustic, singer-songwriter and Americana country with neo-trad interpretations and original music. We say alt. folk, which includes traditional folk in contemporary arrangements or even popular music played folk, but not folk music played rigidly.

This is a session for all attending to join in. We have a mix of experience, from performing solo musicians open to working beyond their own solo path, those developing confidence to perform folk and acoustic music to those getting into ensemble, session and band experience to grow their improvisation and aural playing. Everyone joins in, singer, background vocals, even tambourine, percussion. We have a few house instruments - check if you can't bring one over. We have house amps, mics and full drum kit, steel string guitars, mandolin family, cello and folk instruments. Local cafe audience present for feedback.

Sign up RSVP for musicians.

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

title: Falling Moon @ THE FILM ATELIER: Acoustic Folk Coffeehouse Concert
description:
Falling Moon Productions brings another coffeehouse concert to THE FILM ATELIER 314 Sangley Road LONDON SE6 2JT on Thursday 28th JULY @7pm onwards!

A wonderful lineup consisting of three evening acoustic folk acts \~ ***Hiding Places, Porch Culture &*** ***Frankie D*** celebrating new up and coming music in London's southeast's acoustic coffeehouse scene.

======================================================================

**THE FILM ATELIER 314 Sangley Road LONDON SE6 2JT** is unusual as London's only dedicated acoustic coffeehouse lounge venue serving high altitude organic (that's low caffeine) ice cold Peruvian indigenous coffee and fresh Peruvian pomegranate cold hand-pressed juice as well as our range of herbal tisane teas and fluffy Japanese Dorayaki dessert pancake filled with green matcha, mascarpone, chocolate ganache and select red bean.

By day, it is both a speciaist cafe and teahouse; a psychotherapy & counselling speciality therapy space for engaging with mental health challenges using Cognitive Analytic Therapy [CAT] and accredited clinical evidence based practices and a traditional film camera darkroom photography specialist studio, darkroom and chill out space for creatives eschewing digital interference in everyday life.

We're encouraging under 18s; families; well-behaved pets to attend and enjoy acoustic folk evenings of music like we used to! Tonight, three acoustic folk artists perform followed by a late evening social in our therapy garden yard sanctuary or intimate studio.

FREE ENTRY ON RSVP via Meet-up or email.

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

title: Acoustic alt.folk jam session Meetup [THE FILM ATELIER LONDON SE6 2JT]
description:
Acoustic Alt.folk Meetup [London Southeast]

We've started a Wednesday evening acoustic alt. folk meet up in Lewisham [London Southeast] at our venue space, THE FILM ATELIER, 314 Sangley Road, LONDON, SE6 2JT in southeast London at the start of the year and have been holding public jam sessions in our acoustic coffeehouse venue.

Style is mostly acoustic, singer-songwriter and Americana country like Gregory Alan Isakov whom we aspire to (and fail miserably) and other alternative folk genres. We say alt. folk, which includes traditional folk in contemporary arrangements or even popular music played folk, but not folk music played rigidly

We have a mix of experience, from solo performing, band performance to open mics and those starting out playing ensemble. Everyone joins in, singer, background vocals, even tambourine, percussion. We have a few house instruments - check if you can't bring one over. We have house amps, mics and full drum kit, steel string guitars, mandolin family, cello and folk instruments.

We play in the acoustic lounge of The Film Atelier behind the CAT Cafe where audience members sit and listen.

RSVP to sign up for session.

We've started a Wednesday evening acoustic alt. folk meet up in Lewisham [London Southeast] at our venue space, THE FILM ATELIER, 314 Sangley Road, LONDON, SE6 2JT in southeast London at the start of the year and have been holding public jam sessions in our acoustic coffeehouse venue.

Style is mostly acoustic, singer-songwriter and Americana country like Gregory Alan Isakov whom we aspire to (and fail miserably) and other alternative folk genres. We say alt. folk, which includes traditional folk in contemporary arrangements or even popular music played folk, but not folk music played rigidly

We have a mix of experience, from solo performing, band performance to open mics and those starting out playing ensemble. Everyone joins in, singer, background vocals, even tambourine, percussion. We have a few house instruments - check if you can't bring one over. We have house amps, mics and full drum kit, steel string guitars, mandolin family, cello and folk instruments.

We play in the acoustic lounge of The Film Atelier behind the CAT Cafe where audience members sit and listen.

RSVP to sign up for session.

group.name: THE FILM ATELIER  Folk Indie Classical Music Jam, Gigs Meets

title: Acoustic alt.folk jam session Meetup [London Southeast Lewisham]
description:
Acoustic Alt.folk Meetup [London Southeast]

Wednesday evening acoustic alt. folk meet up in THE FILM ATELIER, 314 Sangley Road, LONDON SE6 2JT [nearest station Catford/Catford Bridge; Buses 181/284 from Lewisham station stop X directly adjacent)

Style is mostly acoustic, singer-songwriter and Americana country with neo-trad interpretations and original music. We say alt. folk, which includes traditional folk in contemporary arrangements or even popular music played folk, but not folk music played rigidly.

This is a session for all attending to join in. We have a mix of experience, from performing solo musicians open to working beyond their own solo path, those developing confidence to perform folk and acoustic music to those getting into ensemble, session and band experience to grow their improvisation and aural playing. Everyone joins in, singer, background vocals, even tambourine, percussion. We have a few house instruments - check if you can't bring one over. We have house amps, mics and full drum kit, steel string guitars, mandolin family, cello and folk instruments. Local cafe audience present for feedback.

Sign up RSVP for musicians.

title: Writing @ the Laundrette
description:
We will be running a social writing event in what used to be our family-run laundrette. Now a coffee house we love believes in creativity. I, as the owner, am writing a novel and will be joining the writing sessions along with attendees.

This is a writing workshop and created to encourage writers of all levels. I have been running similar sessions for 2 years, the last year they have been online but now with the opening up of businesses, I would like to resume these sessions.

Writing workshops have been great opportunities for writers to spend concentrated time on the pieces. We do not run feedback sessions but these groups create the opportunity for writers to share their work with others in a social environment. It can take away the loneliness out of writing and creates a fantastic opportunity to meet other writers. Not to mention the contagious effects of writing in silence alongside others.

The structure of the evening will consist of a short greeting, followed by writing in silence. At the end of the 2 hours, we will book a pub nearby and spend some time together sharing our own writing experience.

I look forward to meeting all who want to come along.

title: Writing @ the Laundrette
description:
We will be running a social writing event in what used to be our family-run laundrette. Now a coffee house we love believes in creativity. I, as the owner, am writing a novel and will be joining the writing sessions along with attendees.

This used to be my favourite writing spot, while mum would wash her clothes I would sit on the thin yellow benches that matched the walls.

Now it is my favourite writing spot.

This is a writing workshop and created to encourage writers of all levels. I have been running similar sessions for 2 years, the last year they have been online but now with the opening up of businesses, I would like to resume these sessions.

Writing workshops have been great opportunities for writers to spend concentrated time on the pieces. We do not run feedback sessions but these groups create the opportunity for writers to share their work with others in a social environment.
