description:
We will be running a writing event in what used to be our family-run laundrette. Now a coffee house we love believes in creativity.

\*\*As a side note - I will be away till April and during this period I have asked the regular members to fill in as hosts. Come along and enjoy\*\*

These sessions are self-run. This space is reserved for writers. With or without the event manager the space is filled with other writers, all writing.

Once you book it, just turn up and write!

These sessions are set up to create accountability and as writing is such a solo endeavour it is there to meet others with similar goals.

This used to be my favourite reading spot, while mum would wash her clothes I would sit on the thin yellow benches that matched the walls and read. Now I write here.

This writing workshop is created to encourage writers of all levels. I have been running similar sessions for 3 years. Writing workshops have been great opportunities for writers to spend concentrated time on the pieces. We do not run feedback sessions but these groups create the opportunity for writers to share their work with others in a social environment. It can take away the loneliness out of writing and create a fantastic opportunity to meet other writers. Not to mention the contagious effects of writing in silence alongside others.

The structure of the session will consist of a short greeting, followed by writing in silence. At the end of the 2 hours, writers it and socialise.

I look forward to meeting all who want to come along, if at times I am not there talk to the other writers. This is an opportunity for you to write, i hope you enjoy and get lots of writing done.

Sinem

title: Writing @ the Laundrette
description:
We will be running a social writing event in what used to be our family-run laundrette. Now a coffee house we love believes in creativity. I, as the owner, am writing a novel and will be joining the writing sessions along with attendees.

This is a writing workshop and created to encourage writers of all levels. I have been running similar sessions for 2 years, the last year they have been online but now with the opening up of businesses, I would like to resume these sessions.

Writing workshops have been great opportunities for writers to spend concentrated time on the pieces. We do not run feedback sessions but these groups create the opportunity for writers to share their work with others in a social environment. It can take away the loneliness out of writing and creates a fantastic opportunity to meet other writers. Not to mention the contagious effects of writing in silence alongside others.

The structure of the evening will consist of a short greeting, followed by writing in silence. At the end of the 2 hours, we will book a pub nearby and spend some time together sharing our own writing experience.

I look forward to meeting all who want to come along.

These sessions are self-run. This space is reserved for writers. With or without the event manager the space is filled with other writers, all writing.

Once you book it, just turn up and write!

These sessions are set up to create accountability and as writing is such a solo endeavour it is there to meet others with similar goals.

This used to be my favourite reading spot, while mum would wash her clothes I would sit on the thin yellow benches that matched the walls and read. Now I write here.

This writing workshop is created to encourage writers of all levels. I have been running similar sessions for 3 years. Writing workshops have been great opportunities for writers to spend concentrated time on the pieces. We do not run feedback sessions but these groups create the opportunity for writers to share their work with others in a social environment. It can take away the loneliness out of writing and create a fantastic opportunity to meet other writers. Not to mention the contagious effects of writing in silence alongside others.

The structure of the session will consist of a short greeting, followed by writing in silence. At the end of the 2 hours, writers it and socialise.

I look forward to meeting all who want to come along, if at times I am not there talk to the other writers. This is an opportunity for you to write, i hope you enjoy and get lots of writing done.

Sinem

title: A focused weekly club for writers to engage in "deep work"
description:
Our weekly Write Club 'Deep Work' is ideal for anyone who writes and needs a block of time to write and gain the inspiration from being around other writers.

The group meets every Thursday at @Work Hubs, a coworking community right by Euston Station.

This is how we roll:
9.30 - brief introduction and sharing with group your planned writing
9.45 - 11.15 - focused period of 'deep work' on your planned writing.
11.15 - group review of people's progress.

- Tea, coffee, water and super fast internet provided
- Healthy snacks
- No charge
- Bring your own laptop or typewriter

title: Art of Innovation Election Night Special
description:
The Art of Innovation: Election Night Special

https://secure.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/a/7/d/8/600_461322968.jpeg

Cast your vote early, and while the rest of the nation decides the colour and shape of the next government, join us to think differently about your work, and play with colours and shapes of all kinds. Book now to attend this lightly facilitated, free event. Enjoy a great view, lovely company and good conversation, while exploring some interesting, different, and creative ways to think about work.

This informal session is being held at the wonderful London offices of BDG, overlooking the River Thames.

BDG are very kindly providing some drinks and nibbles for your enjoyment. Spaces are limited, and though this event is free to attend, you need to Book to avoid disappointment.

In addition, you are welcome to join us for a deeper exploration of how to be more innovative and resilient at work. We have a London event running during the day on June 8th, (https://www.eventbrite.co.uk/e/the-art-of-innovation-tickets-33271171971) and one two day event in Berlin on July 4th and 5th. Click the links for more information and to book tickets.

Your hosts for the evening are:

Stephanie Barnes

Stephanie is a painter and knowledge management consultant. She works with organisations to make better use of what they know, utilising her strategic business knowledge, critical thinking, and creativity in the process.

Phil Dodson

Coach, Mentor, Blogger, Artist, Podcaster, Coworking Space Operator, Facilitator and speaker.
It’s all about why we do what we do, not what we do. Life is all about stories and being able to tell our own story. I am in love with writing, art and other communication and how it helps collaboration, connection, ideas, self-confidence and productivity.

Doug Shaw

Artist, Organisational Development Consultant, Facilitator.
I’m at my best when helping people find greater effectiveness, enjoyment and inquiry in their work. I believe together beats apart, productive beats busy, connection gives us meaning, and conversations are the bond. Curiosity is underrated. We are all artists.

title: Write Club E17 (Wednesday)
description:
**Welcome to Creator Write Club!**
We've been meeting in London coworking spaces for over seven years.

**What is Creator Write Club?**
Write Club is where you can write anything from a book chapter to a work email to a song or comedy script.

**Who comes to Write Club?**
Every week authors, freelancers, artists, academics, comedians, gamers, marketers, bloggers, developers, podcasters, event managers, musicians, rappers, poets, lawyers, and sailors gather with one goal: - to work on their writing for two hours.

**How does Write Club work?**
Come and be ready to share what you intend to work on in the session.

**Start writing from 10:00 am sharp!**

We'll all write for around two hours and check in again at the end, so share our progress.

**That sounds scary?!**
We make extra effort to make sure everyone feels welcome and can do their work.

You only need to share what you are comfortable with sharing.
This group has always been relaxed, open and supportive.

**Food and Drink?**
There is an open kitchen with all-day breakfast, coffee, tea and biscuits, and fruit and water.

**Doors open from 9:30 am, and the main writing session is 10 am - 12 pm at [Creative Works](https://www.creativeworks.space/) - [Blackhorse Lane, Walthamstow E17 6DS](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Creative+Works/@51.5886642,-0.0420934,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x48761dd1e1d2ff2d:0x3298c94ad8dc5a6c!8m2!3d51.5886642!4d-0.0399047)**

That's only a minute's walk from Blackhorse Road Underground & Rail Station.

13 minutes to King's Cross on the Victoria Line and 17 minutes to Oxford Circus.

**\*Space is limited - we only have ten chairs around the table!**

title: Write Club Brixton (Friday)
description:
**Welcome to Write Club!**
We've been meeting in London coworking spaces for over seven years.

**What is Write Club?**
Write Club is where you can write anything from a book chapter to a work email.

**Who comes to Write Club?**
Every week authors, freelancers, academics, comedians, marketers, bloggers, developers, event managers, musicians, poets, lawyers and sailors gather around a table with one goal - to work on their writing for two hours.

**Join us from 12 pm to 2 pm.**

Our host for the Friday Group is [Impact Brixton](https://impactbrixton.com/), the vibrant local coworking space above Brixton Market.

[Impact Brixton](https://impactbrixton.com/) is less than a two-minute walk from Brixton tube station, in zone 2 on the Victoria line.

**How does Write Club work?**
Come and be ready to share what you intend to work on in the session.
Start writing from noon sharp.

We'll all write for around two hours and check in again at the end, so share our progress.

**That sounds scary?!**
We make extra effort to ensure everyone feels welcome and can do their work.

You only need to share what you are comfortable with sharing.
This group has always been relaxed, open and supportive.

**Food and Drink?**
There is tea, filter coffee, wifi and water here, and feel free to bring some cakes, fruit or brain food to share!

[Impact Brixton](https://impactbrixton.com/) is above Brixton Market, so you can check the many excellent independent coffee shops and restaurants here - [Brixton Market.](https://brixtonvillage.com/eat)

**p.s. Every Friday, [Impact Brixton](https://impactbrixton.com/) also hosts the [Creator Club Happy Hour](https://impactbrixton.com/events/).**

If you are a writer, videographer, entrepreneur, blogger, speaker, freelancer or doing anything else that enables you to monetise your creativity, we'd love to see you!

Enjoy a complimentary rum punch and happy hour cocktails in our iconic black bar between 6 pm and 8 pm.

Join other folks every Friday to connect with other creators and find collaboration partners.

Do you have a business or want to become a creator?

Maybe your just starting up and want to meet more creators?

If the answer is yes, you should come and join us every Friday!

**RSVP here >> for the [Creator Club Happy Hour](https://impactbrixton.com/events/).**

title: Creator Club Open Mic Night & Happy Hour (Online & In Person)
description:
**On Fridays, authors, freelancers, artists, academics, comedians, gamers, marketers, bloggers, developers, podcasters, event managers, musicians, rappers, poets, lawyers, and sailors gather at Creator Club open mic with one goal:**

✅ To network and meet potential collaborators and supporters.

**The Meet Up is ONLINE and is a live stream via Instagram.**

**🎥 [Watch this clip on Instagram from previous Creator Clubs.](https://www.instagram.com/reel/CgO8gg3oomj/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link)🎥**

When you RSVP, we'll send you a link to book to come in person at [Impact Brixton](https://impactbrixton.com), a friendly local coworking space by Brixton Tube.

# Agenda

Open mic starts at **7.30 pm** \- this will be live streamed for you folks here on Meet Up\.

(See below for in-person details)

**As a creator in the room, you can get on the mic:**
You'll have 5mins to talk about what you are working on, what inspired you to start, and the most significant challenge you have or are currently facing.

These five minutes are also for practising public speaking while creating engaging content.

It is a great place to ask for what help you need, which creators you'd like to connect with or anything else!

# How Creator Club helped us:

Through this Creator Club community, we decided how to move forward with these meet-ups.

A painful but collaborative lesson, now we see a clear and better future for what we are doing with this meet-up community.

At IB Creator Club, we welcome all dreamers to come to hang out, meet, learn and watch the magic happen.

(See below for more details on this)

**🎥 [Watch this clip on Instagram from previous Creator Clubs.](https://www.instagram.com/reel/CgO8gg3oomj/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link) 🎥**

# How do I come in person?

When you RSVP for the **live stream on Instagram**, we'll send a link to book the in-person event.

Right now, 'network events' can only be online on Meetup.com, and there is limited space in the room.

# The timings for the in-person are:

**18:00** doors open, and happy hour on 2-4-1 cocktails.

**19:00** get ready for the open mic live stream

**19:30 Open mic** live stream on Instagram

**20:30** wrap up

**21:00** event overhead out to party!

# The future of our Meet Ups

We've been running [London Bloggers Meet Up](https://www.meetup.com/londonbloggersmeetup), [Art Club](https://www.meetup.com/London-Art-Club-Deep-Work/) and [Podcast Club](https://www.meetup.com/London-Podcasting-Community/) and [Creator Write Club](https://www.meetup.com/London-Write-Club/), as well as other MeetUps, since 2009.

During COVID and lockdown, we lost our way with all these meet-ups and never got it back.

After trying many ways to kick start the whole thing, we found our true passion is getting people together to meet, connect and share their work.

Something we never worked out was how to pay people for running [Art Club](https://www.meetup.com/London-Art-Club-Deep-Work/) and [Podcast Club](https://www.meetup.com/London-Podcasting-Community/) \- it is essential as creators and artists to earn a living and build up your sense of self\-worth\.

"It's great exposure for your work" is a poor offer to build your creative career.

# Vision and next action:

Over the next few weeks, we'll invite you to join [Creator Write Club](https://www.meetup.com/London-Write-Club/) and close all our other groups.

The vision is to continue building this meet-up group into a place where every day in London, there is a chance to get together, talk about your work and, most importantly, get your creative jobs done.

You'll be able to meet daily at [Creator Write ](https://www.meetup.com/London-Write-Club/)Clubs across London AND the Friday Creator Clubs.

**🎥 [Watch this clip on Instagram from previous Creator Clubs.](https://www.instagram.com/reel/CgO8gg3oomj/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link) 🎥**

# Can't make this event?

## RSVP for the following in-person [Creator Write Club](https://www.meetup.com/London-Write-Club/)

## -> [Town Square Islington](https://www.townsqislington.co.uk) Tuesdays

## -> [Creative Works E17](https://www.creativeworks.space) Wednesdays

## -> [Impact Brixton](https://impactbrixton.com) Fridays

title: Write Club Old Street (Tuesday)
description:
**Welcome to Creators Write Club!**
Everybody Writes!

We've been meeting weekly (apart from 2020/21 COVID lockdowns) since 2014.

**What is Creators Write Club?**
Write Club is where you can write **anything** from a book chapter to a work email to a song or comedy script.

People write academic papers, podcast show notes, pitches, film documentaries, social media posts and project plans.

**Who comes to Creators Write Club?**
Every week authors, freelancers, artists, academics, comedians, gamers, marketers, bloggers, developers, podcasters, event managers, musicians, poets, lawyers and sailors gather around a table with one goal - to work on their writing for two hours.

**Join us from 10 am to 12 pm.**
This group is the Wednesday Group, and we are hosted at the [Town Square Islington](https://www.townsqislington.co.uk/) coworking space by the Old Street Roundabout.

**[Town Square](https://www.townsqislington.co.uk/) part of White Collar Factory is a 1-minute walk from Old Street tube on the Northern Line.**

Barbican and Liverpool Street stations are about fifteen minutes walk.

**How does Creators Write Club work?**
Come and be ready to share what you intend to work on in the session.

We'll all write for around two hours and check-in again at the end, so share our progress.

**That sounds scary?!**
We make extra effort to make sure everyone feels welcome and can do their work.
You only need to share what you are comfortable with sharing.

This group has always been relaxed, open and supportive.

**Food and Drink?**
There is tea, filter coffee, wifi and water here, and feel free to bring some cakes, fruit or brain food to share!

Nearby is O-zone Coffee, The Daily Grind and Pret.

We've been meeting in London coworking spaces for over seven years.

**What is Write Club?**
Write Club is where you can write anything from a book chapter to a work email.

**Who comes to Write Club?**
Every week authors, freelancers, academics, comedians, marketers, bloggers, developers, event managers, musicians, poets, lawyers and sailors gather around a table with one goal - to work on their writing for two hours.

**Join us from 12 pm to 2 pm.**

Our host for the Friday Group is [Impact Brixton](https://impactbrixton.com/), the vibrant local coworking space above Brixton Market.

[Impact Brixton](https://impactbrixton.com/) is less than a two-minute walk from Brixton tube station, in zone 2 on the Victoria line.

**How does Write Club work?**
Come and be ready to share what you intend to work on in the session.
Start writing from noon sharp.

We'll all write for around two hours and check in again at the end, so share our progress.

**That sounds scary?!**
We make extra effort to ensure everyone feels welcome and can do their work.

You only need to share what you are comfortable with sharing.
This group has always been relaxed, open and supportive.

**Food and Drink?**
There is tea, filter coffee, wifi and water here, and feel free to bring some cakes, fruit or brain food to share!

[Impact Brixton](https://impactbrixton.com/) is above Brixton Market, so you can check the many excellent independent coffee shops and restaurants here - [Brixton Market.](https://brixtonvillage.com/eat)

**p.s. Every Friday, [Impact Brixton](https://impactbrixton.com/) also hosts the [Creator Club Happy Hour](https://impactbrixton.com/events/).**

If you are a writer, videographer, entrepreneur, blogger, speaker, freelancer or doing anything else that enables you to monetise your creativity, we'd love to see you!

Enjoy a complimentary rum punch and happy hour cocktails in our iconic black bar between 6 pm and 8 pm.

Join other folks every Friday to connect with other creators and find collaboration partners.

Do you have a business or want to become a creator?

Maybe your just starting up and want to meet more creators?

If the answer is yes, you should come and join us every Friday!

**RSVP here >> for the [Creator Club Happy Hour](https://impactbrixton.com/events/).**

Everybody Writes!

**Who comes to Creators Write Club?**
Every week authors, freelancers, artists, academics, comedians, gamers, marketers, bloggers, developers, podcasters, event managers, musicians, poets, lawyers and sailors gather around a table with one goal - to work on their writing for two hours.

This group is the Wednesday Group, and we are hosted at the [Town Square Islington](https://www.townsqislington.co.uk/) coworking space by the Old Street Roundabout.

**[Town Square](https://www.townsqislington.co.uk/) part of White Collar Factory is a 1-minute walk from Old Street tube on the Northern Line.**

Barbican and Liverpool Street stations are about fifteen minutes walk.

**How does Creators Write Club work?**
Come and be ready to share what you intend to work on in the session.

We'll all write for around two hours and check-in again at the end, so share our progress.

**That sounds scary?!**
We make extra effort to make sure everyone feels welcome and can do their work.
You only need to share what you are comfortable with sharing.

This group has always been relaxed, open and supportive.

**Food and Drink?**
There is tea, filter coffee, wifi and water here, and feel free to bring some cakes, fruit or brain food to share!

Nearby is O-zone Coffee, The Daily Grind and Pret.

People write academic papers, podcast show notes, pitches, film documentaries, social media posts and project plans.

**Who comes to Creators Write Club?**
Every week authors, freelancers, artists, academics, comedians, gamers, marketers, bloggers, developers, podcasters, event managers, musicians, poets, lawyers and sailors gather around a table with one goal - to work on their writing for two hours.

**Join us from 10 am to 12 pm.**
This group is the Wednesday Group, and we are hosted at the [Town Square Islington](https://www.townsqislington.co.uk/) coworking space by the Old Street Roundabout.

**[Town Square](https://www.townsqislington.co.uk/) part of White Collar Factory is a 1-minute walk from Old Street tube on the Northern Line.**

Barbican and Liverpool Street stations are about fifteen minutes walk.

**How does Creators Write Club work?**
Come and be ready to share what you intend to work on in the session.

We'll all write for around two hours and check-in again at the end, so share our progress.

**That sounds scary?!**
We make extra effort to make sure everyone feels welcome and can do their work.
You only need to share what you are comfortable with sharing.

This group has always been relaxed, open and supportive.

**Food and Drink?**
There is tea, filter coffee, wifi and water here, and feel free to bring some cakes, fruit or brain food to share!

Nearby is O-zone Coffee, The Daily Grind and Pret.

title: Script Bootcamp Intro (Free)
description:
This is a free introductory class which prepares students for the intensive 8-week script bootcamp. In this introductory class on July 25, professional repped screenwriter Conor Kyle will teach you the process of taking an idea and developing it into a story, outline and complete feature screenplay first draft.

Bring up to 3 loglines / brand new script ideas! Conor is requesting that students use newer, fresher ideas, and stay away from the magnum opuses you've been working on or thinking about for years. The intention behind this camp is not for you to write a perfect script, but instead to teach you the organization skills, discipline, and craft techniques that will set you on the path to becoming a professional screenwriter.

This event will take place on the Script Camp Discord server: https://discord.gg/mUtQKbtsgb

8-Week Script Bootcamp Course Description:
In this eight-week live bootcamp, you’ll go from a blank page to the first draft of a complete feature screenplay. You’ll attend one three-hour class session each week in which we’ll walk through the entire process of conceiving, outlining, and writing an 80 to 120-page script. Conor will make plenty of time to take questions from students, as well as to review your work and offer feedback. This is an intensive crash-course for all skill levels, intended to keep students motivated and on track as they make their story come to life.

Week 1: Why this story?
Now that you've narrowed down your high-concept idea, we will ask the simple questions: why this story? Why now? What is both timely and universal in your idea? We will begin to chisel away at the central dramatic question of your script, and design a plan to explore this theme from all angles. You'll refine and polish your story's premise, and begin the process of outlining.

Week 2: Outlining I – Broad Strokes
Now that you’ve selected your feature idea, we’ll look at the key building blocks of your story. Chiefly: how to structure and place key scenes, and begin to establish connective tissue between them.

Week 3: Outlining II – Scene Cards
Time to organize your ideas into a much more detailed outline. These “scene cards” will each feature a key moment of your story, and you’ll organize your brainstormed sketches into a cohesive, page-by-page plan for your upcoming feature.

Week 4: Beginnings
It’s time to get going on your feature! This class will feature a both a FAQ / troubleshooting session (where we address and fill holes in your outlines before you begin) and a lecture on first acts: everything from opening image to the act break. From this class on, you’ll have to write a few pages a day to keep up with the benchmarks and get optimal feedback on your script.

Week 5: Transitions
You’ve finished the first 20-30 pages of your script, so this class focuses on your first act break. How do we diagnose whether we’ve done everything we need to do in act one? We’ll heavily emphasize a propulsive boost into the “fun and games” of your script’s second act, balancing B-stories, and more.

Week 6: Act 2 A
This class follows us into the deep dark woods of your script: the second act. We’ll go over the creation of sequences and setpieces, and review how to find the fun in your premise and mine its full potential.

Week 7: Act 2 B
Many newer writers begin to falter or repeat themselves in this section of a script, so we’ll focus on keeping up the energy and narrative push, as well as beginning to answer questions and pay off setups from earlier in the script. Danger and tension must ramp up significantly in this section, and we’ll make sure our scripts are doing just that.

Week 8: Act 3
In our eighth and final week, we will work through the difficult final act of your script. How do we conclude subplots? How can we leave the reader feeling satisfied with the ideal “unexpected yet inevitable” conclusion?

title: Structure & Pacing
description:
This two-hour live and interactive class will delve deeply into feature film structure and pacing. You’ll break open some famous movie stories, identify their primary beats, and understand how your stories can both adhere to or break these conventions. You'll also learn the steps to build and maintain narrative momentum, examining the timing, rhythm, and structural role of key scenes.

This is class is free and everyone is welcome. Be sure to RSVP early to reserve your spot.

How to enroll in the FREE Screenwriting Structure class:
• Hit the RSVP button
• Then drop by our discord server and meet Conor and your fellow students: https://discord.gg/mUtQKbtsgb

About the Instructor:
Conor Kyle has written for Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. He writes everything from stage musicals to Westerns to horror movies, and has taught screenwriting in Summer camps and online courses since 2018.

If you don't have discord, you can download it here: https://discord.com/download

title: Sunday Script Bootcamp: Week 1
description:
Sunday Script Bootcamp is an intensive 8-week course that meets weekly on Sundays. Pro screenwriter Conor Kyle walks you through the process of conceiving, outlining and writing a complete 80-120 page first draft, with personal feedback on your loglines, outlines and script pages.

Week 1: Why this story?
Now that you've narrowed down your high-concept idea, we will ask the simple questions: why this story? Why now? What is both timely and universal in your idea? We will begin to chisel away at the central dramatic question of your script, and design a plan to explore this theme from all angles. You'll refine and polish your story's premise, and begin the process of outlining.

This event will take place on the Script Camp discord server: https://discord.gg/mUtQKbtsgb

How to enroll in the Sunday Script Bootcamp:
• You can either purchase this course "a la carte" (enter coupon code MEETUP50 when you check out for $50 off): https://scriptcamp.net/product/script-bootcamp-sunday/
• Or start your free trial Unlimited Script Camp membership (includes access to all Saturday bootcamps, Sunday bootcamps, regular feedback on your ideas, outlines and pages from pro screenwriter Conor Kyle, plus all the supplemental weekday classes, over 30 hours of live classes per month): https://scriptcamp.net/membership/
• Then drop by our discord server and meet Conor and your fellow students: https://discord.gg/mUtQKbtsgb

About the Instructor:
Conor Kyle has written for Shudder's Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. He writes everything from stage musicals to Westerns to horror movies.

Complete schedule:
Week 2: Outlining I – Broad Strokes
Now that you’ve selected your feature idea, we’ll look at the key building blocks of your story. Chiefly: how to structure and place key scenes, and begin to establish connective tissue between them.

Week 3: Outlining II – Scene Cards
Time to organize your ideas into a much more detailed outline. These “scene cards” will each feature a key moment of your story, and you’ll organize your brainstormed sketches into a cohesive, page-by-page plan for your upcoming feature.

Week 4: Beginnings
It’s time to get going on your feature! This class will feature a both a FAQ / troubleshooting session (where we address and fill holes in your outlines before you begin) and a lecture on first acts: everything from opening image to the act break. From this class on, you’ll have to write a few pages a day to keep up with the benchmarks and get optimal feedback on your script.

Week 5: Transitions
You’ve finished the first 20-30 pages of your script, so this class focuses on your first act break. How do we diagnose whether we’ve done everything we need to do in act one? We’ll heavily emphasize a propulsive boost into the “fun and games” of your script’s second act, balancing B-stories, and more.

Week 6: Act 2 A
This class follows us into the deep dark woods of your script: the second act. We’ll go over the creation of sequences and setpieces, and review how to find the fun in your premise and mine its full potential.

Week 7: Act 2 B
Many newer writers begin to falter or repeat themselves in this section of a script, so we’ll focus on keeping up the energy and narrative push, as well as beginning to answer questions and pay off setups from earlier in the script. Danger and tension must ramp up significantly in this section, and we’ll make sure our scripts are doing just that.

Week 8: Act 3
In our eighth and final week, we will work through the difficult final act of your script. How do we conclude subplots? How can we leave the reader feeling satisfied with the ideal “unexpected yet inevitable” conclusion?

Week 6: Act 2 A
This class follows us into the deep dark woods of your script: the second act. We’ll go over the creation of sequences and setpieces, and review how to find the fun in your premise and mine its full potential.

Week 7: Act 2 B
Many newer writers begin to falter or repeat themselves in this section of a script, so we’ll focus on keeping up the energy and narrative push, as well as beginning to answer questions and pay off setups from earlier in the script. Danger and tension must ramp up significantly in this section, and we’ll make sure our scripts are doing just that.

Week 8: Act 3
In our eighth and final week, we will work through the difficult final act of your script. How do we conclude subplots? How can we leave the reader feeling satisfied with the ideal “unexpected yet inevitable” conclusion?

title: Screenwriting Class: Endings
description:
How does it all end? In this two-hour live and interactive class, we'll look at examples of great endings from different genres, and why they work. You'll peel apart the exact mechanics of finales and climaxes, and connect all the threads that your story has left hanging. The ending in your outline - by this point - might not be the best ending for your story anymore, and we will make sure that your script has a finish line that is worth running toward.

Please note this class requires $9/month basic script camp membership

title: Screenwriting Class: Writing Dialogue
description:
Like a lot of storytelling, writing dialogue is the act of excision, and cutting right to the interesting parts. In this two hour live and interactive class, we will explore what makes movie dialogue unique and special and how to reveal character through dialogue. We will also dive into subtext, developing a distinct voice for each character and how to diagnose and rewrite dialogue.

title: TV Pilot Bootcamp: Week 1
description:
This intensive six-week live bootcamp meets weekly on Saturdays (Sundays GMT+10/GMT+12) and continues every week through September 25. Pro screenwriter Conor Kyle takes you from blank page to the first draft of a complete original pilot screenplay. You’ll attend a three-hour class session each week in which we’ll walk through the entire process of conceiving, outlining, and writing an original TV pilot.

This is an intensive crash-course for all skill levels, intended to keep students motivated and on track as they make their story come to life.

Week 1: Concept and Loglines
We begin this course by zeroing in on the high concept core premise, and developing two separate loglines to express this idea. The first is the series logline, and the second is the pilot logline. These will act as guideposts to keep us on track through construction of your script. We’ll also start brainstorming a few different episode ideas from our prospective first season, to get a sense of where your show should begin, and where it’s headed.

How to enroll in the 6-week TV Pilot Bootcamp:
• You can either purchase the complete course "a la carte": https://scriptcamp.net/product/pilot-bootcamp/
• Or start your free trial Unlimited Script Camp membership (includes access to all Saturday bootcamps, Sunday bootcamps, regular feedback on your work from pro screenwriter Conor Kyle, plus all the supplemental weekday classes, over 30 hours of live classes per month): https://scriptcamp.net/membership/
• Then join us on discord, meet Conor and your fellow students: https://discord.gg/mUtQKbtsgb

About the Instructor:
Conor Kyle has written for Shudder's Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. He writes everything from stage musicals to Westerns to horror movies.

Week 2: Structure and Broad Strokes
Now that you have a solid grasp on the basics of your show, you’ll begin sketching out the key characters, plot points, and set-pieces in your pilot episode. Whether you’re planning for a 30-minute or 60-minute episode, you’ll need to carefully structure and pace your outline to ensure that you’re delivering on the promise of your premise quickly and efficiently enough.

Week 3: Scene Cards
Time to start getting concrete. This class focuses on nailing down every scene from your pilot as a “scene card,” which is essentially a synopsis for every single major moment in your show. ScriptCamp heavily emphasises this part of the process, and we will make an exhaustive roadmap through your entire story before starting pages next week.

Week 4: First Act
Now is when you’ll put pen to paper and begin drafting pages. You’ll have to write an act a week in order to keep up with the group’s milestones, and this is the first of three weekly check-ins in which we’ll evaluate your progress, troubleshoot issues, and give feedback.

Week 5: Second act
You’re in the thick of your script, and this class will feature both a short lecture on second acts and setpieces, as well as a lot of feedback on your in-progress pages. The goal is to keep your energy and momentum up as you approach the finale of your story, so we’ll ensure that your pacing, plot progression, and character arcs are all taking the reader in the right direction.

Week 6: Third act
Time to finish strong. We’ll again diagnose issues with your in-progress scripts, and discuss crafting the ideal “unexpected but inevitable” finale. Plus, where do we go from here? Once the script is done, we’ll discuss show bibles, contests and fellowships, and all the steps on the long road toward those coveted TV writing jobs. But more importantly, congratulations: by now you will have finished a complete pilot script!

We’ll heavily emphasize a propulsive boost into the “fun and games” of your script’s second act, balancing B-stories, and more.

Week 6: Act 2 A
This class follows us into the deep dark woods of your script: the second act. We’ll go over the creation of sequences and setpieces, and review how to find the fun in your premise and mine its full potential.

Week 7: Act 2 B
Many newer writers begin to falter or repeat themselves in this section of a script, so we’ll focus on keeping up the energy and narrative push, as well as beginning to answer questions and pay off setups from earlier in the script. Danger and tension must ramp up significantly in this section, and we’ll make sure our scripts are doing just that.

Week 8: Act 3
In our eighth and final week, we will work through the difficult final act of your script. How do we conclude subplots? How can we leave the reader feeling satisfied with the ideal “unexpected yet inevitable” conclusion?

title: Pitch Workshop (FREE)
description:
Join pro screenwriter Conor Kyle for an interactive feature pitch workshop! Bring your loglines and movie ideas of any genre! No documents are required, but if you are going to pitch be sure to have the following ready:

title: TV Pilot Bootcamp: Week 2
description:
This intensive six-week live bootcamp meets weekly on Saturdays (Sundays GMT+10/GMT+12) and continues every week through September 25. Pro screenwriter Conor Kyle takes you from blank page to the first draft of a complete original pilot screenplay. You’ll attend a three-hour class session each week in which we’ll walk through the entire process of conceiving, outlining, and writing an original TV pilot. This is an intensive crash-course for all skill levels, intended to keep students motivated and on track as they make their story come to life.

Week 2: Structure and Broad Strokes
Now that you have a solid grasp on the basics of your show, you’ll begin sketching out the key characters, plot points, and set-pieces in your pilot episode. Whether you’re planning for a 30-minute or 60-minute episode, you’ll need to carefully structure and pace your outline to ensure that you’re delivering on the promise of your premise quickly and efficiently enough.

How to enroll in the 6-week TV Pilot Bootcamp:
• You can either purchase the complete course "a la carte": https://scriptcamp.net/product/pilot-bootcamp/
• Or start your free trial Unlimited Script Camp membership (includes access to all Saturday bootcamps, Sunday bootcamps, regular feedback on your work from pro screenwriter Conor Kyle, plus all the supplemental weekday classes, over 30 hours of live classes per month): https://scriptcamp.net/membership/
• Then join us on discord, meet Conor and your fellow students: https://discord.gg/mUtQKbtsgb

About the Instructor:
Conor Kyle has written for Shudder's Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. He writes everything from stage musicals to Westerns to horror movies.

Week 1: Concept and Loglines
We begin this course by zeroing in on the high concept core premise, and developing two separate loglines to express this idea. The first is the series logline, and the second is the pilot logline. These will act as guideposts to keep us on track through construction of your script. We’ll also start brainstorming a few different episode ideas from our prospective first season, to get a sense of where your show should begin, and where it’s headed.

Week 3: Scene Cards
Time to start getting concrete. This class focuses on nailing down every scene from your pilot as a “scene card,” which is essentially a synopsis for every single major moment in your show. ScriptCamp heavily emphasizes this part of the process, and we will make an exhaustive roadmap through your entire story before starting pages next week.

Week 4: First Act
Now is when you’ll put pen to paper and begin drafting pages. You’ll have to write an act a week in order to keep up with the group’s milestones, and this is the first of three weekly check-ins in which we’ll evaluate your progress, troubleshoot issues, and give feedback.

Week 5: Second act
You’re in the thick of your script, and this class will feature both a short lecture on second acts and setpieces, as well as a lot of feedback on your in-progress pages. The goal is to keep your energy and momentum up as you approach the finale of your story, so we’ll ensure that your pacing, plot progression, and character arcs are all taking the reader in the right direction.

Week 6: Third act
Time to finish strong. We’ll again diagnose issues with your in-progress scripts, and discuss crafting the ideal “unexpected but inevitable” finale. Plus, where do we go from here? Once the script is done, we’ll discuss show bibles, contests and fellowships, and all the steps on the long road toward those coveted TV writing jobs. But more importantly, congratulations: by now you will have finished a complete pilot script!

We’ll heavily emphasize a propulsive boost into the “fun and games” of your script’s second act, balancing B-stories, and more.

Week 7: Act 2 B
Many newer writers begin to falter or repeat themselves in this section of a script, so we’ll focus on keeping up the energy and narrative push, as well as beginning to answer questions and pay off setups from earlier in the script. Danger and tension must ramp up significantly in this section, and we’ll make sure our scripts are doing just that.

Week 8: Act 3
In our eighth and final week, we will work through the difficult final act of your script. How do we conclude subplots? How can we leave the reader feeling satisfied with the ideal “unexpected yet inevitable” conclusion?

title: Logline Workshop (FREE)
description:
Welcome to Logline Workshop! This is a weekly workshop designed to help you refine your feature film logline or TV pilot logline.

This event is completely free and open to everyone. Space is limited, so be sure to hit the RSVP button. Then join us in the Workshop channel on discord ( https://discord.gg/kQfrX3R7Zy )

If you'd like to workshop your logline please post it in the #ideas-and-loglines channel on the Script Camp Discord ( https://discord.gg/E2sDHGfwG8 ) along with your title, genre and comps, and we will review them in the order received.

Here's an example logline template from Conor: “When (INCITING INCIDENT), a (ADJECTIVE) (PROTAGONIST) must (CONFLICT) before / or else (STAKES or TICKING CLOCK).”

It's difficult to perfect a logline by yourself. Usually this requires some help and feedback from fellow writers.

FAQ:

Q: I have no idea how to create a logline. Is it okay if I just join to listen and learn?
A: Absolutely! This workshop is entirely free and everyone is welcome to join.

Q: What's the purpose of a logline?
A: The logline is not only a way to get others interested in reading your script, but it's also an important step in the outlining and writing process. Usually it requires a little help from others to workshop a rough idea into a strong logline that seems like it can sustain a feature length story. And then it serves as your North star while developing the idea, constructing your outline, and writing the first draft

Q: My writing is ____ genre, is that okay?
A: Yes! Bring your logline for a feature film or TV Pilot (note that TV pilots require a series logline and pilot logline). Any genre is OK.

Q: I'm worried that my logline sucks, should I still bring it?
A: This is a process. Nobody will be perfect. We're here to support you, which means pointing out the parts that are awesome and providing honest feedback for improvement.

Q: I still don't understand what a logline is, exactly.
A: Here is a detailed write-up by Chris Lockhart about how to construct a logline: http://www.twoadverbs.com/logline.pdf

title: Outline Workshop (FREE)
description:
Welcome to Outline Workshop! This is a weekly workshop designed to help you refine your screenplay outline using Conor Kyle's practical story development process.

This event is completely free and open to everyone. Space is limited, so be sure to hit the RSVP button. Then join us in the Workshop channel on discord ( https://discord.gg/kQfrX3R7Zy )

If you'd like to workshop your outline please post it in the #outlines channel on the Script Camp Discord ( https://discord.gg/Kv827aqw6q ) along with your title and logline and we will review them in the order received. You should already have a very solid logline and either a rough Story Beats Outline or a more detailed Scene Cards Outline. If you need help with your logline, please drop by the weekly Logline Workshop meetup on Friday.

See below a breakdown of the story development steps Conor teaches. If you complete each step properly, it makes the next step a lot easier:

1. The first step is to take your rough idea and develop this into a solid logline that can sustain a feature film. (Or if this is a TV pilot, you need to develop a series logline and a pilot logline.) Here's an example logline template from Conor: “When (INCITING INCIDENT), a (ADJECTIVE) (PROTAGONIST) must (CONFLICT) before / or else (STAKES or TICKING CLOCK).” It's difficult to perfect a logline by yourself. Usually this requires some help and feedback from fellow writers.

2. The second step is filling up your sketchbook. This can be google docs, Evernote, MS word, whatever you use for notes. Brainstorm lots of fun ideas for scenes, develop your theme, anti-theme and flesh out your characters. Whatever sort of notes and doodling process you need to develop your story. Some writers find it helpful to collect photos and artwork at this stage as well.

3. The third step is to break out your story into beats and develop a Story Beats Outline with estimated pages for each section and a list of scenes. If you are writing a 90 page script, for example, your Story Beats Outline is going to have sections something like this, with a list of scene breakdowns in each section.

Intro (1-10):

Catalyst (10):

Debate (10-20):

Break into 2 (20):

Fun and Games (20-45):

Midpoint (45):

Bad Guys Close In (45-60):

All is Lost (60):

Dark Night of the Soul (61-70):

Break Into 3 (70):

Finale (70-90):

4. The next step is called a Scene Cards Outline. This is a detailed prose description of what happens in every single scene (not sluglines, but dramatic scenes), with estimated page count for each scene, dialogue excerpts and as much as you can of the action description that will end up in your first draft. This stage of your outlining process should feel more like writing than outlining. You are getting the heavy lifting out of the way, so that when you sit down to start the first draft, the pages are going to fly very quickly.

FAQ:

Q: I have no idea how to create a screenplay outline. Is it okay if I just join to listen and learn?
A: Absolutely! This workshop is entirely free and everyone is welcome to join.

Q: My writing is ____ genre, is that okay?
A: Yes! Bring your outline for a feature film or TV Pilot, whatever genre you're working on.

Q: I don't have a solid logline yet.
A: If you're having trouble with your logline, drop by our weekly Logline Workshop on Friday or post your logline in the #ideas-and-loglines channel for feedback on the Script Camp Discord ( https://discord.gg/E2sDHGfwG8 ).

Q: I'm worried that my outline sucks, should I still bring it?
A: Rough drafts and outlines are always rough. Nobody will be perfect. We're here to support you, which means pointing out the parts that are awesome and providing honest feedback for improvement.

title: Scene Critiques Workshop (FREE)
description:
During this meetup, we will workshop individual dramatic scenes from our screenplays in progress (anywhere from 1 to 5 pages). Our goal is to help each writer find a breakthrough with a troublesome scene, through table reads and constructive feedback.

This event is free for everyone to attend. Space is limited, so be sure to hit the RSVP button. If you have a scene to submit, please post your script in pdf format in the #scripts channel on the Script Camp discord ( https://discord.gg/SeBAJUGm7N ) 24 hours prior to the workshop, along with the following info:

- Title
- Format (Feature, Pilot or Short)
- Genre
- Logline (Any comps with similar tone?)
- What is the main problem you have with this scene that you need help to fix?
- Why is this scene important to the film?
- What is essential for us to know about what happened prior to the scene?
- Who is the main character of the scene?
- What do they want?
- What stands in their way?

title: Scene Study: Escalation
description:
Join Conor for a two-hour live and interactive class on how to escalate the dramatic tension and stakes in your scenes. We will perform a case-study of several scenes from produced features, all of which demonstrate some great ways to amp up conflict and urgency. Bring a 1-4 page scene from one of your own features! Conor will select a few student scenes during the class to examine, and we'll brainstorm ways to take them to the next level.

Please note this class requires $9/month basic script camp membership.

How to enroll in the Scene Study: Escalations class:

title: Logline Workshop (FREE)
description:
Welcome to Logline Workshop! This is a weekly workshop designed to help you refine your feature film logline or TV pilot logline.

This event is completely free and open to everyone. Space is limited, so be sure to hit the RSVP button. Then join us in the Workshop channel on discord ( https://discord.gg/kQfrX3R7Zy )

If you'd like to workshop your logline please post it in the #ideas-and-loglines channel on the Script Camp Discord ( https://discord.gg/E2sDHGfwG8 ) along with your title, genre and comps, and we will review them in the order received.

Here's an example logline template from Conor:
“When (INCITING INCIDENT), a (ADJECTIVE) (PROTAGONIST) must (CONFLICT) before / or else (STAKES or TICKING CLOCK).”

It's difficult to perfect a logline by yourself. Usually this requires some help and feedback from fellow writers.

FAQ:

Q: I have no idea how to create a logline. Is it okay if I just join to listen and learn?
A: Absolutely! This workshop is entirely free and everyone is welcome to join.

Q: What's the purpose of a logline?
A: The logline is not only a way to get others interested in reading your script, but it's also an important step in the outlining and writing process. Usually it requires a little help from others to workshop a rough idea into a strong logline that seems like it can sustain a feature length story. And then it serves as your North star while developing the idea, constructing your outline, and writing the first draft

Q: My writing is ____ genre, is that okay?
A: Yes! Bring your logline for a feature film or TV Pilot (note that TV pilots require a series logline and pilot logline). Any genre is OK.

Q: I'm worried that my logline sucks, should I still bring it?
A: This is a process. Nobody will be perfect. We're here to support you, which means pointing out the parts that are awesome and providing honest feedback for improvement.

Q: I still don't understand what a logline is, exactly.
A: Here's a detailed write-up by Chris Lockhart about how to construct a logline: http://www.twoadverbs.com/logline.pdf

title: TV Pilot Bootcamp: Week 4
description:
This intensive six-week live bootcamp meets weekly on Saturdays (Sundays GMT+10/GMT+12) and continues every week through September 25. Pro screenwriter Conor Kyle takes you from blank page to the first draft of a complete original pilot screenplay. You’ll attend a three-hour class session each week in which we’ll walk through the entire process of conceiving, outlining, and writing an original TV pilot. This is an intensive crash-course for all skill levels, intended to keep students motivated and on track as they make their story come to life.

Please note this class is not free. To join you must enroll in Unlimited Script Camp on our website.

Week 4: First Act
Now is when you’ll put pen to paper and begin drafting pages. You’ll have to write an act a week in order to keep up with the group’s milestones, and this is the first of three weekly check-ins in which we’ll evaluate your progress, troubleshoot issues, and give feedback.

How to enroll in the TV Pilot Bootcamp:
• Start your free trial Unlimited Script Camp membership (includes access to all Saturday bootcamps, Sunday bootcamps, regular feedback on your work from pro screenwriter Conor Kyle, plus all the supplemental weekday classes, over 30 hours of live classes per month): https://scriptcamp.net/membership/
• Then join us on discord, meet Conor and your fellow students: https://discord.gg/mUtQKbtsgb

About the Instructor:
Conor Kyle has written for Shudder's Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. He writes everything from stage musicals to Westerns to horror movies.

Week 1: Concept and Loglines
We begin this course by zeroing in on the high concept core premise, and developing two separate loglines to express this idea. The first is the series logline, and the second is the pilot logline. These will act as guideposts to keep us on track through construction of your script. We’ll also start brainstorming a few different episode ideas from our prospective first season, to get a sense of where your show should begin, and where it’s headed.

Week 2: Structure and Broad Strokes
Now that you have a solid grasp on the basics of your show, you’ll begin sketching out the key characters, plot points, and set-pieces in your pilot episode. Whether you’re planning for a 30-minute or 60-minute episode, you’ll need to carefully structure and pace your outline to ensure that you’re delivering on the promise of your premise quickly and efficiently enough.

Week 3: Scene Cards
Time to start getting concrete. This class focuses on nailing down every scene from your pilot as a “scene card,” which is essentially a synopsis for every single major moment in your show. ScriptCamp heavily emphasizes this part of the process, and we will make an exhaustive roadmap through your entire story before starting pages next week.

Week 5: Second act
You’re in the thick of your script, and this class will feature both a short lecture on second acts and setpieces, as well as a lot of feedback on your in-progress pages. The goal is to keep your energy and momentum up as you approach the finale of your story, so we’ll ensure that your pacing, plot progression, and character arcs are all taking the reader in the right direction.

Week 6: Third act
Time to finish strong. We’ll again diagnose issues with your in-progress scripts, and discuss crafting the ideal “unexpected but inevitable” finale. Plus, where do we go from here? Once the script is done, we’ll discuss show bibles, contests and fellowships, and all the steps on the long road toward those coveted TV writing jobs. But more importantly, congratulations: by now you will have finished a complete pilot script!

title: Sunday Script Bootcamp: Week 8
description:
Sunday Script Bootcamp is an intensive 8-week course that meets weekly on Sundays. Pro screenwriter Conor Kyle walks you through the process of conceiving, outlining and writing a complete 80-120 page first draft, with personal feedback on your loglines, outlines and script pages.

Please note this class is not free. To join, you must enroll in Unlimited Script Camp on our website.

Week 8: Act 3
In our eighth and final week, we will work through the difficult final act of your script. How do we conclude subplots? How can we leave the reader feeling satisfied with the ideal “unexpected yet inevitable” conclusion?

How to enroll in the Sunday Script Bootcamp:
• Simply start your free trial Unlimited Script Camp membership (includes access to all Saturday bootcamps, Sunday bootcamps, regular feedback on your ideas, outlines and pages from pro screenwriter Conor Kyle, plus all the supplemental weekday classes, over 30 hours of live classes per month): https://scriptcamp.net/membership/
• Then drop by our discord server and meet Conor and your fellow students: https://discord.gg/mUtQKbtsgb

About the Instructor:
Conor Kyle has written for Shudder's Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. He writes everything from stage musicals to Westerns to horror movies.

Complete schedule:
Week 1: Why this story?
Now that you've narrowed down your high-concept idea, we will ask the simple questions: why this story? Why now? What is both timely and universal in your idea? We will begin to chisel away at the central dramatic question of your script, and design a plan to explore this theme from all angles. You'll refine and polish your story's premise, and begin the process of outlining.

Week 2: Outlining I – Broad Strokes
Now that you’ve selected your feature idea, we’ll look at the key building blocks of your story. Chiefly: how to structure and place key scenes, and begin to establish connective tissue between them.

Week 3: Outlining II – Scene Cards
Time to organize your ideas into a much more detailed outline. These “scene cards” will each feature a key moment of your story, and you’ll organize your brainstormed sketches into a cohesive, page-by-page plan for your upcoming feature.

Week 5: Transitions
You’ve finished the first 20-30 pages of your script, so this class focuses on your first act break. How do we diagnose whether we’ve done everything we need to do in act one? We’ll heavily emphasize a propulsive boost into the “fun and games” of your script’s second act, balancing B-stories, and more.

Week 6: Act 2 A
This class follows us into the deep dark woods of your script: the second act. We’ll go over the creation of sequences and setpieces, and review how to find the fun in your premise and mine its full potential.

Week 7: Act 2 B
Many newer writers begin to falter or repeat themselves in this section of a script, so we’ll focus on keeping up the energy and narrative push, as well as beginning to answer questions and pay off setups from earlier in the script. Danger and tension must ramp up significantly in this section, and we’ll make sure our scripts are doing just that.

title: Outline Workshop (FREE)
description:
Welcome to Outline Workshop! This is a weekly workshop designed to help you refine your screenplay outline using Conor Kyle's practical story development process.

This event is completely free and open to everyone. Space is limited, so be sure to hit the RSVP button. Then join us in the Workshop channel on Script Camp discord ( https://discord.gg/kQfrX3R7Zy )

If you'd like to workshop your outline please post it in the #outlines channel on the Script Camp discord ( https://discord.gg/Kv827aqw6q ) along with your title and logline and we will review them in the order received. You should already have a very solid logline and either a rough Story Beats Outline or a more detailed Scene Cards Outline. If you need help with your logline, please drop by the weekly Logline Workshop meetup on Friday.

See below a breakdown of the story development steps Conor teaches. If you complete each step properly, it makes the next step a lot easier:

1. The first step is to take your rough idea and develop this into a solid logline that can sustain a feature film. (Or if this is a TV pilot, you need to develop a series logline and a pilot logline.) Here's an example logline template from Conor: “When (INCITING INCIDENT), a (ADJECTIVE) (PROTAGONIST) must (CONFLICT) before / or else (STAKES or TICKING CLOCK).” It's difficult to perfect a logline by yourself. Usually this requires some help and feedback from fellow writers.

2. The second step is filling up your sketchbook. This can be google docs, Evernote, MS word, whatever you use for notes. Brainstorm lots of fun ideas for scenes, develop your theme, anti-theme and flesh out your characters. Whatever sort of notes and doodling process you need to develop your story. Some writers find it helpful to collect photos and artwork at this stage as well.

3. The third step is to break out your story into beats and develop a Story Beats Outline with estimated pages for each section and a list of scenes. If you are writing a 90 page script, for example, your Story Beats Outline is going to have sections something like this, with a list of scene breakdowns in each section.

Intro (1-10):

Catalyst (10):

Debate (10-20):

Break into 2 (20):

Fun and Games (20-45):

Midpoint (45):

Bad Guys Close In (45-60):

All is Lost (60):

Dark Night of the Soul (61-70):

Break Into 3 (70):

Finale (70-90):

4. The next step is called a Scene Cards Outline. This is a detailed prose description of what happens in every single scene (not sluglines, but dramatic scenes), with estimated page count for each scene, dialogue excerpts and as much as you can of the action description that will end up in your first draft. This stage of your outlining process should feel more like writing than outlining. You are getting the heavy lifting out of the way, so that when you sit down to start the first draft, the pages are going to fly very quickly.

FAQ:

Q: I have no idea how to create a screenplay outline. Is it okay if I just join to listen and learn?
A: Absolutely! This workshop is entirely free and everyone is welcome to join.

Q: My writing is ____ genre, is that okay?
A: Yes! Bring your outline for a feature film or TV Pilot, whatever genre you're working on.

Q: I don't have a solid logline yet.
A: If you're having trouble with your logline, drop by our weekly Logline Workshop on Friday or post your logline in the #ideas-and-loglines channel for feedback on the Script Camp Discord ( https://discord.gg/E2sDHGfwG8 ).

Q: I'm worried that my outline sucks, should I still bring it?
A: Rough drafts and outlines are always rough. Nobody will be perfect. We're here to support you, which means pointing out the parts that are awesome and providing honest feedback for improvement.

title: Scene Critiques Workshop (FREE)
description:
During this meetup, we will workshop individual dramatic scenes from our screenplays in progress (anywhere from 1 to 5 pages). Our goal is to help each writer find a breakthrough with a troublesome scene, through table reads and constructive feedback.

This event is free for everyone to attend. Space is limited, so be sure to hit the RSVP button. If you have a scene to submit, please post your script in pdf format in the #scripts channel on the Script Camp discord ( https://discord.gg/SeBAJUGm7N ) prior to the workshop, along with the following info:

- Title
- Format (Feature, Pilot or Short)
- Genre
- Logline (Any comps with similar tone?)
- What is the main problem you have with this scene that you need help to fix?
- Why is this scene important to the film?
- What is essential for us to know about what happened prior to the scene?
- Who is the main character of the scene?
- What do they want?
- What stands in their way?

title: Copyright for Screenwriters (FREE)
description:
Join Nacho for a two-hour live and interactive class on copyright and entertainment law for screenwriters. We will discuss what copyright is and how it protects our work. Is there any point in registering scripts with the WGA or U.S. Copyright Office? What options do we have if someone steals our idea? Do we really need to sign those restrictive, one-sided waiver letters and submission release forms from producers? We will also discuss working with writing partners and how to option source material IP or life story rights.

This event is completely free and open to everyone. Space is limited, so be sure to hit the RSVP button. This event is completely free and open to everyone. Space is limited, so be sure to hit the RSVP button. Then join us in the Workshop channel on discord ( https://discord.gg/kQfrX3R7Zy )

title: Script Swap & Table Reads (FREE)
description:
Need some feedback on your feature film screenplay or tv pilot? During this meetup, we will read out loud and critique the first 10 pages of your screenplays in progress, and assign script swap readers to provide feedback on your entire script.

This event is free for everyone to attend. Space is limited, so be sure to hit the RSVP button. If you have a scene to submit, please post your script in pdf format in the #scripts channel on the Script Camp discord ( https://discord.gg/SeBAJUGm7N ) prior to the workshop, along with the following info:

- Title
- Format (Feature, Pilot or Short)
- Genre
- Logline (Any comps with similar tone?)

- What is the main problem you have with this script that you need help to fix?

title: Script Camp Writers Room (FREE)
description:
During each Writers Room session, we simply gather here to connect remotely and write together at the same time. This supports us in building a regular writing discipline. You are welcome to join us and see if this helps your writing process.

Please note that no one will read or critique your writing in this session. Writers Room sessions are a safe space for screenwriters to work on their craft. We gather here solely in order to write our screenplays during the scheduled time.

Great time to get your logline ready for the upcoming bootcamp, or polish off your pages for the Script Swap & Table Reads!

**Schedule:**
• First 15 minutes: Greetings & introductions / socializing
• Remainder of the 4 hour session: Everyone writes in quiet, with hourly 5 minute break to check in.
• You can join later or leave early at any time - no need to attend the full 4 hour session.

**How to join the Writers Room?**
• The Writers Room is free to join, everyone is welcome!
• Just hit the RSVP button
• Then hop in the voice channel here: [https://discord.gg/KGyUqXu2dZ](https://discord.gg/KGyUqXu2dZ)

title: Comedy TV Pilot Writers Group (FREE)
description:
**[Ready to Write a Comedy Pilot?](https://forms.gle/bAbnM58cToqUhnKt7)**

Attention comedy screenwriters! Join us on the Script Camp Discord for the next meeting of the **Comedy TV Pilot Writers Group!**

In this group we support each other to achieve our writing goals as we develop our comedy TV pilot projects and share comedy writing techniques. The group meets weekly on Mondays (3pm ET / 2pm CT / 12pm PT / 8pm London) and Wednesdays (10am ET / 9am CT / 7am PT / 3pm London).

**How to Join the Group?**

* Note this group is for intermediate to advanced writers. Ideally you have already written at least one TV pilot.
* Please fill out this sign-up form to join the Comedy Pilot Writers Group: [https://forms.gle/bAbnM58cToqUhnKt7](https://forms.gle/bAbnM58cToqUhnKt7)
* Then hop in the voice channel on Discord: [https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna)

Contact [@bob](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna) on the Script Camp Discord if you have any questions about the **Comedy Pilot Writers Group.**

If you're interested in starting your own writers group, here's the form to request a new Script Camp writers group: [https://forms.gle/TrHtLVMZdCTpMTvL9](https://forms.gle/TrHtLVMZdCTpMTvL9)

title: How to Analyze a Screenplay, Part 1 (Free Class)
description:
Designed for both aspiring story analysts and screenwriters who want to accelerate their careers, this live two-day course helps you master the methods used by script readers and story analysts who evaluate submissions to production companies, fellowships, screenwriting contests, literary agencies, and studios.

You'll learn how to evaluate a premise and conduct an in-depth analysis of a script's three-act structure and scene construction. You'll also master the terminology used in story development sessions, the foundations for great dialogue, and how to find original approaches to established genres.

These principles become synthesized into coverage written to the highest professional standards either in preparation for a job as a script reader, or simply in order to critique your own scripts effectively.

**How to enroll in the class?**
• This class is free and open to everyone
• Hit the RSVP button to save your spot
• Then join us on discord: [https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna)

title: Script Camp Writers Room (FREE)
description:
During each Writers Room session, we simply gather here to connect remotely and write together at the same time. This supports us in building a regular writing discipline. You are welcome to join us and see if this helps your writing process.

Please note that no one will read or critique your writing in this session. Writers Room sessions are a safe space for screenwriters to work on their craft. We gather here solely in order to write our screenplays during the scheduled time.

Great time to get your logline ready for the upcoming bootcamp, or polish off your pages for the Script Swap & Table Reads!

**Schedule:**
• First 15 minutes: Greetings & introductions / socializing
• Remainder of the 4 hour session: Everyone writes in quiet, with hourly 5 minute break to check in.
• You can join later or leave early at any time - no need to attend the full 4 hour session.

**How to join the Writers Room?**
• The Writers Room is free to join, everyone is welcome!
• Just hit the RSVP button
• Then hop in the voice channel here: [https://discord.gg/KGyUqXu2dZ](https://discord.gg/KGyUqXu2dZ)

title: How to Analyze a Screenplay, Part 2 (Free Class)
description:
Designed for both aspiring story analysts and screenwriters who want to accelerate their careers, this live two-day course helps you master the methods used by script readers and story analysts who evaluate submissions to production companies, fellowships, screenwriting contests, literary agencies, and studios.

You'll learn how to evaluate a premise and conduct an in-depth analysis of a script's three-act structure and scene construction. You'll also master the terminology used in story development sessions, the foundations for great dialogue, and how to find original approaches to established genres.

These principles become synthesized into coverage written to the highest professional standards either in preparation for a job as a script reader, or simply in order to critique your own scripts effectively.

**How to enroll in the class?**
• This class is free and open to everyone
• Hit the RSVP button to save your spot
• Then join us on discord: [https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna)

title: Feature Bootcamp: Week 6 (Paid Screenwriting Class)
description:
The eight-week Bootcamp runs June 24 through August 12. Conor takes you from a blank page to the first draft of a complete feature screenplay, walking you through the entire process of conceiving, outlining, and writing a 90-120 page script.

The intention behind this bootcamp is not for you to write a perfect script, but instead to teach you the organization skills, discipline, and craft techniques that will set you on the path to becoming a professional screenwriter.

**Week 6: Second Act (July 29)**
This class follows us into the deep dark woods of your script: the second act. We’ll go over the creation of sequences and setpieces, and review how to find the fun in your premise and mine its full potential.

***About the Instructor:***
**Conor Kyle** has written for Shudder's Creepshow (2019) and placed twice in the Nicholl Fellowship with his scripts “Peter and the Wolves” (quarterfinals, also Launchpad top 10) and The Tube (semifinals). His screenplays have also been featured on special sections of the annual Hit List, Young & Hungry List, Spec Book, and on Tracking Board’s “Best Writers of the Year” booklet. He writes everything from stage musicals to Westerns to horror movies. Follow Conor on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/TheScriptCamp), [YouTube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCHTkV9mxO1_wqfUsoGe7mXg/videos) and [Twitch](https://www.twitch.tv/scriptcamp)

**How to join the 8-week Screenwriting Bootcamp:**

* Please note this class is not free.
* You can either purchase the full course “a la carte”: [https://scriptcamp.net/classes](https://scriptcamp.net/classes)
* Or start your free trial $49 Unlimited Script Camp membership with access to over 70 hours of live classes, workshops and bootcamps every month, including the weekly Writers Lab: [https://scriptcamp.net/membership/](https://scriptcamp.net/membership/)
* Then join us on Discord: [https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna)

***8-Week Bootcamp Course Schedule:***
**Week 1: Why this story? / Sketchbook (June 24)**
Now that you’ve narrowed down your high-concept idea, we will ask the simple questions: why this story? Why now? What is both timely and universal in your idea? We will begin to chisel away at the central dramatic question of your script, and design a plan to explore this theme from all angles. During this class, you’ll refine and polish your story’s premise, and begin the process of filling out your sketchbook.

**Week 2: Outlining I – Story Beats (July 1)**
Now that you’ve filled out your sketchbook, we’ll look at the key building blocks of your story. Chiefly: how to structure and place key scenes, and begin to establish connective tissue between them.

**Week 3: Outlining II – Scene Cards (July 8)**
Time to organize your ideas into a much more detailed outline. These “scene cards” will each feature a key moment of your story, and you’ll organize your story beats into a cohesive, page-by-page plan for your upcoming feature.

**Week 4: Beginnings (July 15)**
It’s time to get going on your feature! This class will feature a both a FAQ / troubleshooting session (where we address and fill holes in your outlines before you begin) and a lecture on first acts: everything from opening image to the act break. From this class on, you’ll have to write a few pages a day to keep up with the benchmarks and get optimal feedback on your script.

**Week 5: Transitions (July 22)**
You’ve finished the first 20-30 pages of your script, so this class focuses on your first act break. How do we diagnose whether we’ve done everything we need to do in act one? We’ll heavily emphasize a propulsive boost into the “fun and games” of your script’s second act, balancing B-stories, and more.

**Week 6: Second Act (July 29)**
This class follows us into the deep dark woods of your script: the second act. We’ll go over the creation of sequences and setpieces, and review how to find the fun in your premise and mine its full potential.

**Week 7: Escalation (August 5)**
Many newer writers begin to falter or repeat themselves in this section of a script, so we’ll focus on keeping up the energy and narrative push, as well as beginning to answer questions and pay off setups from earlier in the script. Danger and tension must ramp up significantly in this section, and we’ll make sure our scripts are doing just that.

**Week 8: Endings (August 12)**
In our eighth and final week, we will work through the difficult final act of your script. How do we conclude subplots? How can we leave the reader feeling satisfied with the ideal “unexpected yet inevitable” conclusion? But more importantly, congratulations: by the end of this week you will have finished a complete feature-length screenplay!

title: Advanced Screenwriters Lab (FREE)
description:
Welcome to the **Advanced Lab**! We are a group of writers serious about improving at the craft. We meet weekly to share our work for feedback and discuss writing techniques.

This is a place for advanced students and emerging writers to continue their journeys by developing new projects on a regular basis and revising completed scripts. You should already have a firm handle on screenwriting fundamentals, with multiple screenplays completed.

**How to join the Advanced Lab?**

* Please complete this sign-up form: [https://forms.gle/w9LJcwqD3MsbYBny5](https://forms.gle/w9LJcwqD3MsbYBny5)
* Then join us on Discord: [https://discord.gg/4Rfkv6MEJ8](https://discord.gg/4Rfkv6MEJ8)

If you have any questions or difficulty completing the form, contact [@fehabhab](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna) or [@nacho](https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna) on Discord or email [classes@scriptcamp.net](mailto:classes@scriptcamp.net)

title: Script Camp Writers Lab (Paid Class)
description:
The Script Camp Writers Lab is an intensive weekly script development session where Conor Kyle and other pro screenwriters are available to help you work through specific problems with your project.

Through one-on-one chats and group discussion, lab participants engage in a rigorous process that helps you get past whatever issues you encounter during the outlining and writing process.

How to join the Writers Lab:

• You can either purchase the session “a la carte”: https://scriptcamp.net/classes/
• Or start your free trial Unlimited Script Camp membership (US$49/month, includes over 60 hours of live classes, workshops and all the bootcamps every month, plus the weekly Writers Lab): https://scriptcamp.net/membership/
• Then hop on the Script Camp discord server, and get some help with your project: https://discord.gg/Qy3E35DZna
