group.name: Writing for the Soul of the World in London

title: Writing as a Sacred Act
description:
Join us for a conversation on “Writing as a Sacred Act” where we contemplate the questions:
• Where do stories come from? Do we choose them or do they find us?
• Do they spontaneously emerge from some Freudian memory scrap?
• Or, do they descend like angels from a Jungian archetypal kingdom?
• What’s the best way to begin a story?
• What’s the best strategy to overcome writer’s block?

Some stories taunt their writers with an irresistible idea then outright refuse to cooperate with the telling, leaving their writers completely in the dark as to how or where begin. Yet these rascally stories incessantly demand to be written. Other stories get rolling with great momentum only to abruptly abandon their writers leaving nothing behind but an unending, never diminishing, unrequited hope-against-hope of return.

In the great cave of the unconscious runs a gold vein of fables waiting to be mined by your daydreams and forged into shape through a fiery battle of ego and soul. Stories are “literary beings” that carry our knowledge and wisdom. They are as essential to our survival as food. The archetypal role of storyteller is a powerfully serious, ultimately sacred role. It is from stories that we form the phantom body of our collective identity, be it a small family or an entire people. Stories can spark new nations into manifesting, while carrying others into disillusionment and disintegration. The imagination of a single writer can carry millions of others to the glorious heights and devastating depths of human experience. Stories lull babies to happy sleep, send us chasing after love, or sometimes marching off to war. Stories show us where to find the courage to sacrifice our egos for the greater ecstasy of compassion. Stories not only inspire us, they are us.
Join us for an inspiring conversation.

group.name: Writing for the Soul of the World in London

title: Writing into Destiny: Do we write our stories or do they write themselves in us?
description:
In all the decades I’ve been teaching, I have yet to meet a writer whose story developed exactly as it was imagined at the start. Stories come to us one way, only to shift and morph inevitably into something entirely different with full maturity. Like parents holding a newborn child, we writers too have an overwhelming instinct to nurture our creation. And like parents, we too experience the anguishing reality that our vision for it is not its vision for itself. Stories are autonomous entities coming into the world bearing their own destiny regardless of what the writer might have wanted.
Our topic draws from Sigmund Freud's work in the personal unconscious, Carl Jung's work in the collective-unconscious, and Roberto Assagioli's work on the super-conscious, as well as a bold dive into straight up magic.
Join us for a short presentation and long conversation about the destiny of the writer’s story, as we contemplate to what degree the writer controls the story and to what degree the story controls the writer.

This is a Universal Grammar of Story Presentation based on the core book of the same name by Hazel Denhart. Free chapters are available from the publisher at www.InvisiblePress.com

1:00PM Central Time USA
2:00 PM Eastern Time USA

description:

Sign up through [Eventbrite](https://www.eventbrite.com/e/creativity-for-writers-finding-keeping-and-advancing-your-muse-tickets-318233604277?aff=ebdssbdestsearch) if you would like to make a small donation, or if you have difficulty signing on through the Zoom link below.

group.name: Writing for the Soul of the World in London

title: 1st Meeting!  Shepperton Wordsmiths Writers' Club
description:
I'm excited that so many people have signed up to Shepperton Wordsmiths even in advance of scheduling our first meeting! It's taken me longer than expected to make venue arrangements, but now we're all set.

The first meeting will be Tuesday, 15th January, at the Thames Court Pub on the Towpath at Shepperton, TW17 9LP. They've got a great room for us, just upstairs to the right as you come in, and they do nice food for those coming straight from work who want a bite to eat.

As it's our first meeting I expect the initial agenda to cover who we are and what we aspire to achieve together as a writers' group. I've some ideas, but I'm keen to hear what you think and the experiences you bring to the group. If you've participated in other writers' groups in the past, I'll want to learn what you liked and what you didn't like.

Anyone keen to read a piece of their own writing, please keep it to less than 5 minutes and drop me a message to let me know so I can plan for timings.

I'm looking forward to meeting you next Tuesday!

If you will have trouble getting to the Thames Court transport-wise, message me and I'll see what we can do.

£3 per person to cover the room charge.

Kind regards,

Kathleen Tyson
07554 348843

title: The Elements of Style and moving our work forward
description:
The image above is the bollard obstructing residents' parking at Shepperton Lock, and the inspiration for David's doggerel 'Wind Up The Bollard', our first reading last night at the Shepperton Wordsmiths Writers' Club. It will be published for everyone local to enjoy in the next issue of Shepperton Matters.

Our next meeting is Tuesday, 29th January, 7:30pm, also at the Thames Court Pub, Shepperton TW17 9LP, in the Upstairs Room.

We'll be discussing Strunk & White's 'Elements of Style', which I've uploaded to Google Drive: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1pEtKpQScdQuJt_s-z7wvWS2UdLDBNJcP

It's a short read that will instantly make you a better writer, as supported by Dorothy Parker:

"If you have any young friends that aspire to become writers,
the second greatest favour you can do for them is to present them
with copies of 'The Elements of Style'. The first greatest, of course,
is to shoot them now, while they're happy."

If you are coming by train or otherwise need a ride from High Street in Shepperton, message me as several people offered pick ups. I appreciate the Thames Court is a bit of hike in the winter dark from town centre, though it will be a lovely walk as the days lengthen and weather warms.

Kind regards,

Kathleen Tyson
07554 348 843

title: Self-Publishing Tutorial & Member Readings
description:
Another great meeting on Tuesday! We welcomed four new Members: Fiona, Guy, Sue, and Jerry. Note the Oxford or serial comma there.

Our discussion of 'The Elements of Style' quickly led to a debate on the Oxford comma, with the group about evenly split between those who favour the comma and those who don't see the point. That led to discussion of the correct use of fewer and less, and whether it was appropriate in writing dialogue to break the rules. Yeah, prob'ly. But we all agreed that verbising nouns is just wrong.

As we had new people we spent some time on introductions and sharing our ambitions for writing. We have four novels in progress, one possible novel or screenplay, a collection of anecdotes, poetry for performance, and short stories.

AGENDA for our next meeting is a tutorial on self-publishing software for creating photo or illustrated books, publishing on Amazon's KDP platform (both print and Kindle), and using self-publishing houses that provide formatting and editing services.

After that everyone will be invited to read about 5 minutes of their work so we get a sense of style from each other.

Cost £3 to cover the room, down to £2 if we are more than 10 people.

See you all on Tuesday, 12th February, 7:30 at the Thames Court!

Kind regards,

Kathleen
07554 348 843

A Fun TED Talk on the Oxford comma:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ptM7FzyjtRk

title: The 'Five Finger Pitch' & More Readings
description:
Another stunning meeting of Shepperton Wordsmiths on Tuesday night! We welcomed new member Paula. I'm immensely grateful to David for his preparation of a 'how to' guide on self-publishing on KDP/Amazon. He passed out also a list of websites that offer tutorials or 'how to' information, and as he is learning as he goes, proved that we can publish what we want to. Guy also shared his experience of using self-publishing services which format the content and prepare a cover for your book, but at a price. It was great to get a range of experience and encourage each other.

We finally got brave enough for readings! Most of us brought something we'd written, sometimes a while ago, to share.

Mike led with his children's story 'Bubble Trouble' which has been read on the radio. Jerry followed with his humorous verse parable 'The Well'. Rosina read some of her poetry evoking nature and a lullaby of sky and trees. Paula darkened the tone with the opening rape scene of her novel, 'Believe Me', which had me gripping the table and gasping at the power of it. Karen read some of her novel of Samoa, which features a family in conflict. David read us 'Sylvia's Letters', with its cruel twist in the final revelation. Guy read us a scene of Big Cat sightings from his sci-fi book. I read a bit of my satire on local current affairs, 'Buy-to-Let Borough Council'.

Chit chat afterward is that we all felt liberated to read to such a supportive group and grateful for the constructive feedback received.

AGENDA for the next meeting will be a screenwriting exercise called The Five-Fingered Pitch, which forces a focus on how to explain your work concisely to someone who can help you realise it with publication or production.

And then more readings, please!

And if you are enjoying our meetings please leave feedback as it encourages me and may bring others to join us.

title: Race Characterisation: From Dr Fu Manchu to Mama Ramotswe
description:
At our 26th February meeting we did the exercise of the 5 Finger Pitch, a concept developed for film pitches by Michael Lengsfield. You can have him teach you at FutureLearn: https://www.futurelearn.com/courses/screenwriting/0/steps/10488

The idea is that if writers meet a publisher or producer, and get the opportunity to pitch their work, they should pitch it in a concise and meaningful way that will engage commercial interest. Instead of describing plot points, which gets boring really fast even if the writing is terrific, they should describe their work in a more structured way. That sort of professionalism should invite a conversation about developing the work if the publisher or producer finds it interesting.

We then had more readings, which was really wonderful again. I'm inspired by everyone who brings their work to read to us! Karen read a thought-provoking piece based on her mother's death. Guy gave us the non-fiction complex politics of the 1960s Tory party. David read his twisty short story 'Abduction in Cremona'. Gerry gave us his comic verse 'The Husband Trap' - which we think should be published so it can be read out at weddings! Rosina, now in her 80s, read us her very first short story ever - written last week - 'Food for Thought', wonderful imagery ending with her rolling in snow under stars on the river bank. I read the opening paragraphs of my 'Godwin the Sea Lord' historical novel. Once again we were all joyful and admiring of the talent we each bring to our group.

Guy has suggested the topic for our next meeting be about whether depiction of race must change for modern readers. He wondered whether Dr Fu Manchu books could be written today. Certainly Sax Rohmer's Chinese evil genius was inspired by and catered to a culture of racism, isolationism and paranoia. Rohmer, who knew nothing of China, asked a ouija board for the most dangerous competitor to white man, and said the board spelled out C-H-I-N-A-M-A-N. The idea of the Yellow Peril was spreading in parallel with Asian economic development and rising educational attainments, and Dr Fu Manchu put a face - and a moustache - to the racist fear of the rising East, selling 20 million books.

Arguably James Bond books and movies sold by inflaming a similar fear of the Commie Threat during the Cold War, along with lovely travelogue locations.

In contrast a modern imagined race and place is the Botswana of Mma Precious Ramotswe, from the No 1 Ladies' Detective Agency series of 19 novels (so far) by Alexander McCall Smith. The author of this wildly popular series did live in Botswana for a time in his youth, so at least had some claim to understanding the place and people he imagined and shared with readers.

Are there limits to what authors could and should imagine or depict about race today? Is it wrong to inflame racist paranoia if it sells more books or cinema tickets?

And then the fun of more readings!

title: Orwell's Rules for Written English - and More Readings!
description:
Our discussion on Tuesday evening was on the tricky subject of racial characterisation. Guy had raised the topic with Dr Fu Manchu, who to him wasn't even intended as Chinese as the Manchus could pass for European (and the character in film was played by Christopher Leigh). To his thinking the character wasn't racist as Dr Fu Manchu had nobility; his ambition to rule the world was allowable because he would rule it better. Nonetheless the character was part of the 'Yellow Peril' and Commie scare-mongering of the mid-20th century. After a wide-ranging discussion of race characterisation - from Mma Ramotswe to Death in Paradise and beyond - we concluded that there weren't any fixed rules. Writers should develop characters of whatever complexion that are well-rounded, true to themselves, and true for the reader.

Then we got to the fun we are all now anticipating as the highlight of our meetings: the Readings! David read a short piece on how technology is driving us. Rosina read a poem that wonderfully creates the rhythm of an underground train as it captures a journey. Paula offered a fiction segment on interrogation of Nazis at Nuremberg. Mike read a synopsis of his sci-fi project which had us all begging for more. Guy entertained with his comic weighing of the advantages of chocolate versus sex and vice versa. Karen gave us more of her crazy family of sisters, whose contrasting characters complicate their reunion after mother's death. I read the next pages of my novel, when Godwin finds his own dead mother in the ruins of his burned down home.

AGENDA: Next meeting on 26th March I thought we might discuss George Orwell's Rules for Written English from 'Politics and the English Language'. The essay is well worth reading, but to make it easy for you I'll summarise here:
1. Never use a metaphor, simile, or other figure of speech which you are used to seeing in print.
2. Never use a long word where a short one will do.
3. If it is possible to cut a word out, always cut it out.
4. Never use the passive where you can use the active.
5. Never use a foreign phrase, a scientific word or a jargon word if you can think of an everyday English equivalent.
6. Break any of these rules sooner than say anything outright barbarous.

Full essay here: https://faculty.washington.edu/rsoder/EDLPS579/HonorsOrwellPoliticsEnglishLanguage.pdf

And, of course, more Readings!

title: Ready, Write, Action!  - And more readings!
description:
Apologies, Wordsmiths, that it has taken me so long to write up the last meeting and schedule the next through MeetUp. I've been away in deepest, darkest Devon - actually sea level and overwhelmingly white. I gained a new perspective on urban versus rural, and am a now more aware of the social divisions driving the disunity we see every day in national politics. Anyway, although Devon offered some entertainment, I'm glad to be back in 21st century multicultural Greater London.

Our 26th March meeting discussed Orwell's 6 rules for writing, which appear above. These were generally welcomed as reinforcing some of the good habits we've been exploring for clearer writing since the Shepperton Wordsmiths first met, and the flexibility implied by the last rule was encouraging. Several of us have been reviewing past writing from a perspective of these rules and those offered by Strunk & White's Elements of Style, and Stein on Writing, and have been improving our past work. All of us seem to have a bit more confidence and are enjoying our writing, especially now that we're sharing it with each other.

Not everyone came with a reading, not everyone has to! Those that did read for us offered a broad spectrum:
David gave us another of his short stories - this one with a cunning twist.
Gerry gave us one of his cabbie stories of 'big tipper' customers for 138 Portchester.
Guy took us from the past to the future and the future to the past until we became "strangers in our own era".
Karen read a prologue setting her characters in scene before they engage with each other in the story.
I read a bit more of Godwin the Sea Lord, where young Godwin anticipates his father's vengeance for the death of his mother, siblings, and the Combe bondsmen.

David has come up with the challenge for our next meeting, Tuesday 16th April, of writing a couple paragraphs each of action or conflict. That's easy for me with a cast of 11th century Vikings to write for!

If you want some ideas, check out this handy list of 50 action writing prompts: https://www.bryndonovan.com/2018/10/11/50-fight-scene-writing-prompts-and-ideas/

So, if you have time between now and Tuesday (and I apologise again for leaving this late) write up a short but nasty conflict or exciting action scene to share with your fellow Wordsmiths.

Kind regards,

Kathleen Tyson

title: Simile & Metaphor - And More Readings!
description:
Fantastic fun Wordsmiths meeting last night on Ready, Write, Action! For the first time there was still daylight when we met upstairs at the Thames Court. We welcomed new member Alison, who then rescued my reading from the Cloud with her IT help desk skills.

David had challenged us to write an action scene and most of us came prepared. Some of us reworked something we'd written earlier and others made up entirely new stories. The readings ranged from the hilariously comic to tense emotional confrontation to bloodthirsty knifing.

David read a teasing scene of film set mishaps descending seaward toward tragedy.
Gerry gave a hilarious account of 'The Humphrey Bogart' passenger he picked up - and pushed in - at Elephant & Castle in his cab.
Rosina combined the familiar waiting room of a garage with the Adults Only column of Exchange & Mart to surprising effect.
Paula gave us a taxi crash and tense dark impending threat that followed.
Karen read bitter recriminations and wounding words and blows between husband and wife from her novel.
Guy read a surprising reaction to litter in a Shepperton park in 'Bob and Yob' with a sting in it.
After some initial IT issues, I read young Godwin's vengeance against the first Saxon he meets after discovering his dead family.

David's challenge for our next meeting is use of simile and metaphor. Will we compose like Lord Byron or are we with Ogden Nash? I blaze with writing ambition like a Viking beacon!

Grammarly Tutorial: https://www.grammarly.com/blog/whats-the-difference-between-a-simile-and-a-metaphor/

VERY LIKE A WHALE by Ogden Nash

One thing that literature would be greatly the better for
Would be a more restricted employment by authors of simile and
metaphor.
Authors of all races, be they Greeks, Romans, Teutons or Celts,
Can't seem just to say that anything is the thing it is but have to
go out of their way to say that it is like something else.
What does it mean when we are told
That that Assyrian came down like a wolf on the fold?
In the first place, George Gordon Byron had enough experience
To know that it probably wasn't just one Assyrian, it was a lot of
Assyrians.
However, as too many arguments are apt to induce apoplexy and
thus hinder longevity,
We'll let it pass as one Assyrian for the sake of brevity.
Now then, this particular Assyrian, the one whose cohorts were
gleaming in purple and gold,
Just what does the poet mean when he says he came down like a
wolf on the fold?
In heaven and earth more than is dreamed of in our philosophy
there are great many things.
But I don't imagine that among them there is a wolf with purple
and gold cohorts or purple and gold anythings.
No, no, Lord Byron, before I'll believe that this Assyrian was
actually like a wolf I must have some kind of proof.
Did he run on all fours and did he have a hairy tail and a big red
mouth and big white teeth and did he say Woof Woof?
Frankly I think it is very unlikely, and all you were entitled to say,
at the very most,
Was that the Assyrian cohorts came down like a lot of Assyrian
cohorts about to destroy the Hebrew host.
But that wasn't fancy enough for Lord Byron, oh dear me no, he
had to invent a lot of figures of speech and then interpolate them,
With the result that whenever you mention Old Testament soldiers
to people they say Oh yes, they're the ones that a lot of
wolves dressed up in gold and purple ate them.
That's the kind of thing that's being done all the time by poets,
from Homer to Tennyson;
They're always comparing ladies to lilies and veal to venison,
And they always say things like that the snow is a white blanket
after a winter storm.
Oh it is, is it? All right then, you sleep under a six-inch blanket of
snow and I'll sleep under a half-inch blanket of unpoetical
blanket material and we'll see which one keeps warm.
And after that maybe you'll begin to comprehend dimly
What I mean by too much metaphor and simile.

title: Show, Don't Tell . . . Description, Narrative Summary & Immediate Scene
description:
First, many thanks to Paul and the team at the Thames Court Pub for giving us such a great meeting venue. As the weather warms and the evenings lengthen, Paul has assured me that Shepperton Wordsmiths can continue to use the upstairs room on alternate Tuesdays into the summer.

Last Tuesday, keeping to David's challenge, we offered pieces of writing composed as or with simile or metaphor. I opened with "Moon River", an account of the final song and final days of a neighbour who passed away recently. David kept the fatal theme but lightened the tone considerably with his story recounting a series of hilarious crematorium mishaps. Guy kept the dark comedy going with a reading from his book Tapestry: "You're fired." Karen took us deep into her wardrobe and the magic of memory we all experience when viewing or touching something we rarely wear but can't discard. Paula gave us a pacy account of middle-age marathon running inspired by new running shoes. Gerry took us on a joyous taxi ride from The Westbury Hotel to The Cumberland Hotel with a working girl who claimed it was "the ride of her life." Rosina entertained us with Hoover, the aptly-named dog who eats everything. Mike enchanted us with a tour through London that snaked along a surprising yet familiar route.

David then challenged us to count similes and metaphors in a "trivial piece of nonsense" he wrote while not writing what he intended (Guy and I counted 21).

NEXT MEETING:

As an exercise for the next meeting I thought we might each try to frame an idea in three different ways to demonstrate the power of showing rather than telling. When I first showed my fiction writing to another author a few years back, he immediately handed it back and said, “Show, don’t tell.” Ouch!

What he meant was that I lost him as a reader by starting my book with a detailed background explanation rather than bringing the detail out as action or dialogue driving a story with characters that drew him into the scene.

From p. 43 of author and editor Sol Stein's "Stein On Writing":
_____________________
Description is a depiction of a locale or person. The Latin root of the word "depiction," pingere, means "to picture" or to fashion a visual image.

Narrative Summary is the recounting of what happens offstage, out of the reader's sight and hearing, a scene is told rather than shown.

An Immediate Scene happens in front of the reader, is visible, and therefore filmable. That's an important test. If you can't film a scene, it is not immediate. Theatre, a truly durable art, consists almost entirely of immediate scenes.

Just as every form of writing that is expected to be read with pleasure moves away from abstraction, every form of pleasurable writing benefits from conveying as much as possible before the eye, onstage rather than offstage.
_______________________

Either working with a scene you’ve already written, or with a new idea for a scene, just try writing it in alternative versions, as a Description, then as a Narrative Summary, then as an Immediate Scene. Now that I know the difference, I try to drive my stories through the power of Immediate Scenes, keeping the reader engaged even if they don’t always have a complete grasp of all the detailed background and context I might think important. As Rosina commented during discussion, "The curious card is the one you cannot see." Authors always know more than readers; so long as there is action and pace, a few curious gaps will be forgiven sooner than too much descriptive detail.

I've put a couple "Show, Don't Tell" worksheets online: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1pEtKpQScdQuJt_s-z7wvWS2UdLDBNJcP?usp=sharing

title: A Burned Book in My Garden - And More Readings
description:
The exercise for our last meeting was to write the same scene from three different perspectives: description, narrative, and immediate scene. David found this one challenging, but eventually started on it by imagining an oil painting depicting a cruel sea captain, then narrated the same scene from the perspective of a crewman, then made the scene come alive with immediacy as the cruel captain ordered a flogged seaman dragged to him while his mates were ordered to trim the sails. I followed by prosaicly describing a sunning cat, narrating its leap to a lock gate, and then showing its outstretched claws digging into the hot, sun-baked black paint as it stretched its length along the arm of the gate to take in the heat. Paula gave us an escalating intensity account of limping into a convenience store to find herself painfully obstructed and delayed by a scratch-card customer at the till. Mike also read us a piece, but it must have been so enthralling that I forgot to take notes!

Not each of us writes these exercises, and that's just fine. There are no rules. Nothing is obligatory. No one gets graded. I find doing the exercises makes me more conscious of alternative choices I make when I'm writing, which hopefully makes my writing more powerful over time. Some Wordsmiths choose not to do them. It's always your choice.

We welcomed Mandy and Judy as 1st timers in the Wordsmiths, and hope they'll come again.

Moving on to readings, Jerry applied his 6th sense of reading characters from the drivers' seat of his cab to recount the antics of a purse-pinching cheapskate. Guy rounded off our readings with an excerpt from his account of a convert terrorist driven by disillusionment and an emptiness of motivation and meaning in his life. I read a bit more of my Viking saga, as they torched a chapel before fleeing by boat.

AGENDA: I hadn't come up with an exercise for the next meeting by the time we adjourned, but serendipity has solved my problem. This morning I found a single page from a book burned around all four edges on my garden path. As we've recently lost two houses to fire just up the island, it's probably blown over from one of them. I thought as an exercise we could take the scene from the singed page as a starting point, and each write a further paragraph or two filling out the scene or what happened after. The margin on the right is burned off, so you'll have to fill in a few words. The page is the featured picture above.

After we read our expansions on the fragment, we'll move on to our own readings as usual.

title: Exploring the Wild West - and more Readings
description:
The Burned Book exercise we wrote for the last meeting was extremely telling about the different approaches we take as members of the group, and revealed a surprise gender divide. The fragment which each writer keyed off to extend the story had a man and woman separating after she dropped him at his car. The first two continuations, by David and Jerry, both involved car chases and violent crashes. The continuations by Karen, Paula and me explored the emotions of lust, guilt and shame hinted at by the woman. Maybe the perfect novel would combine them!

Mike didn't make it to this meeting, but did write the Burning Book exercise so might read it next time. He also asked to read ours. I offered to email our exercises to him, but it's probably simpler to just bring your printed Burned Book story to give him at the next meeting.

Following on, Guy read an extract from his non-fiction essay on American identity, settlement, and geographic expansion. We don't read much non-fiction, but as I write more history than fiction, I think it's okay to mix it up if that's what we write.

Guy's excerpt led to a discussion that ranged about a bit, ending when Linda suggested that for the next meeting we write something brief on the theme of the Wild West. She's a big fan of the old classic movies when good guys wore white hats and shot straight, and bad guys always got their comeuppance.

So that's the plan, and I'm up for it. If you feel inspired, write something short from the Wild West genre. The picture above is me and my sons at Delicate Arch in Arches National Park near Moab, Utah. My dad took us on camping holidays in the high dessert every other year when I was growing up, and I love the landscape as much as the narratives of pilgrim settlement and cowboys & indians. The picture above is from the first Western holiday with my dad and boys in 2004. John Wayne liked the scenery so much he bought himself a ranch on the Colorado River just outside Moab.

We continued the readings with a fragment I've written that will go somewhere in my Godwin novel called 'Soulseer', when Godwin captures and enslaves a Saxon noblewoman on the shores of the combe taken from him as a boy. Gerry followed that with a New Year's Eve story from the driver's seat of his cab, and a particularly unwelcome demand for a kiss from a drunken fare. David gave us a ghostly ambition to spread spookiness on social media. And Mandy rounded off the readings with a heart-rending introduction to Phoebe the Dog, the adventurous hero of her childrens' books. Delightful!

Giddyup, partners! Join us upstairs in the Thames Court Saloon when we take aim at the Wild West next time.

title: Self-Publishing KDP Tutorial and Readings!
description:
The speed at which time elapses is accelerating as the year progresses! Apologies for not getting this invitation up sooner, but the past 10 days have sped by in a blur. The Wild West exercise at the last meeting was an amazing success. David gave us a brave sherriff and boy challenging Black Jack at the saloon. Karen had us making a paper headdress and playing cowboys and indians in the garden, but "being a girl, I had to be rescued a lot". Guy raised the tone with a history of American expansion and imperialism, displacing and dispossessing Native Americans. I read a little piece about a cowboy trapped by bad guys up an arroyo. Paula gave us an insight into her family history, as her Uncle Joe settled on an Indian reservation in New Mexico as a clerk and met a bad end after challenging the systematic oppression and corruption of the government. Mike took us on air with Country 1035AM, stetsons, line dancing, and the ambitions of young Susie & Johnny to open a themed restaurant. Gerry gave us a humerous parable about Old Sam and his horse. Mike then rounded this off with a reversion to our previous exercise, reading his expansion on the burned book fragment to take it to a dark place and explosive ending.

We agreed next Tuesday we'll try to have a tutorial on KDP self-publishing if we can get the technology to work. Either David or I will have our laptop there to get online, project to the film screen, and walk you through how KDP organises itself to let you publish your work as a printed book.

title: 107 Ironclad Rules for Writing & More Wordsmith Readings
description:
Last meeting we welcomed Peter to his first meeting, and were glad to see Mandy return too. The demo of KDP Self-Publishing went pretty well, followed by Readings from Karen, Jerry, Rosina and David. Karen shared her impressions of 1989 pre-supression Tiananmen Square. Jerry gave us another comic spin in his cab as he stalked fares during a slowdown in trade. Rosina livened up the Shepperton Village Fair with cowboys and magic. David spooked us with the potential for characters to migrate from our imaginations to our dreams to controlling and destroying our lives. Yikes!

We've had ongoing discussion in the Wordsmiths about whether writers need to follow rules, some rules, no rules, all the time, some of the time, when they feel like it, only after the 2nd G&T, on alternate Saturdays, etc.

Just for fun I'm going to point you this week at Tom McAllister's '107 Ironclad Rules for Writers Who Want to Be Better at Writing': http://www.tom.mcallister.ws/blog/2016/6/19/107-ironclad-rules-for-writers-who-want-to-be-better-at-writing

These rules are mostly silly, but I found them funny and often thought-provoking. Tom says, "My whole teaching philosophy is built around giving accidentally good advice between making bad jokes."

Anyway, if you want an assignment for next Tuesday's MeetUp then pick three of these Rules and tell us why we should follow them, not follow them, or at least think about them.

For example, "Rule 79. Never kill a dog in your book. The dogs will know." What about cats? Cats rule the Internet! When the 21st century is looked back on 1000 years from now, humans will be seen as cat worshippers and cat-servants. Therefore it must be more important not to offend cats. They will probably rule the society that writes about the past in the future.

And then more Readings!

Unless I hear otherwise from you I'll book the British Library outing for the Making Your Mark Exhibition on writing for Tuesday, 23rd July, late morning (11:00-ish). If there is a rail strike I can drive us in and park just a block from the Library in a private lot I have liberty to use. Please confirm if you want a ticket as I'll try to get a group rate.

title: Plot Development - And More Readings
description:
We started the last meeting of Wordsmiths by celebrating the publication of two books by our authors: 'Believe Me' by Paula and 'The Kambatan' by Guy. Well done!

We also welcomed Dan to his first meeting.

Karen told the Group about the Curtis Brown 1st Novel Prize which is open for entries of 1st novels until noon on 1st August. Submission requires a 10,000 words of your book and a 400 word synopsis. Even if you don't think you'll win, it might be a good exercise for novelists to read the requirements for this publisher and try to write a synopsis to their recommendations. Details are here: https://www.curtisbrowncreative.co.uk/first-novel-prize/

We then discussed Tom McAllister's '107 Ironclad Rules for Writers Who Want to Be Better at Writing': http://www.tom.mcallister.ws/blog/2016/6/19/107-ironclad-rules-for-writers-who-want-to-be-better-at-writing. These are tongue-in-cheek rules, but they made us think a bit.

Mandy offered her own rule: 'Create your characters and then let them loose. Don't keep them on a short leash.' A good rule for an author who relies on her dog Phoebe getting into new scrapes for her stories!

For the next meeting, I thought we'd go back to craft and discuss plot. Above is a photo I took of a poster at Shepperton Studios Career Fair on Thursday from someone who advises on plot development for film scripts. I thought it might be useful to the Worsmiths. I can only display part of the photo in the header for MeetUp but the whole photo and complete list are on the Wordsmith G-Drive. I've also put there Guy's list of 'Some Tips for Aspiring Writers'. Everything is here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1pEtKpQScdQuJt_s-z7wvWS2UdLDBNJcP

5 Wordsmiths said they wanted to joint the British Library outing on 23rd July for the 'Making Your Mark' exhibition. Full price tickets are £14 and senior tickets are £12. If we go for 11:30 train entry we might be able to get Super Off-Peak fares at Shepperton Station and save a bit on train travel. I'll confirm arrangements and bookings on Tuesday with those going, or email me if you are missing the meeting Tuesday.

That should be enough to start conversation before Readings. See you then!

title: British Library:  Making Your Mark Exhibition
description:
We'll be taking our first Wordsmiths expedition next Tuesday, 23rd July, to the British Library for the Writing: Making Your Mark exhibition. Let's meet at 10:00 at Shepperton Station to get the 10:11 train.

Full description and booking options here: https://www.bl.uk/events/writing-making-your-mark

You can save 10 per cent by booking online using the promo code WRITING10. Otherwise we'll buy tickets when we get there as I've checked and availability is good. Book the 11:30 time slot as the 10:11 train from Shepperton should get us to Kings Cross just about on time, changing at Vauxhall for Victoria Line.

We'll likely have lunch at the BL cafe, although there are many good places nearby to explore and forage at lunchtime too.

There is a 1 hour public tour of the British Library at 2:00pm for those who want more, cost £10.

Alternatively I can take you to visit Saint Pancras Boat Basin and the Victorian Waterpoint that are just up the road. The commodore of St Pancras Cruising Club and will meet us there to open up the Waterpoint and its amazing rooftop view over London.

That will conclude our organised expedition, so you can make your own plans to shop, explore London, or wend your way back home.

There is usually good parking for Shepperton Station nearby on adjacent streets if you are driving to join us. There are no charges or parking restrictions for street parking.

Please email me whether you are coming with a mobile phone number for coordination on the day. Email is shepperton.wordsmith@gmail.com

title: Formatting for Editors - And More Readings!
description:
We were a select group of just five Wordsmiths at the 16 July meeting, but David said afterwards that it was one of the 'best ever'. We did have a very good discussion of plot development and characterisation. And then when we gave our readings there was more careful analysis and structured critique, which each of us found useful.

I decided to submit 'Godwin the Sealord' to the Curtis Brown first novel competition that Karen brought to our attention, so I read my 400 word summary. Guy, David and Mandy made some very good plotting suggestions which I'm integrating into the revised summary.
https://www.curtisbrowncreative.co.uk/first-novel-prize/

For the pre-meeting exercise on Tuesday I recommend you read a blogpost from 2013 by Arlene Prunkl on 'How to professionally format your manuscript for editors, agents, and publishers'. It taught me very many things I did not know. I'm using it to format Godwin now.
http://penultimateword.com/editing-blogs/how-to-professionally-format-your-manuscript-for-editors-agents-publishers/

David and Rosina have also invited a neighbour of ours to Wordsmiths who has just had her first novel published and distributed throughout the UK. It has already sold out in Waterstones and WH Smiths! Congratulations, Elizabeth! We hope she joins us.

Karen, Guy and I went to the British Library on Tuesday for the 'Making Your Mark' exhibition. No doubt we'll tell you about that too.

See you Tuesday!

title: Ghost stories . . . And other readings
description:
We had an exciting meeting of Wordsmiths on 30th July, welcoming a neighbour from the Island who has published a best seller first novel this summer and just submitted a sequel for publication next year. Elizabeth started her career in acting, and from what she said the ability to write to order and take direction from her agent and publisher were very important to her success. Acting also gave her an ear for dialogue. Her novel 'Liverpool Girl' has already sold out at Waterstones and WH Smith, and has 5 stars on Amazon.co.uk. Rosina has read it already and says it kicks along at a great pace - 'a real page-turner'.
https://www.amazon.co.uk/Liverpool-Girl-Elizabeth-Morton/dp/1529103525/

I've always leaned toward the view that although writing is a solitary pursuit getting published requires acts of collective will and collaboration. Elizabeth originally won a short story contest with the premise of her novel, and then rewrote it as a longer book at the suggestion of an agent at the award ceremony. Her agent then asked her to set it in the 1950s instead of the 1970s as more commercially marketable. The publisher then gave it a slant toward 'Call the Midwife' and put a baby on the cover, though there is no baby in the book. When Elizabeth queried this - mind you, not objecting - she was told "babies sell better than bumps". Publishers know their market! Her advice to us is to go along with advice you're given so as not to be seen as precious and difficult to work with.

Importantly, Elizabeth made it clear she was not an overnight success. She has been writing for television and submitting short stories to contests for decades. Her success comes after a lot of hard work and determination, and even some discouragement. Well done!

In member readings Gerry gave us an unusally saucy account of a pick up from a club near Smithfield Market, Guy gave us a retrospective assessment of US presidents Nixon, Carter and Reagan, and Karen a lovely, evocative jazz session in a smoke-filled grass hut with Pepe's paella on Timpana Island.

For Tuesday, if you're up for a spooky challenge, Guy suggested we write ghost stories. David has the advantage of us here, as he writes ghost stories quite a bit already, but the rest of us might try our hands - or keyboards - at something ethereal from the other light.

title: KDP Cover Making - And more readings
description:
What an amazing meeting we had 13th August on 'Ghost Stories'! Eight Wordsmiths brough ghost stories they had composed on the theme, and Guy - who proposed the theme - will read his at the next meeting.

We started the meeting with a bit of improvised comedy that neighbour Gordon from the Island wanted to try out. We gave him our feedback and learned some lessons ourselves about the importance of projection, timing and comedic effect.

Then we read our marvellous ghost stories. David gave us a pickpocket in purgatory. Gerry's taxi was hailed by a spirit to pick up his widow from her annual trip to a medium at the Spiritualist Society. Mandy gave us a shooting at Berkeley Hall. I infused my plum jam with a little spirit. Rosina revived her magician in a new story, evoking the scent of 'mown grass, mint and wild thyme'. Mike's silent oarsman rowed passengers Ross and McPherson across a misty river, but only one arrived on the opposite shore. Karen brought the spirit of RLS down the mountain path from his graveside on Mount Vaea to the home he once rented. Each story was different and quite wonderful. I'm proud of us all for rising to the challenge!

Next Tuesday we'll be treated to another performance as Paula and David will read Paula's Trotsky play.

Then we'll have another KDP tutorial, this time on uploading covers for KDP published books either as paperbacks or as kindle ebooks.

Then, of course, more readings from the works that each of us is pushing forward with this summer.

Finally, I'm illustrating this invitation with a 1945 Dorothy Parker telegram published this week by Nicholas Thompson, editor of my favourite magazine Wired. It proves that even the wittiest and best writers can stumble and lose spirit from time to time. At least with Wordsmiths we have each other to cheer us up and cheer us on.

title: Cats! and more Readings
description:
We started our last meeting with a discussion of how covers can be created in KDP for self-published books and ebooks. While we weren't able to help Karen with all her technical challenges, we were successful in in finding a potential title for her biofiction about Robert Louis Stevenson from one of his quotes: "Life is not a matter of holding good cards, but of playing a poor hand well." This echoes a lot of the drama from her book, so maybe 'Playing A Poor Hand Well' will be her title.

We were next treated to Guy's ghost story. It was an evocative piece, telling of curiousity, temptation, restraint, capitulation, copulation, and then fear. Poor Adam!

Next Paula and David did a staged reading of her short play evoking the ghost of Leon Trotsky in 1941, a year after his Murder in Mexico City. It was a problematic piece, projecting onto a man who rejected identity as a Jew an urgent obligation to write in defence of Jews as if his posthumous acceptance of the obligation half a world away would have mattered. He says, "Jew is not a category I recognise," but is hounded to reconsider. When he capitulates he is told he is "too late, homeless and hopeless".

Mandy told us about the Phoebe story she is working on next, when the adventurous pup saves Wimbledon.

As I write this my familiar Leia is curled on my lap with her chin resting on the desk below the keyboard. That's appropriate since the theme for our next exercise, for those who wish, will be cats. Unfortunately, I will be at a dinner in Westminster with the editor of the Financial Times, so David will deputise. Have fun all! Here, kitty, kitty . . .

Tim Berners Lee on the 25th anniversary of the internet: "I never expected all these cats."

title: Busting Stereotypes - And other readings
description:
MANY THANKS TO DAVID FOR HOSTING LAST WEEK'S MEETING AND THE NOTES BELOW!

The numbers were a little down at this meet due to members’ other commitments, but nevertheless those present enjoyed a lively time.

David read his “cats” homework piece “My Friend Apophis” which was held to be a little too obscure and he received some useful feedback on where in the story some clarification would be useful.

No other “homework” pieces were forthcoming!

Our discussions then took a more philosophical turn following Guys reading of his new work “Wisdom”, a guide to living well and at peace with your fellows.

Karen showed us the drafts of the front and back covers of her forthcoming book “Chances mean Choices” about Robert Louis Stevenson and this gave rise to some suggestions about the proposed front cover typeface and back cover summary.

We discussed attending book festivals and finding useful websites and Karen told us about a website https://www.pinterest.co.uk/ where she had registered and through which she now receives two or so emails every week containing information applicable to authors and writers.

Amanda told us that in her books about the young bitch Phoebe she is going to scramble the spelling (and hence) pronunciation of some words, which will both help identify the speaker as Phoebe and hopefully amuse the reader.

David challenged the notion that one should never use Stereotypes in one’s fictional work and the group discussed this. Four instances were identified in which a stereotype can be employed to useful effect.

And so that takes us to the (purely optional) homework which has been set as “a short story that invokes a stereotype and then unexpectedly blasts it to bits”.

Happy writing!

title: The Economics of Being an Author
description:
We started the meeting on 24/09 with reviewing alternative cover designs for Karen's biofiction novel on Robert Louis Stevenson. She's changed the title again and had various alternative covers, some busy, some plain. What came through in the discussion was the importance of clear text and fonts, especially if there is a complex background image. It also matters who you are targeting as readers, men or women, in designing the cover.

We went on to the exercise of sterotype busting. Some sterotyping is useful if you think it will help the reader move along with the story, but the risk is profiling that is unnecessary and does not progress the plot. Karen gave us a short story in Eden where Eve is dynamic, brave and embraces her sexuality while Adam is timid, shy and threatened. Lovely! Guy gave us the cat Asterix who was a part of his family for more than 15 years, ceding place to successors Hannah and Brodie. Mandy gave us an gentle and delightful story of a career woman in London misjudging a homeless man. My favourite line: "I think you are still everything you used to be." Rosina rounded off the stories with 'Sweetie the Lap Cat'.

We agreed the topic for discussion next Tuesday could be marketing a self-published book, but since that is exactly what I'll be doing I won't be with you. I'm giving my talk on '1066: The Siege, Surrender and Triumph of London' to the London & Middlesex Archaeological Society at the Clore Centre, Museum of London, 150 London Wall, London EC2Y 5HN, 6pm for 6:30 talk. Cost £3 if you would like to come along. I'll be flogging the book after the event.

David will deputise again with Wordsmiths on Tuesday. He'd like to start with the Radio 4 Money Box show from February 'The economics of being an author'. He will play the recording downloaded to prompt the discussion afterwards.

And then more readings from those who have them! Have fun and wish me luck!

title: Childhood stories . . . And other readings, too
description:
To start the 8th October meeting we listened to a BBC Moneybox phone-in programme entitled “The Economics of being an Author” which featured a panel comprising a literary agent and some fulltime authors who shared their experiences. The resulting discussion covered such topics as transiting from other, fulltime paid work to writing as a career, earnings levels, the value of using a literary agent, self-publishing, audiobooks and unbound.com (a crowdfunding publisher).

Following this we discussed the necessity and methods of marketing one’s own self-published work and the desirability of using one or more of Instagram, Facebook and Twitter et al as major components in the marketing mix. There emerged a distinct lack of enthusiasm about such use and the general view about these applications was that whilst they appeared to be necessary for promoting one’s work they should be employed with full awareness and a degree of caution.

Gerry then read us a memoir which featured a male passenger with a very rude and superior manner and accompanied by a lady whom he was most probably trying to impress demanding to be taken to the Savoy. As we know London cabbies are renowned for their wit and Gerry’s immediate and questioning riposte, delivered with both courtesy and wit was nevertheless sufficient to have the lady laugh out loud whilst at the same time delivering a portion of humiliation to her unpleasant partner. The journey terminated at the Savoy and as might be expected Gerry only received the “Legal” (metered) recompense for the trip and was no doubt only too happy to be denied the customary tip in this instance. Thus we are reminded that we reap what we sow!

Guy then read an extract from his book “The Bigger Picture” which argues that there is a fundamental truth about the nature of things and an interplay between them. Climatic conditions and events in history (environmental disasters, wars, the industrial revolution, the reformation, for example) are bound by nexus and a change in one condition will instigate change in others and in that way affect decision making and the direction of the development of civilisations.

For those interested in doing some homework before our next meeting the topic suggested by Mandy and approved by the assembly was “Childhood” and so stories must include a child, but they can of course be autobiographical, semi-autobiographical or pure fiction.

As David has deputised for Kathleen as host twice now, he's been added as a host also to the MeetUp group, enabling him to administer the webgroup.

title: Literary Festivals, and More Readings . . .
description:
Apologies for getting this invite up so late, but we will meet as usual next Tuesday at the Thames Court. Our last meeting was small but great fun. It was just David, Rosina, Mandy and me, but we were all in a sociable mood and delighted to hear Mandy's account of the Bath Literary Festival.

I thought Festivals would be a good topic to discuss on Tuesday. They can certainly be a great source for candid feedback, advice about agents, and inspiration to get on with your writing. I've been to a writers' festival at Leeds and Mandy has just been to Bath. I'll do a little prep work on what goes on at festivals and how you can make the most of them as an aspiring author.

I'll also bring a list of literary festivals and dates for 2020. The 2019 season is just ending this week, so we should be looking ahead. Perhaps we will find a festival that a few of us want to go to together next year and we can organise a bit to get ourselves and our writing ready in advance.

One of the many things I'm proud of with Shepperton Wordsmiths is how we have begun to collaborate and help each other, beyond the meetings. Very little in life of any importance is achieved by solitary effort. A little teamwork and practical support can go a long way in giving each other confidence and enthusiasm.

As it will be Bonfire Night, perhaps we will see some fireworks from our room upstairs at the Thames Court!

title: How to get the most out of a Literary Festival . . And Readings
description:
At the 5th November meeting we enjoyed some very nearby fireworks, seemingly a fusillade directed at the Thames Court, and a lively discussion of the calendar of UK literary festivals which extends from June to November. After reviewing the list of top UK festivals near and far, we agreed that we might try to go to the Cliveden Literary Festival in 2020. Cliveden is fairly near so we wouldn't need hotels (20 miles from Shepperton) and the festival offers a broad scope. I've registered our interest with the organisers and will follow up with the Wordsmiths when the dates are announced and as the 2020 agenda fills out.

The 2019 Cliveden Literary Festival was a good mix of the types of writing we do in Shepperton Wordsmiths: Novels, Poetry, History, Politics, War and Spies. No children's topics this year, but perhaps there will be next year.
http://clivedenliteraryfestival.org/programme/

Since Mandy and I have each found festivals motivating and inspiring, I thought we might discuss at the next meeting Tuesday, 19th November, how to get the most out of the festival experience. Usually there are chances for writing clinics, meetings with agents and editors, and other opportunities to get helpful feedback on your work, but you get the most profit from these if you prepare before the event. I'll try to have a word with the organisers on how best to prepare for Cliveden so we can discuss it Tuesday evening. Mandy can supplement with insights from her experience at the Bath Children's Literary Festival.

For readings at the last meeting Guy asked for feedback on his brief history of the founding of Israel. He regretted Paula wasn't there for insight. I read the first few pages of a novel I started in 2013 - a narrowboat thriller intended to be pacy at 4 miles per hour. I'll read a bit more next time too.

title: Three Red Flags for Agents . . . And More Readings
description:
Another small but fun meeting of Wordsmiths on Tuesday. Attending were Mandy, David and Karen. Following up on the previous meeting, when we decided we might try the Clivedon Literary Festival in 2020, I reported on my contact with the organisers. Unlike the writers' festivals that I attended in York and Mandy attended in Guildford, Clivedon offers no workshops, no tutorials, no one-on-one with author or agents, and is limited in its agenda to famous authors talking to the audience from the stage. This doesn't really fit with the Wordsmith ethos. Instead I researched other options.

Instead of Clivedon I put forward that we might attend the National Association of Writers' Groups (NAWG) Festival 2020.

The 2020 programme is not online yet, but the 2019 agenda remains up for review. It includes speakers, workshops, themed seminars, and meetings with agents and publishers. Also, it is much more broadly scoped to embrace travel writing, poetry, crime fiction, romantic novels, etc. I have subscribed to the mailing list and will keep you all updated as more information comes through.

https://www.nawg.co.uk/nawgfest-2019

Karen elaborated on her own travel writing ambitions, regaling us with an account of her participation in a Tahitian beer night ritual which was sort of oriented to 'last man standing'.

No one else had brought readings so I read the opening of Safari Club again, as none of the the three had been at the previous meeting. That brings everyone up to the same point if I continue the work going forward.

For the next meeting there is interest in finding a way to do some chained collaborative writing, passing a work forward through the group from some starting point, to see where it ends up after serial contributions. This might be done through Google Drive, but not everyone has a gmail account so we'll have to discuss it more for practicalities.

As an opening topic for the Wordsmiths' next meeting, I thought I would introduce a short work from Autocrit (an online editing application available by free subscription for now) on Three Red Flags that often mean failure with agents. The lessons are short and to the point, and I found them helpful.

I've uploaded a PDF to the Google Drive using the following link:
https://drive.google.com/open?id=1yJxg2evlFt5BzBtRjbQI2P0D7Yn2n7hk

And bring some Readings!

title: Seasonal Celebration and Stories with Nibbles!
description:
We had another smallish but productive meeting on 3rd December, welcoming new Wordsmith David. David is another writer of biofiction. He shared an app for organising a draft manuscript which intrigued us all. I couldn't find it later in the Apple App store so will need to follow up to provide a link.

I've registered our interest in going to the 2020 National Association of Writers' Groups Festival (NAWG Fest) and will keep you posted as I hear from the organisers.

I read some more of my narrowboat thriller. Otherwise we had a free-flowing and fun conversation.

Our next event is a special Seasonal Celebration on Hamhaugh Island. To save the risk of losing anyone in the dark, David will collect such Wordsmiths as attend from elsewhere at the Thames Court Pub at 7:15 and guide them to the party. Be prompt if you want his guidance.
Bring nibbles and a bottle of what you fancy.

If you come later, call me on 07554 348843 and we'll describe the way to the Island, across the lock gate, across the weir bridge, down past the Green, along the path to a break in the hedge . . . You may want a torch.

Rosina has asked everyone to bring a seasonal story to read for our entertainment.

If we don't see you Tuesday, have lovely holidays. Wordsmiths will welcome you back with new writing resolutions in 2020.

title: 2020 Visionaries!
description:
It's 2020 and a whole new year lies ahead of us to get on with writing more great stories and other stuff. I used the holidays to crank out 25 pages on global financial stability reform, which I will NOT be reading to the Wordsmiths as it is for a very niche audience.

Thanks again to Rosina for hosting our first Christmas Party at Toad Hall. Quite a few of us showed up and all but two had written Christmas ghost stories to share. They were so amazing I was captivated. I didn't even take notes, except for Rosina's story which came first. As usual she engages our imaginary senses with oozing mud, a wood fire, howling winds, and glowing eyes, before carrying the story of Mad Cat and Dog to its eerie conclusion at Shepperton Lock.

New Wordsmith David has volunteered to come up with an excercise for our first meeting of 2020, so kudos to him for stepping forward! I'm always grateful for help and ideas.

Also, we've been invited to write about 300 words for Shepperton News about Wordsmiths to gen up some new members. Have a think about what that might look like for discussion on Tuesday. And if Wordsmiths want to contribute short stories for the neighbourhood to enjoy, the editor would welcome more regular contributions.

Hoping you all had lovely holidays and wishing you literary productivity to share with us in 2020!

title: Critiquing our work . . . And more readings
description:
Entering into our second year, Shepperton Wordsmiths has so much to be proud of. I'm going to reflect a little before setting the course for our next meeting. And I'm also going to use a new picture of the Thames Court Pub that captures my optimism about the coming year, taken when the Thames was at flood last month.

We've all learned a bit and honed the craft of writing, editing, and publishing together over the year. We've shared toil, visions, insights, tips, fun, and generally been friendly and supportive. If there have been disagreements, they have been good natured and addressed with tolerance and respect.

And we have accomplishments! Guy has published two books, 'The Kambatan Assignment' (June 2019) and 'Facing the End: Why it is not crazy to believe the Second Coming is imminent' (November 2019).
https://www.amazon.co.uk/s?k=guy+blythman
Karen has published her biofiction of Robert Louis Stevenson as 'The Love Affair' (December 2019). As Karen told us on 7th January holding the hardcopy proudly, "I couldn't have done it without Shepperton Wordsmiths; it would still be sitting in a drawer."
https://www.amazon.co.uk/Love-Affair-karen-steele/dp/1695574710/
Well done, both of you!

I failed my own objective of finishing my novel, but I've had fun along the way. A little failure is good for the soul, endowing humility and deeper appreciation of others' achievements. I've written lots of good stuff in 2019, some of it published, some not, some for work, some for fun, but all of it better for the lessons we've learned together.

At the last meeting we did two exercises proposed by new member David-2, as I think of him. The first was a scene-setting view of a seaside town that's known better days. David-2 read his own introduction of Ilfracombe that starts his biofiction. Several others of us read our own views of seaside squalor. The scond was brainstorming plots for Dr Who. Guy revealed a massive history of writing for the Dr Who fanzine, three novels, a beastiary, and various plot proposals. What an unsuspected gold mine of Who-ology!

For our next meeting I'd like to discuss method of critique, which means how we can best frame our commentary on each other's work to be useful and relevant. I've copied a really good set of Rules of Critique I found online to the Google Drive that we can read before the next meeting, and then discuss together. The link is here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1PhC4loFL2xOfMYZhXG6pU6yU5096KJ5z

And, of course, bring along some writing to read to us so that we can put into practice the wisdom we acquire.

See you next Tuesday at the Thames Court!

title: David's 'Short Story Checklist' . . . And more readings!
description:
We had a really good discussion of the Rules of Critique at the 21/01/20 meeting. (Wordsmith drive link: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1PhC4loFL2xOfMYZhXG6pU6yU5096KJ5z)

Rosina had the inspiration to try to apply the method of critique to the winning short stories from the Exeter short story competition (previously won by our neighbour Elizabeth some years ago). She noted that all winning stories were very well written, with good follow through, and each had a little surprise for the reader.

Karen read us a bit of of Diane Setterfield's 'Once Upon A River' about how blokes in a pub celebrated the variety and use of new words, stretching each other as collectors of words. It sounds so charming that I've ordered my own copy of this best-selling novel: https://www.amazon.co.uk/Once-Upon-River-Diane-Setterfield/dp/1784163635/

Wingman David told us how he likes to set a scene by bringing multiple senses into play in the reader's mind, then drive right into the action with the active voice and some emotional engagement. He had reworked his 400 word story 'Nearly Christmas' to add a mother in the house, and it charmed us all this time when he read it for us.

Gerry read us his own words of wisdom on criticism. It begins: "Criticising, a minefield of opinion, explosive egos, feelings, hopes, ambitions, prejudices, preferences, grievances, grudges, and perhaps not in equal measure, genuine goodwill and admiration for a good work or performance." The whole thing is worth re-reading, though it won't be as good without Gerry's narration! I've scanned the half page and added it to our Wordsmith Drive here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1S9odzzzjnrj_SZNzPZB_bJB4RV7wPl13

Guy gave us some history of Angles, Saxons and Normans. I always enjoy a new perspective on Alfred (Saxon), Aethelstan (Anglo-Danish), and William the Conqueror. His history emphasised the mongrel nature of an early England that emerged from serial migrations and conquests to coalesce in the medieval era as a young nation with its own imperial ambitions and its own wide-ranging mercantile sea army.

David-2 gave us the beginning of a 'Christmas Ghost' where Steve advances from the windy shore of Ilfracombe into an abandonned hotel where 'memories are broken and painful'.

We agreed at the next meeting to review Wingman David's checklist for editing short stories. I've put in in the Wordsmith Drive here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1C0hHSeFShtkgpDIMKDoBHr5gVhu68308

See you Tuesday!

title: Writing Apps - What's your experience?  And Readings
description:
We had a good discussion of Wingman's Short Story Checklist (https://drive.google.com/open?id=1S9odzzzjnrj_SZNzPZB_bJB4RV7wPl13). The key takeaways are:
- Has the story been read aloud?
- Engage with a strong opening sentence
- Ground the reader's experience in their 5 senses
- Use pacing to move the story along
- Convey a unique voice

Wingman and Mike then gave a reading of 'The Algorithm Trap', an attempt to raise awareness of the receding role of human agency and human control as Big Data and complex technologies gain more and more leverage over our experience of the world, and they never forget anything about us with the aim of ever higher profits, executive bonuses and share prices. "Yeah, crazy world, innit?"

Mike then shared 'half a story' which teased us by weaving our diverse Wordsmith interests together as a very clever tapestry: out of season seaside, ghost, a cat named Max, music, romance, looming violence and jealousy, and a windswept esplanade after 'Max the Sax and Carrie the Canay clicked' . . . MORE PLEASE! The characterisation, cadence and pace were thrilling.

Guy gave us his long trailed essay on Trump and Obama. 'Yes We Can! No, we couldn't.' Both compromised American values and political identity, if in very different ways.

David2 gave us more James Allen biofiction from Illfracombe, this time featuring dialogue as his character Bill quotes Allen in conversation: "Actions and circumstances will follow your thoughts. Master your thoughts and you can do anything."

Next time I thought we should discuss how technology is adapting to support complex writing. Wired Magazine (one of the best written journals there is anywhere) pointed me to a new writing app aimed at complex fictional worlds, developed by a writer 'to scratch is own itch'. Have a look at Granthika: https://granthika.co/

I hope David2 will also tell us more about the app he uses for his writing, and that others will share their technology experiences.

See you upstairs at the Thames Court, Tuesday!

title: Writing from Life - and other Readings
description:
We were delighted to welcome Mandy back from her adventure in Australia. It sounds like she had such a good time that we risk losing her to an Antipodean writing group. Even with fires and floods and plagues she loved it there! David enthused about a 'flash writing' competition which gave him an award just for waiting until the last minute to make his submission.

I'm afraid the rest of the evening is a bit of a blur. Rosina and I had spent all day in a mediation with the Countil over the parking dispute at Shepperton Lock and we were exhausted. I wrote something to read, but ended up deciding to save it for the next meeting.

What I'll be reading is rather special. It is an account from life of a rather surprising discovery that made local news.

As an exercise for the next meeting I thought we all might bring something we wrote from a life experience. I know it will be a broad range from the lot of us, given some of the life-inspired writings shared at previous gatherings. Ghosts, travels, cats, and so much more.

The Christmas Party was such a success we decided to have another social event on the Island when the weather warms. Bring your diaries on Tuesday so we can decide a date for a boat trip on Diona followed by croquet and barbeque on the Green.

And watch for the next Shepperton News. David sent a story which has gone forward to the editor. No feedback yet, but fingers crossed.

title: Lockdown Stories - Just staying in touch with Wordsmiths!
description:
David, Rosina and I miss you all and want to catch up with you if we can. We contemplate a Zoom meeting at the usual time of 19:30 on Tuesday, 12th May.

The free version of Zoom limits meetings to 40 minutes so it will have to be a quick tour-de-table among us on how we're all coping with Lockdown and whether we are writing or not. We'll save any readings until we decide whether we want to continue on Zoom for further meetings.

You MUST RSVP to get the link to the Zoom meeting. Meetup will only confirm the link and password to Wordsmiths who confirm they are attending. You will need functioning microphone, speakers and optional camera to participate.

Back in January when Covid-19 was just beginning its spread from China, I was minded to look up Edgar Allen Poe's 'The Masque of the Red Death'. It remains curiously relevant in our own times. Enjoy!

https://www.public.asu.edu/~cajsa/eng200_fall07/The%20Masque%20of%20the%20Red%20Death.pdf

See you (virtually) next Tuesday.

Kathleen

title: Something in the background . . .
description:
So we had our first Wordsmiths Zoom meeting, and it was pretty cool, even with just four of us: David, James, Karen and me. There were some screw ups. Mike tried to get in but I must not have seen him in the virtual waiting room. I'll try to do better!

Few of us seem to be taking advantage of Lock Down to write much. I know I'm not. But perhaps if we encourage each other, we'll get back up to pace.

We've decide to have another Zoom Meetup on Tuesday, 26th May, at the usual time of 19:30. Zoom could have cut us off at 40 minutes as I've got the free account so far, but actually gave us as much time as we wanted. We'll test that generosity again next week!

It was fascinating to see everyone in their homes rather than around the table at the Thames Court. As a writing exercise for next week the proposal agreed was to write 1000 words more or less about an object in the background on Zoom. If this is your home, it may be an object in the background with meaning to you. As I've got pretty full shelves behind me, I'll have to think on that one.

James showed us his Zoom proficiency by switching to a rainforest then a woodland background. If you prefer to switch backgrounds, write a story suitable for the one chosen.

Here's a blog post on how easy it is to switch backgrounds and offering some images:
https://www.owllabs.com/blog/zoom-virtual-background

See you next Tuesday!

title: Bills & Moon Burnt Book Exercise
description:
Our Zoom Wordsmiths is growing! We had five (Karen, David, Rosina, Guy and myself) on the last Zoom meeting, and very friendly it was too. Karen gave us a tour around her sitting room, with polar bears, RLS books and an oriental desk. Guy read an amazing piece of 'flash fiction' with "Death by Writers Workshop" that referenced some of us had me reaching for the carving knife and duct tape. Rosina showed us the brass 'lucky miner's shoe' match holders from her mantle that remind her of a happy interval of kindness and simplicity as a little girl. David gave us the origins and history of the fabulous rug hanging behind his desk that he found in a skip, used to cushion his knees for oil changes for 10 years, then took for expert cleaning to find it was valued amongst his treasures. I shared my adventures in Iraq in 2003. Then we just chatted as the time fled away. Zoom was once again gracious enough to ignore the 40 minute limit on my free plan.

If Zoom ever does cut us off, I will schedule a further meeting for 5 minutes afterwards, and immediately send around an invite. In the event, check your emails.

Last year a house tragically burnt down on Hamhaugh Island. A few weeks later a single page of burnt book landed on my front path, blown there by the wind. We used that fragment in Wordsmiths for one of our more successful - and enlightening - writing exercises. All the blokes wrote about car chases and violent death. All the chicks wrote about tearful anxiety for a sister's hurt feelings. Genders may be equal, but we are definitely not the same!

The book page was traced to a Mills & Boon bodice ripper. Since we're distorting the content to our own preferences, I'm calling it the Bills & Moon exercise, echoing a slip I once made to your delight.

Two weeks ago another wind brought another single page of burnt book to my path. Let's have another go, shall we? Start with the fragment above and write us what happens next to Mary after she is discovered on the dyke at night.

Once again you will need to RSVP to this invite to see the Zoom link and password. Email me if you have trouble.

title: Bills & Moon Burnt Book Exercise, Part II
description:
Part I of the Bills & Moon Burnt Book Exerise took me by surprise yesterday evening. Guy called to ask me why the Zoom meeting wasn't started. It was because I thought it was next Tuesday, in our usual slot, but had made an error in the configuration of the Meetup invite, leaving the date unedited for Thursday evening.

Because we had assumed it was next week, neither Mike nor I had written to the exercise. Details on the exercise in the previous Meetup invitation: https://www.meetup.com/Shepperton-Wordsmiths-Meetup/events/271053792/

Ah well, it worked out just fine. There were 5 Wordsmiths on the Zoom meeting: Guy, David, Mike, Mandy and me. Guy, David and Mandy had written to the Bills & Moon exercise and each was chillingly wonderful. David's take on the events after Mary was captured on the dyke at night had her gain a bloody but satisfying revenge on her tormentor. Guy's adaptation had Mary flee into the night, pursued in her terror by a vengeful squire, and only saved by spirits of other maidens despoiled by evil squires who rose from the bog to save her. Mandy led us one way and then surprised us at the end. Her Mary had no escape, succumbing to blows, murdered by her captor, but had satisfaction at last in having secured some treasure to her aunt, who had quite accurately predicted how Mary would meet her death.

Although all 3 writers chose to write thrillers starting with our bit of burnt scrip, they were each very different in tone and events. What fun!

Next followed a discourse on D'Oyly Carte Island, which was vandalised over the weekend. I agreed to try to find some interior pictures to share. While doing that I got nosy and looked up the ownership on Companies House, writing to the owners about the vandalism and grafitti, and our worries about arson risk. The message has been passed on and hopefully some action will be taken to restore security on the site.

Following on, Guy read us again his Writers' Club flash fiction, which was just as wonderful second time around.

So next week will be more of the Bills & Moon exercises from those of us who were unprepared this week. And with such time as Zoom permits, I'll be prepared to share some pictures of Eyot House on D'Oyly Carte Island. It's such a romantic ruin, we might have a future exercise set in its interior. . .

title: What made you laugh, caught your attention, and why?
description:
Hey there, Wordsmiths, and apologies for this going up so late. It's been on my list, but I find things come off the list slower and slower these days.

We had a small but fun Wordsmiths on Zoom on 9th June. I completed the Bills & Moon fragment with proper bodice-ripper attraction, temptation, and seduction - but made Mary the aggressor in 'warming' up to the lonely farmer who gave her shelter from the moor. As Rosina commented afterward: "Steamy, provocative, tut tut! Will they or won't they . . ."

David gave us one of his twist-in-the-tale endings, leading us to expect a wronged husband pursuing his wife with murderous intent, only to have her protector kill her lover on the moor instead.

Guy gave us an evolution of economics from the Stone Age through the ages to modern economies, necessarily eliding over some of the small stuff like successive empires and religions.

Rosina hadn't written anything, but after came up with her preferred exercise for our next meeting: What made you laugh this week, or what caught your attention on a walk and why?

I used the picture above because I remember in 1990 when I first encountered a "Dogs Must Be Carried" sign on the Underground at the escalators, I thought to myself, "I don't have a dog. Do I need to take the stairs?" I smile still whenever I see this sign.

We have decided to meet every two weeks, as we used to in the real world before Covid-19.

By the way, the Zoom link I send out for meetings is the same every time. So once you have it, copy it somewhere handy, like two weeks forward in your diary, and you'll always be able to reuse it.

title: What made you laugh this week, or what caught your attention on a walk and why?
description:
Apologies again for last minute invite, but as agreed at last meeting we are repeating the exercise: What made you laugh this week, or what caught your attention on a walk and why?

I must have lock down brain, as I've intended to have this up every day since cancelling last Tuesday.

At our last meeting we welcomed Sally from Dorking, who read us her composition "Holy Loudness" about the blessings of the dawn chorus in rural Surrey.
Guy entertained us with a piece on badly composed instructions for technology from China.
I read a composition about a sudden encountet with a grass snake here on the Island, and another short scene from my Viking effort.

When we meet tonight via Zoom we can discuss whether and when we want to resume meetings at the Thames Court Pub, now that it has re-opened.

title: Next Shepperton Wordsmiths meeting
description:
I hope that all you busy Wordsmiths are still writing, keeping well, enjoying the summer weather and successfully dodging the “Curse of Covid”.
Kathleen has kindly consented to my hosting our next meeting and I’m planning one for next Tuesday, being August 11th at the usual time of 7:30 pm.
