Now I don’t know how you all feel but after observing the displacement and general demeanour of people drinking outside our usual pub venue I’m not so sure that all of our population has yet grasped that the fun ain’t over yet, and so I’m steering clear of pubs and clubs. For the time being at least. Hopefully you’re all now comfortable with Zoom and so we’ll be meeting there.
At Rosina’s suggestion we would like you to select an item that is quirky, fun, or has a special place in your heart or home and request that you have it ready for a “Show and Tell” to the rest of us. Or alternatively, as usual you’d be welcome to entertain us with a reading. But please bear in mind that we have only 40 minutes or so in total and we’d like everyone to have the opportunity of a slot.
Looking forward to seeing you there!
David

title: Wordsmiths Assemble!  We're back at the Thames Court . . .
description:
At our most recent Zoom meeting we all agreed that it was time to reconvene upstairs at the Thames Court. I've spoken to Brandon, the manager, and he is delighted we want to return. There is a limit currently on groups to a maximum of 8, so he has not been able to book the room out for events otherwise. We have not generally exceeded 8 recently, and never in Zoom meetings, so I'm confident we can keep within this bound for the near-term.

Because of the size restriction, I'd like everyone who plans to attend to RSVP using Meetup. If you have not registered as one of the first 8, you may not be able to attend. If we hit the limit, we can explore a Zoom connection for virtual participation.

Of course, if you do register to attend, and then change your plans, please release your place via Meetup so that another Wordsmith can come along instead.

To celebrate our coming together at the Thames Court, let's make the first writing challenge a pub story. It can be based on real life or imagination, and a riverside pub setting is preferred. We might even share some stories with Brandon as a way of saying 'thanks'.

title: Punishing Your Characters (readers are sadists)
description:
Wordsmiths reassembled upstairs at the Thames Court for the first time since Lock Down on 1st September. There were just four of us, but that let us space ourselves around a single large round table. It was great to catch up.

Guy was congratulated for finishing 'Ironclaw', his novel about a Native American fighting pollution on ancestral lands. He then read us 'Blue', a poem to a lost love, a blue-eyed golden-skinned girl. The poem evokes the cadence of waves on the shore and was quite moving.

David then gave us a gloomy visit to the 'Rose & Crown' on a Saturday afternoon after a long period abroad. All the regulars he counted as friends were discovered to have been imprisoned, fired, killed in accidents or debilitated by strokes, leaving him unable to share his stories or jokes over a pint. All except for Old Ben, the publican's dog inherited by the new owner. For once David's story has a happy ending. Instead of a twist in the tail there is a wagging tail.

Mandy gave us a charming and funny poem 'I name this pub' that runs through the possible names for a modern pub ('lukewarm pint and freezing loo') before deciding the name should fit the clientele: 'The Grumpy Goat'.

I read a re-written opening to my narrowboat thriller that put Water Nomad and her skipper on a mooring in front of the Thames Court. After all, it's better to write what you know. Sharp-eared David caught me out in getting the river's direction of flow wrong in one passage, so further work needed.

Next time we'll be up-skilling with advice from Erik Bork's 'The Idea: the seven elements of a viable story for screen, stage or fiction'. The topic will be punishing your characters with a very big, difficult and plot-sustaining problem or series of problems. As Erik says, "Audiences are basically sadists." As an exercise think about the problem your main character faces in your stories and how the tension it creates carries the audience along with the story.

And some readings from you, of course.

I was going to write personally to some lapsed Wordsmiths we miss to try to get numbers up for next week, but as the maximum for these meetings has been reduced by Covid-19's surge from 8 to 6 persons, we'll hold off on that.

As before, please RSVP using Meetup to confirm your place.

title: Zooming Wordsmiths reprised (sigh)!
description:
Sadly, it looks like we're back to meeting virtually via Zoom for a bit while plague ravages the land.
We'll meet tonight using the same old Zoom link from previous Zoom meetings.
I've not prepared anything yet, but suggest we carry on with the next chapter of Erik Bork's 'The Idea'. The chapter is on making characters 'relatable' so the audience is engaged enough to care what happens to them.
And, of course, if you are writing we will welcome your readings.

title: ZOOM-ing again!
description:
Take a break! Give your keyboard a rest (or for those traditionalists amongst us scrub the ink from your fingers) and join us online for an hour or so of motivational insights, witty conversation and a chance to entertain the rest of us with an extract from your latest work.

We're looking forward to greeting all you new members too, so make sure you RSVP to get the url link right away and log-in before the start.

See you there!

title: The Spirits are about to walk again........
description:
Lockdown. Covid. Brexit. Presidential election. Darker evenings. Winter approaching fast.
All very scary, but even scarier and coming up fast – HALLOWEEN.
And we would like you to read your new ghostly short story to the rest of us via Zoom.
Will it be traditional Gothic? Or contemporary? Or sci-fi? Or historical? Unshackle your imagination and set it free!
Place your story in any location and in any age, and bear in mind that not all ghosts are necessarily post-human. Or so I’ve heard.
We start at 7:30pm next Tuesday 27th, so you’ve a whole weekend to create your contribution.
Please don't forget to RSVP.

And I for one am already feeling the hairs on the back of my neck starting to prickle……….

title: “Publish and be damned”
description:
So said Arthur Wellesley, twice British Prime Minister and 1st Duke of Wellington to Joseph Stockdale, publisher, who was trying to blackmail him into being left out of the memoirs of one Harriette Wilson, “retired London courtesan” in 1824.

Those of us who have produced work of publishable quality might be only too pleased to receive the attentions of a publisher who would also take on the attendant marketing, but in the event a number of us have taken to self-publishing. And so the question of how to effectively market our work remains.

This session is dedicated to “Marketing” and we are looking forward to a collective sharing of our experiences, and Haley is going to tell us about this subject from the “small press” perspective.

So don’t be late!

title: Short notice. Short story. You have just 99 hours. Can you meet the challenge?
description: In just 99 hours you will be invited to read your "Boys Own" adventure story where the baddies get taken out by the good guys in the nick of time. Meetup with us in secret at the usual Zoom address. Usual time.

title: Fairy Tales and a Virtual Christmas Party
description:
Hey there, Wordsmiths! We were a tiny crowd of three for our most recent meeting, so David handed the admin back to me in despair. Cheer us both up with a Fairy Tale for our next and final meeting of 2020 on 15th December. You won't have the excuse of the office Christmas party this year for missing it!

I thought we would write Fairy Tales for our exercise, inspired by the very beautiful leather-bound collection that Rosina gave me for my last birthday. The image above is the title page of the 1913 first edition of Clair de Lune and Other Troubadour Romances by Michael West, illustrated by Evelyn Paul, and music by Alfred Mereer.

As you would expect, the book came with a story. Rosina was given £20 by her mother-in-law for her 21st birthday to buy a new dress. Instead, she disappointed by buying three first edition books from an estate liquidation in a London used bookshop. The other two were later stolen, so this was the only one remaining.

A week before she died Rosina gave me her final gift, a painting of the cherry tree in her garden with the table where we shared so many lovely tea parties, and Rosina herself in the Thames holding the side of her beloved rowboat and smiling, her blue eyes shining. You can see some of her paintings at her website: http://www.rosinalyford.com/. She was Royal Academy and exhibited all over the world.

Rosina passed away on 27th November, as gracefully as she lived, at home, in her own room fronting the Thames. Her granddaughter held her hand, and Ed sat by her as she slipped into the next life. Despite writing about ghosts in many of her stories, I saw her shortly afterward and don't think she left one. She was ready to cross over to wherever she is now.

This will be our last meeting for 2020, and it is a year I will be happy to see ending. Let's all look forward to 1st January 2021, when everybody will have 20/20 hindsight!

title: Wordsmiths Re-Assemble! Back to the Thames Court . . .
description:
It's been a long time coming, but we'll be welcomed back by the Thames Court Pub in our old upstairs room from September. Some of you have written to say how much you are looking foward to getting back together to share writing, encouragement, and fun. Me too!

I had another article accepted for publication yesterday. It's probably too boring to be of general interest, but it's still something to celebrate.

Bring something of your writing to read, if you've been writing. It doesn't matter how little or how unfinished. We're always welcoming and supportive.

Anyone new who wants to join will also be made very welcome.

title: Wordsmiths Afloat!
description:
We had our first in-person meeting of Wordsmiths in 2021 yesterday evening, upstairs at the Thames Court, as of old. There were only five of us, but the core Wordsmiths since our early days.

Many of us found we had writers' block during the past year and a half of disrupted life. Apparently it is a recognised and quite common condition. Human interactions and a bit of randomness in life sustain the creative spirit.
https://ethos3.com/2021/04/pandemic-writers-block-is-real/

Karen, David and I offered readings. Karen read the prologue of her memoir, introducing herself from birth as a changeling forced to share a human life. David gave us a humorous and all too accurate story of the frustration getting any kind of appointment with a local GP under pandemic-revised restrictive rules of engagement. I read the first chapter of my end-of-life rom-com documenting the loss of Rosina, one of the founder Wordsmiths and a dear friend and neighbour. It was deemed hilarious, something Rosina would approve, though sadly I am the butt of every joke.

Mandy updated us on the progress of the adventurous dog Phoebe toward publication. Mike may take up his guide to the statues in central London, or such as are left after the 'woke' cull.

So now that we are all double-jabbed and can meet together and write again, it's time to make Wordsmiths even more fun and inspirational. We agreed to have a Wordsmiths Afloat day on the Thames, venturing to a more distant pub on my lovely broads cruiser Diona.

I'll pick everyone up at Shepperton Lock for a cruise downriver to the Weir Hotel at Sunbury (where I found poor Mr Sturgess floating peacefully just downstream in February 2020). We'll enjoy their delicious food and drink, and then cruise back at a leisurely pace that will offer everyone on board a chance to take the wheel.

Because this event is kind of special, and space onboard is limited to 10 passengers, we agreed to limit participation to Wordsmiths who have actually attended an in-person meeting at some point prior. Please don't feel excluded if you don't make the cut, and join us instead at the usual Thames Court Wordsmiths on 21 September 2021 - the following Tuesday - 19:30.

title: Filling the Frames with Word Pictures
description:
We were intrigued by the five empty frames adorning the grey wall above us at the Thames Court upstairs room yesterday evening.

We discussed how these empty frames might be filled, not just with art, but with stories, with poetry, with haiku. (David learned anew of the ancient word art: https://www.britannica.com/art/haiku)

So our exercise for the next meeting at the Thames Court - not the jolly boat ride the week before - is to write something to fill an empty frame. Even with writers' block we should all be able to manage the 17 syllables (arranged in three lines of 5, 7, and 5 syllables respectively) of a haiku, if not something more substantial.

Mike, who sent the photo above, is clearly up for the challenge. The accompanying email read:

Empty frames watch us
Gather to test our secret
Scrawled imaginings

Note that we are reverting to the later meeting time of 19:30 which was customary for our meetings before lockdown. And also please bring £3 toward the costs of MeetUp and room rate.
